PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; BEALE; BRAITHWAITE; BROWN; CAMERON; CHARLESWORTH; COURTICE; FIFE; FISCHER; GOODLUCK; GRIFFITHS; HALL; HAWKE; HICKS; JAKOBSEN; JENKINS; JOHNS; JULL; KELLY; LLOYD; MACKELLAR; MARTIN; MILTON; MOORE; MORRIS; MORRIS; NEHL; PEACOCK; PRATT; SHACK; SHARP; SNOW; SNOWDON; TUCKEY; WHITE; WOODS

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the Treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

That we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 27 citizens), Mr Beale (from two citizens), Mr Braithwaite (from 162 citizens), Mr N.A. Brown (from 58 citizens), Mr Ian Cameron (from 27 citizens), Dr Charlesworth (from 81 citizens), Mr Courtice (from 54 citizens), Mr Fife (from 103 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 86 citizens), Mr Goodluck (from 192 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 26 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 136 citizens), Mr Hawke (from 106 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 54 citizens), Ms Jakobsen (from 56 citizens), Mr Jenkins (from 163 citizens), Mr Johns (from 136 citizens), Mr Jull (from 212 citizens), Mrs Kelly (from 134 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from 81 citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 133 citizens), Mr Martin (from 184 citizens), Mr Milton (from 27 citizens), Mr Moore (from 27 citizens), Mr Allan Morris (from 54 citizens), Mr Peter Morris (from 27 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 256 citizens), Mr Peacock (from two citizens), Mr Pratt (from 54 citizens), Mr Shack (from 27 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 79 citizens), Mr Snow (from 192 citizens), Mr Snowdon (from 27 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 94 citizens), Mr White (from 84 citizens), and Dr Woods (from 74 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 potentially life saving pharmaceutical drugs-including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, and high cholesterol-and place them on a special list requiring Authority from a Health Department official in Canberra, and;

That we believe that a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to waste valuable time referring a case to an official in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly ask that the House request the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whilst acknowledging the Government's desire to contain the growth in health costs, the introduction of 61 new drugs to the `Authority Required' listing will result in potentially serious delays in patients receiving medication prescribed by their doctors.
Your petitioners request the House to immediately reverse the Government's decision and withdraw these drugs from the `Authorities Required' list.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 88 citizens), Mr Dobie (from 164 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 166 citizens) and Mr Tuckey (from 56 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to fringe benefits of persons who in good faith bought market linked insurance bonds, friendly society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts to protect their savings.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lloyd (from 43 citizens), Mr McArthur (from 74 citizens) and Mr Pratt (from 230 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography: X-rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence, with deterrent penalties, and
Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect of X-rated videos, (and ER) and end the shameful Canberra trade, and the Mafia connections.
Because 98% of Australians in other States have banned X-rated videos.
Because the trade is still flourishing, and it's availability escalates sexual crime.
Because importers of child pornography face only a fine for lying.
Because child pornography peddlers are safe if they cross a border, and cannot be extradited for a summary offence.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration.
And your petitoners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from two citizens) and Mr Carlton (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Non-Violent Erotica Video Classification
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has:
- degraded men;
- lowered the status of women;
- affected the safety of children; and
- escalated crime including sexual crime.
Because the Parliament has a role to play in the well-being of the people of this Nation, your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. not adopt a Non-Violent Erotica (NVE) Video classification;
2. not permit NVE in cinemas;
3. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as it is;
4. control ALL Censorship criteria by substantive legislation; and

5. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that NO Attorney General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Goodluck (from 234 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 39 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We pray that the House immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent (from 506 citizens) and Mr Milton (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Romania: Human Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled. We the undersigned, are appalled that the Romanian Government plans the commencement of the destruction in September of 7000 villages, hundreds of thousands of peaceful homes and homesteads, thousands of churches, historic monuments and cemeteries. With this barbaric action millions of people will be disadvantaged, even sent to their death with these Totalitarian actions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give these matters earnest consideration and request the Romanian Government to abandon these horrific acts against the Romanian Community and its minorities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Federal Government proposes to place the anti-epileptic medication sodium valproate (`Epilim') on the `Authority only' listing as of 1st August 1988. Your petitioners believe that this may well cause great problems for the people who take Epilim, for whom no effective alternative medication is available.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will rescind the decision to place sodium valproate (`Epilim') on the `Authority only' listing.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Income Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned draws attention to the House of the inequitable attack on pensioners of the Federal Government's proposed changes to the pension income test.
The changes will penalise those who have genuinely attempted self-provision in retirement and will eventually produce more dependency on Governments in the future.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
The Federal Government has reaped an unprecedented amount of revenue in taxation recently, over and above expectations:
PAYE tax payers are losing one quarter and more of earnings through direct tax deductions:
Sales taxes which are charged on a vast range of everyday goods and necessities add to the taxes already imposed on wage earners:
The range of compulsory licences, fees, and charges imposed by governments and Statutory Authorities further erode family disposable incomes

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House immediately reduce PAYE taxes and all Sales Tax by one third and hold all Government and Statutory Authority charges at the current level for a minimum four-year period.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House compel TV stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes, by fifty per cent.

PETITION.TITLE: National Anthem
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned, request that the last line in each chorus of the National Song be altered from:
Advance Australia Fair to God Bless Australia Fair.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Private Airstrip: Luskintyre, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House.

To the increased number of aircraft movements at a private airstrip at Luskintyre, Lochinvar. Because of the airstrip's small area the aircraft have to pass low over people's houses, thus creating undue noise and an invasion of privacy. A large amount of time is spent by the Company in take-offs and landings and in performing aerobatics. This constant, monotonous droning is a source of great irritation to the peace of the area.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Benchmarks for Commonwealth Public Servants and Defence Force Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in spite of many petitions and other communications, we are dismayed and disgusted at the lack of will on the part of the Parliament to restore to retired Commonwealth Public Servants and Defence Force Personnel, pension benchmarks which were affected by a two per cent discount as part of the budget brought down in 1986.

Having regard to assurances given by the Government that the base will be restored, your Petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, act to ensure that this is done without further delay so as to remove the permanent and compounding effects of this discriminatory action taken under the guise of the entire community sharing the economic burden.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Australia card will be an attack on the civil liberties and privacy of all Australians, will not achieve the claimed results, will provide a boost to organised crime and will be an enormous burden to the private sector, especially small business, already snowed under with government charges, taxes and red tape.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to abandon legislation for any type of national identity system and work toward building a society based on trust not suspicion.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
The irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House:
(1) Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
(2) Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
(3) Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
(4) Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth that:

There is inadequate provision in the Constitution for national referenda and the people are therefore denied sufficient opportunity to oppose or introduce legislation of national importance or consequence.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled urge the Parliament to: amend the Constitution to provide for the holding of national referenda in the following cases:
(1) If four per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to proposed legislation.
(2) If four per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to existing legislation.
(3) If eight per cent of the electors petition the House of Representatives and/or the Senate with regard to introducing legislation proposed by the electors.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fishing Agreement with the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the activities of the Soviet Union in our region and in particular the South Pacific are detrimental to and threaten the security of our country.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House urge the Government not to enter into a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Income Test for Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House: to the retrospective changes proposed by the Hawke Labor Government to the pension income test.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House: reject the unfair and retrospective changes proposed to the treatment of capital growth investments under the proposed new income test for pensions.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia wish to express their absolute opposition to the Privatisation and Deregulation of the Australian Telecommunications Industry. Your petitioners humbly pray that the House will take the necessary steps to ensure:-
That Telecom's social responsibilities are preserved and extended and adequately funded.
That the telephone service is accessible and affordable to all.
The maintenance of public ownership and control of telecommunications services in Australia.

That Telecom consumers' rights are respected by the establishment of mechanisms whereby their grievances can be adequately represented. Especially domestic, small business and socially disadvantaged people within the community.
Also, your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will reject current proposals to:
Impose State and Local charges and taxes on Telecom.
Alter the legal status, employment conditions and organisation of Telecom from a public sector service provider to a commercial corporation.
Take away Telecom's regulatory function and place this with a new body called Austel.
Remove Telecom's ``Buy Australia'' policy, thus threatening local manufacturing.

PETITION.TITLE: Canberra to Batemans Bay Road
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
Grave concern with the insufficient level of Government grants provided for carrying out improvements to the Canberra/Batemans Bay (MR51) Road.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that your House will call upon the Government to take whatever steps are necessary to allow for and provide special substantial direct funding to carry out the necessary improvements to the road, and, further, call upon the New South Wales State Government to accept greater financial responsibility for the upgrading and maintenance of the said road.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Graduate Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain residents of the Northern Territory draws to the attention of the House that they wish the principle of Free Further and Tertiary Education to continue. Your petitioners therefore request the House to oppose the imposition of a Tertiary Graduate Tax.

PETITION.TITLE: New Caledonia
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Federal Parliament.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory respectfully showeth concern at the situation facing the Kanak people of Kanaky (New Caledonia).
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Speaker and the Members of the House:
-support the right of the Kanak people to self determination and independence;
-acknowledge the FLNKS as the legitimate representative of the Kanak people and acknowledge their refusal to recognise the April 24 elections in Kanaky (New Caledonia);

-urge the French Government to abandon their current path, withdraw the military forces in Kanaky (New Caledonia) and enter into dialogue with the FLNKS to ensure a peaceful transition to Independence;
and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of T-Shirt
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory Electorate respectfully showeth that:
The sale of the T-Shirt entitled ``Ski The Slopes'' is racially divisive and not conducive to harmony in our multicultural society.
Your petitioners therefore humble pray that the Australian Parliament take some action to prevent the shirt from being sold.
and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely extensively on the local road network for all facets of their lives. Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infra-structure. Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled,

Oppose any proposal to absorb road funds into General Revenue Assistance to either Local or State Governments; and Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws the attention of the House to the public concern over the creation of human embryos for the specific purpose of fatal experimental research. The citizens are concerned that human life is deliberately being created with the premeditated intention to destroy it. They believe that this is a gross breach of the responsibility that each member of the human race has to another to ensure life is allowed to thrive and develop according to nature.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House do all in its power to ban the creation of embryos for the specific purpose of life destroying research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-
(1) the Government's failed social and economic policies have caused widespread poverty among Australian families which will not be overcome by the Government's new family assistance package; and

(2) the Government must reverse the record interest rates, high unemployment, high marginal tax rates, housing shortages, high rents and falling value of family allowances if it is to offer real assistance to Australian families.

In 1983 the Australian Labor Party was elected on the promise of an improvement in social and economic conditions in this nation. After six Budgets and four mini-Budgets, the devastating truth is that we are all paying more tax than ever before and yet the level of poverty and homelessness is higher than at any time since the depression. The massive increase in tax revenue has not been used to help the less well off in our community but rather it has been scandalously wasted. Prior to the election, Labor pretended to be interested in the poor and under-privileged, but once in office it forgot its grass roots and has concentrated instead on looking after its rich mates and its colleagues. I hear some scoffs from members of the Government benches. Perhaps they might like to talk to the Federal Secretary, Mr Bob Hogg.

He even complained the other day about too many Labor Party members of Parliament and ex-Keating-Hawke Government Ministers having their snouts in the trough. So its own Federal Secretary is claiming that the Government has too many of its colleagues with their snouts in the trough. Hogg was right. Labor has grossly abused its position of power. It is patently obvious that the Hawke-Keating Government will continue to mouth platitudes about the plight of middle and low income families, but it will actually do absolutely nothing. It is intent on ripping off the taxpayer and using the money to suit its own party political objectives. The $46m shamefully wasted on the referendums is just one recent example. That was a blatantly partisan attempt to change the Constitution to suit its own purposes-but the public was not fooled. Not only were all of the proposals rejected, but in three out of four of them the Government suffered the biggest voter backlash since Federation. Every by-election this year has reinforced the message-the electorate has had enough; Labor's policies have failed-but from the blank look on Ministers' faces, they have not yet got the message.

The concern expressed in the motion I have moved today is about the catastrophic impact Labor's policies have had on the less well off in our society. There is agreement among social commentators today that the indicators for measuring and describing poverty have risen over the last five years. It is generally agreed that more than two million Australians now live below the poverty line. Of even greater concern is the increase in child poverty under the Labor Government. It was this factor, I am sure, that caused the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to make that historic commitment that he would fix child poverty by the mid-1990s. Of course, since the election he has proceeded to back-pedal from that promise at 100 miles per hour. Today Australia has the second highest rate of child poverty of all comparable Organisation for Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries. What a record! And the Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that he is bringing home the bacon! Authors Saunders and Whiteford, in their evaluation last year of the Government's child poverty initiatives, stated:
To be blunt about things, child poverty in Australia has reached unacceptable levels and is a disgrace, both nationally and internationally.

That is from a report on the Government's child poverty initiatives. One in every five Australian children now live in poverty. That is 825,000 children-165,000 or 20 per cent more than when Labor came to office in 1983. The last coalition Government introduced the family allowance as a targeted benefit to assist families with the high cost of raising children. But this Government has allowed the value of that payment to be eroded by 30 per cent. Instead of spending millions of dollars on the taxpayer-funded media machine pumping out misleading information about how wonderful the Government is, the Prime Minister would do the nation a service by focusing on and addressing some of the real problems his Government has created.

A Department of Community Services and Health study reported this year that at least 700,000 households-that is nearly 1 1/2 million Australians-have been forced into what it calls housing poverty. That is because under the Government's high interest rate policy, together with the reduction in home purchase assistance, families are being forced to make huge sacrifices in food, clothing, transportation, education, health care and other essentials just to pay for a roof over their heads. More families are in poverty because of housing costs and Labor's high interest rate policy has put more than ever before on queues for public housing. Though not a recent outcome of poverty in Australia the extent of homelessness is growing in seriousness and magnitude. The Sydney City Mission estimates that Australia's homeless now number 40,000-with a further 40,000 so called street kids. The face of Australia's homeless is changing. The unshaven face of the old man is giving way to families with young children, teenage boys and girls, young men and young women in the prime of adulthood from all walks of life. Last year the Sydney City Mission beat buses picked up 22,000 people and the mission itself is turning away on average 39 homeless families and 100 homeless young people each month.

One of the areas where the flaws in the Government's economic policy are hitting hardest is the area of unemployment. Unemployment figures have recently begun to decline but other cruel and more damaging changes in the unemployed population are beginning to appear. Since Labor has come to office the average length of time spent unemployed has grown from 33 weeks to 51 weeks. The lengthening duration of unemployment and the increase in the number of long-term unemployed not only is a large social cost to the nation but also affects economic efficiency.

The greater the duration of unemployment the lower the probability of regaining employment; work skills of the unemployed atrophy quickly, and this creates a demand for retraining and job experience programs. But the Government's employment and training programs are all hype and no action-jobs, employment and training, Priority One: Young Australia, Jobstart, Go For It and I am sure honourable members have heard of many more. They are great for public relations but the situation is getting worse.

The stark reality is that almost one in five young Australians cannot find work. In addition, increases in unemployment have affected families with children the most. Between 1980 and 1985 the number of children in families affected by unemployment increased by 80 per cent. Too many children are suffering under Labor. The Government's wages and tax policy has also contributed to the increase in poverty. While wages may have kept pace with inflation in the past six years, the amount of personal income tax paid by workers has doubled. Low-income earners in particular are being taxed into poverty.

By the time Mr Keating's long promised tax cuts arrive, that is, if they arrive, in July next year, the worker on average weekly earnings will need a tax cut of $56 per week just to restore his real income to the level it was when Labor came to power in March 1983. The Government itself has identified some of the problems it has created. In this year's Budget it stated:

Studies show that low income families who rent housing in the private market are the least well off of all groups and that high housing costs are a major cause of poverty, particularly poverty among children.

So said the Government in the Budget. Of course, it is the Treasurer's policies which have pushed up the housing costs of which he is now complaining. Nevertheless, the Government stated the obvious. In response, it has said that it will increase rent assistance paid to low income privately renting families.

`Commendable', I hear honourable members say. But in an act of the worst political cynicism, the Government has delayed these increases until June 1989. Why June 1989? The Government has delayed the increases not because that is when the assistance is needed but rather to suit its political agenda. In other words, the increases are timed purely to curry favour with the voters in the lead-up to the next election. Everything is going to happen in June 1989. The Government has doubled our taxes. We are going to get a tax break-not now, but in June 1989. The Government has increased housing costs and put more people into poverty. People cannot afford to pay their rent. The Government says, `Oh, we will increase your rent assistance'. When asked when, the Government says, `Oh, not now-June 1989'. It is odds-on that there will be an election in August or September 1989.

The truth of the matter is that the Government's social policies have failed the nation. The facts speak for themselves. After five years of hard Labor we have more people in poverty, more children in poverty, record queues for housing and record queues for hospital beds. Much of the blame for the growth in poverty lies with the Treasurer, because, despite all the hype he carries on with, it is clear that the economy is not doing well and standards of living are falling while taxes are growing. International indicators show that we as a nation are way behind the eight ball. Our inflation rate is almost treble that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average-that is something to crow about! Our interest rates are the third highest of all OECD countries. To make matters worse, the Government has failed to confront the problem of Australia's productivity, which has long been a matter of concern but which now seems to be deteriorating further, both absolutely and relatively to overseas.

The OECD forecasts a further decline in our total factor and labour measures of productivity. Measures to boost investment and more efficient resource allocation such as lower taxes, reform of the labour market and more competition in transport and communications are necessary to raise productivity. But they are changes which this Government will not introduce because it is in the pockets of the unions, and the unions will resist the changes. As a nation we pay dearly for the fact that this Government is hostage to the unions. The unions get away with murder. Labor's special relationship with the unions has resulted in a 32 per cent increase in working days lost in the last four years. Economic recovery, a higher standard of living and less poverty will only come through significant industrial restructuring involving reorganisation, plant upgrading and substantial changes in the labour market, including the total removal of restrictive work practices. What is the Government doing about that? Nothing! What is the consequence? An article in today's Australian states:
Australian investment abroad has grown dramatically over the past five years, at the same time as the Federal Government has encouraged increased foreign investment here.

Figures produced by the Australian Trade Commission (Austrade) show that investment in the United States quadrupled in the five-year period while investment in the United Kingdom grew by 740 per cent.

Why are our companies going overseas to invest? Why are they not investing here? Let me point to one obvious reason. The United Kingdom and the United States of America are two countries which, unlike our nation, are not union controlled. They are investing where they can see some benefit for their investment, together with an increasing productivity and a good return, which they cannot see in this country under this Government.

It is not just the Soviet Union that needs perestroika. Australia does too. Labor's socialist policy has failed the nation. Middle and lower income earners of this nation are worse off now than they were five years ago when Labor came to power, and there has been a depressing increase in the number of adults and children in poverty. Labor's social and economic policies have not only failed but also increased the level of poverty and held back our economic growth. It is high time the Government faced up to the reality that a change in direction is urgently required. If it does not do it, the electors at the next election will take the necessary action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I am not sure why the Opposition moves these motions unless it is just to try to show a sympathetic face to the electorate that it certainly does not show when it is in government. It just seems to me an incredible waste of time to hear the destructive sorts of comments that have been made on the other side about a government which is so earnestly and successfully trying to help those who are in poverty in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We are in touch with the electorate. One of the most important things that have been done in the last few years is the setting up of the social security review which has allowed Bettina Cass to assess accurately what the problems are, especially amongst the poor in Australia, to evaluate what best can be done and to set priorities in that area for this Government. This Government has effectively, stage by stage, been trying to address those problems where they occur.

It seems to me that, whenever the Opposition advances a case like this, it is, as I said, just to show that rather false sympathetic face or to indulge in its usual scare tactics campaign. I made a list earlier of all the scare tactics that the Opposition has indulged in over the last few years and I have decided now not to repeat them. I think the electorate is well aware of the sorts of crazy stories that have been put about by the Opposition. I will mention the most recent one. As a result of our attempts to equalise investment income consequences for pensioners, we were told from the other side-and it was spread across the newspapers-that hundreds of thousands of pensioners were going to lose their pensions. This was a total misrepresentation which bore absolutely no relationship to the truth but which had age pensioners ringing our electorate offices in tears and, of course, scared stiff. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) has now started the union scare tactic again this morning.

In any event, of course, there is poverty in Australia. Poverty in Australia has been rising since the 1970s. When we came to government it was at its worst and there were more inequities in the Australian society then than at any other time. It was the worst period for the poor in Australia. What had those in government then done about it? Absolutely nothing. What programs did they have for the social wage for those in need? Absolutely nothing. What programs did they have for those in work on low incomes? Again, absolutely nothing.

Let me inform honourable members exactly what the poverty line was when we came to government. A single beneficiary with one child in March 1983 was $23.60 a week below the Henderson poverty line. In June 1988, poverty was not eradicated in Australia but that same single beneficiary with one child was $11.20 a week above the poverty line. In March 1983, when we came to government, a beneficiary couple with two children was $26.30 per week below the poverty line. That is how the Opposition left them. In June 1988 that same beneficiary couple with two children was $20.15 per week above the poverty line.

The most important thing we have done in government has been to assess the problems, estimate what can best be done to overcome them, and then set priorities. As the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) pointed out yesterday in answer to a question, those priorities have meant that, firstly, we have directed our attention to getting people back to work. No-one on a very low income or those in poverty benefit in a society where people are not at work. We have done a great deal to get people back to work; 1,060,000 jobs have been created. How much better off are those people now than when the Opposition was in government and they did not have a job? They now have the security of a job. They are paying taxes. They are off the social security lists. That is the greatest step in overcoming poverty in Australia that any government can achieve. The most effective and successful method for overcoming poverty is to get family breadwinners back to work.

Our second priority is to repair the safety net, to look at those people that the Bettina Cass review has covered, including the unemployed, children in low income families, the young, the aged, sole parents, find out what their needs are and address them. The greatest need that has been discovered relates to children in low income families. Our programs to eliminate child poverty are well on target. Our third priority is to address living standards. That is what we are about. I cannot understand the sorts of things that have been said by honourable members opposite. When the Opposition talks about the living standards of an average family it always has one sort of family in mind. It always assumes that that family is, as Ross Gittins pointed our in his article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday, 15 October, paying `private hospital insurance costing at least $10.70 a week'.

One of the things this Government has done to eliminate poverty is to bring in Medicare, which the Opposition is absolutely dedicated to destroying. The New South Wales Government is helping it to do that. The New South Wales Government has just admitted that the doctors going on strike in hospitals were responsible for the long waiting lists. It is going to spend $12m to get them back to work. A survey carried out recently by Ian McCauley, an economist with the Consumers Health Forum of Australia, and reported this week shows that private health insurance is an administratively wasteful luxury. The report says that more than one-quarter of contributors are not even sure why they have taken out private cover or why they have continued it since the introduction of Medicare. I will tell honourable members why they are doing it: the Opposition has scared them stiff. That is where some of their money is going. It is totally wasted money. The article says that, in terms of equity and economic efficiency, private insurance runs a poor third place to public insurance and direct market transactions; that is just paying the doctors.

Let me briefly address the situation concerning housing, which is referred to in the motion of the honourable member for Barker. Nothing is dearer to my heart than addressing in some way the problems of those who cannot afford accommodation, particularly in the major cities and in my city of Sydney. We are getting people back to work. The great majority of the jobs is in the cities. That is where the people want to live. There simply is not enough land available. That is one of the major reasons for the accommodation problems in Australia. The Housing Industry Association has just appealed to State governments to release more land. I wish the State governments would do something about rents. The only people to win in the high rental crisis are the real estate agents, the speculators and the speculative investors. There is a lot to be done in the housing area. None of the Opposition's program has ever tried to address the problem.
I will conclude by quoting Ross Gittins's article on living standards. He said:
. . . one million people who didn't have a job then-
that is, when we came to government-
but have one now, would have enjoyed a big increase in living standards.
He went on to say that many of those one million people were married women, which suggests that many families are getting over the gap in their living standards by having two incomes. He said:
The point is that what we've seen is the Government's principle of ``restraint with equity'' at work.

That is, workers have exercised wage restraint, with our encouragement. The other side of that means more people back in the work force and, therefore, the burden of restraint will be shared more fairly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great sadness that I rise to talk about the family assistance package and the state of poverty among the young in our country at present. I was amazed to hear the honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) claim that the Australian Labor Party is in touch with the electorate. Just ask the people of Oxley, the people who voted in the referendum or in the Port Adelaide and Adelaide by-elections whether they think that the Labor Party is in touch with any part of the electorate, let alone the poor in our society. The honourable member claimed that the Labor Government's main achievement was the Bettina Cass review. I accept that. Certainly, the review has been worthwhile and valuable. However, the Government has done nothing effective to counteract poverty, particularly child poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member accused us of engaging in scare tactics. In doing so she was clearly supporting the attacks by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on pensioners' incomes. Of course pensioners were distressed. Would honourable members not be distressed in such a situation? There is an old saying about lies, damn lies and statistics. The honourable member for Phillip has used statistics selectively. I will look at some of the real facts in a moment. She claims to support Medicare. Medicare is another tax on the people of Australia, forcing them to pay twice over for their health care rather than just once. She quoted from a Socialist Left report which, to be kind, did not indulge in any consultation procedures with both sides of the fence; it looked at only one side of the spectrum.

The Government's family assistance package fails to address the problems of poverty among Australian families. It came into effect in December last year and was aimed at providing income support to families on pensions and social security benefits and working families with low incomes. It was aimed particularly at assisting low income families in private rental housing. While its aims may be admirable, the reality is that its effectiveness has been persistently thwarted by the counterproductive-to put it politely-economic and social policies of the Keating-Hawke Government. As an income support package it has neither addressed the fundamental causes of poverty nor attempted to address the problems that many poverty stricken families that we see from day to day have in terms of access to other resources.

Let us look for a moment at the statistics which the honourable member for Phillip seems to have quoted selectively. Since the Hawke Government came to power there has been a 25 per cent increase in the number of children living in poverty. At present 20 per cent of Australian children live below the poverty line. By way of comparison, in Canada the figure is 9.6 per cent and in Germany it is 8.2 per cent. Even taking into account the expected family package changes coming into effect in December, researchers Helen Brownlee and Anthony King estimated that 372,500 children would be living in poverty after housing costs had been taken into account.

The cost of housing is one of the major causes of Australians living below the poverty line. From June 1983-the year in which Labor came to power-to the June quarter this year there was a 58.9 per cent increase in rental charges for private housing. One might say that that is due to private entrepreneurs. In fact, the honourable member for Phillip did say that. Therefore, let us look at government-owned dwellings. For government-owned dwellings the position is even worse. In the same period there was an increase of 63.9 per cent. In that period the consumer price index rose by 43.5 per cent. I point out that that is three times the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average. What about applications for public housing? Since June 1983 there has been a rise from 123,700 applications for housing to 195,370 applications as at June this year.

We know what has happened to mortgage rates under the Hawke Government. Based on Sydney housing prices-they are more expensive but they are still representative in terms of the increase-in 1983 the median price was $80,000 and, on average, 52 per cent of average weekly earnings went towards paying the mortgage. Now we find that the median price has gone from $80,000 to $142,000 and, more importantly, the average mortgage payment has gone to 74.8 per cent of average weekly earnings. Long term unemployment was mentioned earlier. When the Government came to power the average duration was about 30 weeks. Now it is closer to 60 weeks.

One of the real eye openers illustrating the failure to combat poverty is the average wage and the real disposable income changes based, for example, on a single income family with a dependent spouse and a couple of kids. In 1983 the average wage was $17,000, while for 1987-88 it was $24,000. Despite this apparent increase, real disposable income, after taking into account inflation and those terrible tax rates, dropped from $21,000 in 1982-83 to $20,000 in 1987-actually dropped. All this damage which was done to the living standards of ordinary Australian workers could not possibly be balanced by the measly increase in the family allowance supplement of $2 a week announced in the Budget. The family allowance supplement is going up to $24 a week. It is increasing by $3 a week for children aged 13 to 15 years. A great increase, $3 a week! It is pitiful when looked at in terms of the reality of market prices at present.

Peter Saunders and Peter Whitford in their report entitled Ending Child Poverty: an assessment of the Government's family package stated that the only way that even indexation of payments to equal 15 per cent of the married rate for up to 13-year-olds would reduce poverty would be if the poverty line itself should fall due to declines in real per capita disposable income. We know how likely that is to happen. All the welfare agencies are unanimous in this regard. The 1985 Commission of Inquiry into Poverty noted:
Inequalities of income and wealth reinforce and are reinforced by inequalities of education, health services, housing, employment and access to legal processes.

It is this Government which is attacking the worst off in our society-the very people it is supposed to be championing. According to the Australian Council of Social Service, by the end of this year the effective 7 per cent inflation rate-which is what it will be-will mean that the supplement would have to increase by $1.55 to keep it at the real level. Therefore, the maximum real increase in payments to children under 13 years was the grand sum of about 45c per week. By the end of this financial year, family allowances will have fallen to two-thirds of their value at the time of the last increase, in November 1987. A family currently receiving $22 for one child should be receiving $33 now to have retained its real value. Of course, the loss of $10 escalates with each additional child. According to the Youth Affairs Council of Australia, the Government's August Budget has made it clear that young people are not a part of the social justice strategy and the employment training and housing assistance announced in the Budget did not help them. There were no increased opportunities for Australia's 100,000 unemployed. Programs for the long term unemployed-one of our main problems at present-basically ignore people under the age of 21 years.

It is ludicrous to think that the family assistance package could in any way lessen the impact of the tax increase. It has been clearly pointed out that we would need an increase of $56 a week by 1 July next year just to restore incomes to what they were when this Government came to power. The Government will grab an additional 13.6 per cent in tax this year-in real terms-that is $5.7 billion. This is over and above the tax increase of 10 per cent last year. Individual taxpayers contribute 54 per cent of the revenue base compared to 52 per cent previously. In the space of three years the Government tax take from individuals has risen by more than 25 per cent in nominal terms.

The Government is going to increase sales tax collections by 14.4 per cent this year-almost three times the forecast inflation rate. The sales tax rise of $1 billion this year will lift the Hawke Government's consumption tax-that is what it is-to $8.6 billion, which is 2 1/2 times higher than it was under the Fraser Government. But we must remember that this Government promised not to introduce a consumption tax. Further, I note that the sales tax take actually makes up 10 per cent of total government revenue, compared with 6 per cent under the Fraser Government. It is really affecting the kids, who are the ones who pay in this regard. I refer to those products which most kids like, such as orange juice, ice cream, flavoured milk and snack foods, which have been taxed for the first time by this Government.

The Prime Minister's election campaign promise that by 1990 no Australian child would live in poverty has already been exposed for the farcical rhetoric it obviously was. He was forced to retract the statement less than a year later when he said, `How can I say that no child will live in poverty?' Even though the family assistance supplement has now been indexed, the Social Welfare Research Centre still believes that this will not be enough to remove all children from poverty by 1990. That is clearly the honest answer to the situation. The only people who benefit under this Government are, firstly, the rich mates who get the verbal wink and nod and are looked after, who have made themselves even richer at the expense of the poor in our society and, secondly, the unions, which are lining their own pockets with their restrictive practices and which are the main reason why productivity in this country is not able to be increased. There are a number of good, responsible unions that contribute to society in general and their members in particular, but they are very much a minority. If we do not fix up the problems which we are facing now, this country will keep on going down hill. The people who are suffering most under this Government are the ones who can least afford it-the worst off in our society, the poor and the underprivileged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously the Government totally disagrees with this motion and will not accept it. Before I defend our position, I would like to pick up a couple of points made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods). In his closing remarks he talked about the tax regime, but he did not mention the fringe benefits tax or the capital gains tax, a few of the taxes we have brought in to make the tax system in this country decent and which those on his side of the House opposed all the way down the line. Of course, he did not mention what the Opposition was going to do with the upgraded tax file number, another innovation that this Government is bringing in to make sure that those people who do not pay tax, the so-called rich mates that we have got, will pay more tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition fought the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the end of entertainment allowances all the way. Whom did those taxes hit? They did not hit the pensioners, sport; they hit the people with the rich mates. The honourable member talked about unions. Who was it who put up with the Builders Labourers Federation for seven years and did not do anything about it despite all the thuggery which went on? It was the Liberal Party. It was left to this Government to get rid of it. When the Opposition wants to talk about unions, it should look at its own record. The fact is that when it came to the crunch, it did nothing; it sat on its hands.

Let me go to the motion before us. It is absolutely preposterous. The previous speaker spoke about the changes in the Government's policy and the effect they had on lifting people above the Henderson poverty line. But let us look at the family allowance supplement. The family allowance supplement for a family on average weekly earnings, with two adults and four children, two between the ages of 13 and 15, and renting privately, equals $41.50 a week. That is what this Government is giving a low income family that does not have its own home, and it is equivalent to a pay rise of $70.60. Let me give another example. The family allowance supplement for a family with three children, between the ages of nought and 12 and once again renting privately, some of the poorest people in our community, on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings, would be $67.60 a week, which is equivalent to a pay rise of $96.90. No wonder Bill Kelty was moved to say that the progress made under this Government would have taken at least 50 years for the trade unions to achieve. Yet the Opposition stands up in here today and talks about low family living standards. When we look at our record the simple fact is that we have looked after our traditional base and those people on low incomes. What would be the effect of the Opposition's policies? We will never find an Opposition spokesman, back bencher or party hack getting up in here and telling us what the Opposition is going to do. The reason the Opposition will not tell us is that, if the truth ever hit the light of day, it would lose even more seats in the next election.

I want to quote from a paper prepared by the Legislative Research Service of the Parliament. These are not Australian Labor Party figures or the shonky $56 that the Opposition talks about; they were not arrived at through the same sort of arithmetic that the Opposition used to put its tax policy together last year. As I said, I am relying here on the Legislative Research Service of the Parliament. It has taken into account a number of assumptions in looking at the living standards and at the Opposition's wages policy. I will not read out all of those assumptions, but they are in line with the objective of the research. The results state:

The above calculations, which build on material prepared by the Office of the Leader of the Opposition, show that the implementation of the Opposition's stated attitudes policies to the national wages cases between March 1983 and June 1988 would have led to a fall in living standards--
A fall in living standards, and these are the people who moved this motion today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ah!

—That is right, the Opposition moved this motion today. Let us see how good the Opposition would have been by looking at its stated policies and press releases. If the Opposition was in government this is what would have happened to living standards: the paper mentions a fall of $132 a week for a single income family with a dependent spouse and two dependent children, where the income earner was a male full time employee on average weekly earnings. That is what the Opposition would have done. It would have ripped $132 a week out of that family's pockets.
—Tell us the productivity assumption.
—They are not my figures. No wonder the Opposition is whingeing. It does not like the truth.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker has already spoken in the debate.
—Be couth. Let me have a go. I am telling honourable members what the Opposition would do. I know it embarrasses him but he has to listen to it.
—No wonder your price watch thing has gone mad.

—I will talk about price watch with the honourable member later. The Legislative Research Service goes on to say that a bloke with two kids would lose $132 under the Opposition. If we look at a two income household-mum and dad working with two dependent children-we see that under the Liberal Government they would lose $212. Yet honourable members opposite stand up here and try to tell us that living standards have gone down under this Government. The simple fact is that they have not. For people on low incomes they have actually gone up under this Government. I pity them if the Liberals ever get into government because the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has told reporters that he will slash taxes. He will do this by cutting $15,000m of government revenue. If I were part of a family on low income getting the family assistance supplement, I would start to wonder where that money was coming from. We know where it will not come from because the Opposition looks after its mates in the Melbourne Club-all those people who have stuck by it all these years, God knows why. But certainly, if the Opposition is to take $15,000m out of spending, it will hit the people on very low incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at a few other things that the Government has done not only to lift living standards now but also to guarantee that in the future they will continue to rise. When looking at education one sees that under the Liberal Party the retention rate in our secondary schools was 36 per cent-as my colleague pointed out, one of the lowest in the world. Shame! Honourable members opposite should be ashamed. We now have over 50 per cent of young people finishing school. In the early 1990s we will have 65 per cent finishing school. I know that the honourable member for Barker finished secondary school. It was a private school and it was all paid for. But the simple fact is that people on low incomes, who were not getting through schools and were not able to make use of the education system to advance themselves, are doing it now. We will lift that figure to 65 per cent. In actual fact, we will double the Opposition's pathetic record.

In the next three years we will put 40,000 new places in our universities. They can only come from one place. Only one group is presently under-represented in our higher education institutions and that is the people from working class families. The Toorak, North Shore and Peppermint Grove families of this world always get their kids into university.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you have put fees on, is it?

—The honourable member opposite talks about fees. What is his position on fees? Once again we would not know. The fact is that the contribution that will be made by students will allow 40,000 more of them in. We think that is equitable.
—No, it is not.
—Order! The honourable member for Barker will not interject.

—That is okay, Mr Deputy Speaker. He is more to be pitied than scorned. Let us look at health. Medicare saves the average family $21 a week and the Opposition would help the doctors' union destroy it. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Lowe, had the gall to talk about taxation. For seven years the top tax rate stood at 60c in the dollar. The whole time that the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer the top tax rate was 60c in the dollar; it is now 49c in the dollar. The Leader of the Opposition was happy to have 48c in the dollar. That was not good enough for us; we took it down to 40c in the dollar. More importantly-for people on low incomes-the lowest tax rate under the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer was 30c in the dollar; it is currently sitting at 24c. When one looks at the record on taxation, as on many other issues, one sees that this Government has delivered. It does not talk about cutting taxes; it actually does it. The `gunnas' over there-`we're gunna do this, we're gunna do that'-never get around to it. They are world beaters in Opposition, but put them on this side of the House and all of a sudden they drop the footy. They cannot go on with it.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that under this Government the living standards of the poorest of Australians have been lifted substantially. The future living standards for Australians have been enhanced by the policies we have introduced, such as the massive restructuring that is currently taking place in industry, in the awards, in unions, and across the education spectrum. Over time, the living standards of Australians will be very much better as a result of their good choice in electing this Government three times.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been very interesting indeed to listen to earlier speakers from the Government side in this debate. I am rather dismayed by their attitudes and the line they have taken. As one of the previous Opposition speakers said, `There are lies, damned lies and statistics'. Of course, this was first said by Benjamin Disraeli. What we have seen coming from the Government benches is just one example after another of the truth of that statement. The honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) spoke about the tax file number and implied that we were in the wrong for being somewhat hesitant. All I can say on that is that the people of Australia do not want an identity card; they do not want a back door Bill of Rights; they do not want a back door identity card introduced by a tax file number. We, on this side of the House, are totally dedicated to the proposition that tax fraud and tax cheating must be eliminated but we are not prepared to do that at the cost of personal liberty.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Canning also spoke about the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax. He said that these had no adverse impact on pensioners or the poor. How wrong he is. It is just another illustration of how out of touch the members and Ministers of this Government are with the ordinary Australians. The fringe benefits tax affects the price of every product sold in this country, and the price paid by every pensioner and every person in this country. The honourable member for Canning said that this Government was looking after its traditional base. The evidence from right around Australia speaks for itself. The traditional base of the Labor Party has had enough. That was demonstrated in the by-elections in Oxley, Groom, Adelaide and Port Adelaide; the New South Wales election; and on 3 September when the four referenda questions were totally thrown out not by Liberal Party or National Party voters but by Labor Party voters who had had enough and were fed up. They know that the silvertail Government of Old Silver is out of touch with the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Cowper will address members by their proper titles. That applies to all honourable members in the chamber.

—I will certainly continue to do so. The honourable member for Canning also spoke about taxation. He tried to indulge in an exhibition of pride in what his Government has done with taxation but the whole of Australia-in fact, the whole world-knows that this is the highest taxing government this country has ever had. We all know that. We are talking about the family package and child poverty. We all know that famous statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that no Australian child will be living in poverty by 1990. I will let the Government know, because it has obviously forgotten it, that 1990 is only 14 months away. The people of Australia know that but I do not think the Government knows it. It still has approximately 400,000 children living in poverty. But the Prime Minister says that, by 1990-14 months to go-it will have been eliminated. An article in the ASW Impact of May 1988 states:

SPEECH.PARA: But what is clear so far is that the package-
that is, the family package-
has gone a little less than half way to meet the Prime Minister's goal of eliminating the need for children to live in poverty.

Unfortunately and regrettably there is no way that that goal will be achieved in that time by this Government. I do not believe it really cares. The honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) spoke with the usual pride of the Government about the number of jobs it created. I can accept that it will take that sort of action but the reality is that jobs are self-generating and that the economic policies are important for getting jobs in place. So the Government can take that pride. It has forgotten, because it is out of touch, that unemployment is still stuck at between 7 1/2 per cent and 7.8 per cent and that there are still 10 unemployed people for every job vacancy in this country. Worse still, when we consider the situation of the men and women in this country who are long term unemployed, we see that the mean duration for that unemployed period was 33 weeks in 1982 before Labor came to office and is now 66 weeks. So for a long term unemployed person the average is 66 weeks. That is very unfortunate indeed.

I find it interesting that Government members come into this chamber and talk about taxation rates. How is it that the workers' friend Government has reduced company tax for its big mates-not its little mates-to 39 per cent and the top rate for individual personal tax is still 49 per cent? It does not ring true. There has been a lot of talk about tax cuts, but when are they coming? For a whole year tax cuts have been floated like balloons; they have gone up and down like kites. Yet, in reality, the people of Australia are being hit harder by insidious back door taxation the whole time.

Stamps and telephone charges are just two of the things that affect ordinary people, people living in poverty and pensioners. Even though Telecom Australia announced on 12 October an operating profit for 1987-88 of $777m, which was almost double the result for 1986-87, local telephone calls will go up another cent to 21c from 1 November. That followed a 2c local call charge increase last year. Directory assistance fees will be increased from 21c to 63c; and so it goes on. Australia Post has just whacked up the cost of local postage stamps by 2c-from 37c to 39c. These are little things that affect every Australian, especially every pensioner; yet the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that more competitive pressure will be applied to the operations of the Australian Telecommunications Commission to `provide better and cheaper services to business and consumers'. That was only in the May 1988 mini-Budget speech. I will quote him again-`provide better and cheaper services to business and consumers'. But the consumers are not getting any better service and they are not getting any cheaper service either.

I think it is significant that total sales tax revenue in 1988-89 will increase by 14.4 per cent to $1,083m. A sales tax is imposed on the goods that people buy and the inflation rate, which is sending up the prices of ordinary, everyday products all the time, is having an impact on the pensioners and poor people of Australia. This Government-the Government of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating -is out of touch with what is happening to ordinary people in Australia. Road funding has been slashed. Everybody in local government knows that the funding for local government has been slashed as well.

The honourable member for Phillip made some references to the Opposition indulging in scare tactics. We do not have to scare anybody. The people of Australia who see what is being done to them by the Hawke-Keating Government are scared in their own right. They do not need us to scare them. The honourable member for Phillip mentioned scare tactics on pensioners. Honourable members should consider for one second what happened before the Victorian election. We had the imposition of retrospectivity in terms of investments by pensioners, and they were right to be scared about that. In a blatant, cynical political exercise just before the Victorian election, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Government backed away from it. If the Victorian election had not been held, they would not have done so. But it was a cynical and blatant exercise in political pork-barrelling just to try to win votes. We on this side of the House do not have to scare people. The people of Australia know what is happening and, as will be found out at the next Federal election, the people of Australia will speak up, saying, `Goodbye, Mr Hawke'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the motion and suggest that much of what we have heard here today is simply a continuation of scaremongering. The Opposition has failed to provide any strategy or overall policy as an alternative to what is currently being done by the Government. As honourable members will be well aware, the Government has in place a social justice strategy which underpins all these programs. Member of the Opposition have just failed to look at that strategy in any way and see it as a total policy program. Hence, when they start singling out a piece of a program here and there, they make some very invalid assumptions. The honourable member for Phillip (Ms McHugh) has already referred to the Bettina Cass reviews. In those reviews Bettina Cass has targeted those groups in our community which, we acknowledge, sadly have been the poorest but which have been best met through the programs which we, as a Government, have developed specifically to target their needs.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those programs is the family assistance package. That is very definitely part of a social justice strategy in which we have seen the fringe benefits tax redistributed to the needy families in our community. Who shouted loudly about fringe benefits tax? Who screamed when their money was to be taken away and given to families? Of course it was members of the Opposition. They know that money for families and money for the poor must come from somewhere. They say that it should not come out of their pockets. We, as a Government, are committed to that. We see family needs first and so we pursued the family assistance package. Honourable members should ask those who receive $40 or $50 a week for their families about what difference it has made to their lives and the lives of their children. I can cite numbers of cases from my own electorate office. I meet people every day who tell me about the kind of difference and the relief which the provision of that amount of money has made.

We are also attempting to tackle children and families in poverty through the Child Support Bill. One of the most shameful social problems in this country has been the putting of children into poverty through family separation. We know that the majority of the supporting parent families are led by women. Women and children are being placed into poverty not only through marital breakup but also through the failure of their spouses to contribute to the support of their children. For too long 75 per cent of those people who have had maintenance orders brought down against them in the Family Court have failed to pay. They have simply walked away from their obligations.
