That is why many of our children and families are in poverty. What has this Government done? It has taken a very large step to ensure that the people who have children are made responsible for their maintenance. Hence, we have seen the introduction of the Child Support Bill and the Child Support Agency this year, in June, and its expansion into stage 2. It is obvious that many of our children and many of our families will benefit from that. We are hopeful that, through adequate maintenance repayments, the very vicious cycle of poverty will be avoided.

Another reality in Australia in 1988 for those who are poor is the need for employment. We know that many of our poorest people are those who are unemployed. This Government has been responsible for the creation of over a million jobs. It has also been responsible, in conjunction with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, for planning a long term strategy for the development of the manufacturing industry in Australia through the Australia Reconstructed program. The Opposition does not like the fact that this Government can work with unions, can get something done and be constructive, and that together we can go ahead and develop industry in this country. That is what brings about changes for families. That is what brings about the creation of a million jobs, not the kinds of destructive confrontationist programs which the Opposition implemented in government.

Other major labour market programs currently within the community through the traineeship programs and other training programs are also cooperative. Industry training councils; the Government, through its Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Commonwealth Employment Service offices; and private enterprise combine to offer realistic skills training for the unemployed, and then offer them employment in markets and areas where there are skill shortages. All of those families and individuals are helped by those labour market programs. The cooperation of industry and government yet again brings this about and acknowledges that we need to work together to overcome the problems of poverty and the lack of skills training in the community. Not once have we heard the Opposition address such a problem. Members of the Opposition are not interested in working with unions or in working with the Business Council of Australia. The Business Council has already made a commitment to attempt to restructure industry and to talk about retraining. The Opposition is not interested in that. The Government cooperates and works together to ensure that the goals we have to remove children from poverty by 1990 can be realistically attained.

Another way in which this is happening is through the education system. The House has heard the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) talk about school retention rates. How else will we have a skilled and trained work force if our school children do not stay on at school? They are the very children who are doomed to poverty and to unemployment if they are not trained properly. One way of keeping them at school is our Austudy payment of $50 a week. Are members of the Opposition going to tell me that any family in this country will turn down $50 a week for its children to stay on at school years 11 and 12? Nonsense! That is what reducing poverty in this country and in families is about-ensuring that everybody, not just the rich and not just those children whose parents can pay, can stay on at school, have the benefits of education and not be doomed to unemployment.

As honourable members may realise, the Austudy amount will rise to $80 a week from 1 January. Any family would welcome such moneys to enable it to ensure that its children have an opportunity to participate in the wealth and resources of this country. The program for 1989 will ensure that a further 48,000 students will receive Austudy payments. That is real money, cash in hand, to enable families to ensure that their children can participate in school programs. It is nonsense to suggest that this Government is not concerned with families and with youth.

One of the other ways in which we have seen an expansion of programs and opportunities is the expansion of higher education. The honourable member for Canning has already talked about an expansion of 40,000 places in tertiary education. Who in the past did not have an opportunity to participate in those places? It was the children from working class families because their parents could not afford it and the available places were always automatically taken by those who could afford it. We will have not only an expansion of places but also an expansion of income which will enable people to participate in the education programs and to move into a much expanded work force-those million jobs we have talked about. They will be assisted by the kinds of payments that are made to families, the family assistance supplement and the child support. People have talked about the need for housing. In my own electorate the housing situation is desperate. However, I remind the House that public housing in this country is the prerogative of State governments and one needs to look at the work they have been doing. In my own area the State Government has failed miserably to provide a public housing sector which adequately meets our needs.

Let us be very sure about where the responsibility for government lies and where the responsibility for care of families and families in poverty is. Let us remember that this Government has a commitment, through its social justice strategy, to ensure that the needs of all families and all children will be met, that redistribution of income will occur and that all will be able to participate in the resources and the values of this country. All families and children will be raised out of poverty and opportunity will not be the prerogative of the rich.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating this morning a motion by my colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) which in part states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government's failed social and economic policies have caused widespread poverty among Australian families which will not be overcome by the Government's new family assistance package . . .

It is to that part of the motion that I want to focus my attention in the minutes available to me in this debate. Australian families face a hostile economic environment and a hostile tax and social security environment. Indeed, those who would have Australia's families face that environment and decide not to have families. The crisis confronting this country is sometimes described as being a consequence of the ageing of the population. That ageing is coming about today largely because of the hostile environment which confronts families or those who would have children if they believed they could give those children a fair start in life, if they believed they could economically afford to maintain them.

To illustrate the point, I draw attention to the fact that if the fertility rates or birth rates applicable in Australia in 1966 had continued until 1986, Australia's population today would be 18.5 million instead of 16 million. Our aged population would be 9 per cent of our population instead of 10.5 per cent. This change in our birth rate, this dramatic decline in the number of children being born, is a consequence of the inadequacies of the Government's tax and social security policies as they impact upon families.

I shall illustrate again the dramatic consequences which could face this country by drawing on an illustration I gave in a speech earlier this week. I took that illustration from West Germany. West Germany today is on a course that yields fewer than 1.3 children per woman in the course of her lifetime. Recent demographic projections show that if that rate continues, it will reduce the West German population from 60 million to 50 million by the year 2000 and down to 16 million by the end of the next century. That is a drop in population over 120 years from 60 million to 16 million. That is the implication facing this country and we must ask ourselves why it is that young Australian couples who would wish to have children are choosing not to do so. One of the significant reasons for that is the hostile economic environment created by this Government.

Since this Government came to office it has failed to index the family allowance; it has failed to index the spouse rebate; and Australian families have been confronted with very high interest rates. Government speakers have said that the Government introduced the family assistance supplement. That is true. That is helping those in need. However, it is resulting in the Government's becoming blind to the real needs of Australian families as a whole. Of course we must help families in need but if they are helped in a way which puts even greater pressure on families in general, more of the families in general will become families in need and more of the families will have fewer children than they would otherwise have had and we will face an ageing population and a social security crisis as a consequence of the added cost of providing for retirees.

I believe the Opposition parties are quite right in bringing to the attention of this House the crisis that is facing Australian families. It is a crisis that results from the fact that through the social security system and the tax system we make totally inadequate provision for children-for all children, not just the children who are in poor families.

We claim that we have a taxation system that has as one of its underlying principles the capacity to pay. What we have not done is properly define the concept of capacity to pay. It appears that the Labor Party believes that capacity to pay is a function of income, and only a function of income. It believes that if a person has a higher income, he should pay more tax-more cents in the dollar, and cents in respect of all those additional dollars. That is a progressive tax system. It has a lot of disadvantages. It takes away incentives as people move from one tax bracket to another; as Australian families on average weekly earnings have moved, because of the inadequacies of the present Government, from a 30c rate to a 40c rate. When the Labor Party came to office 5 1/2 years ago the average weekly earner was paying a marginal tax rate of 30c in the dollar because average weekly earnings were less than $19,500. That was the point at which the tax rate rose from 30c in the dollar to 40c. Has that threshold been altered? No. The Government has used bracket creep. As wages rose, the level at which the 40c rate was levied was maintained as it was in money terms. We find today that the great majority of the full time work force are now paying a marginal rate of tax of 40c in the dollar whereas when Labor came to office they were paying 30c in the dollar.

A large proportion of members in the full time work force are supporting families. A large proportion of those families are single-income families. As a consequence of the failure to index the tax-free threshold and to adjust the threshold at which a taxpayer moves from 30c in the dollar to 40c, single-income families on average weekly earnings are now paying substantially more than $10 a week more in tax than are two-income families with the same household income. Furthermore, I emphasise again that single-income families have received no adjustment in the family allowances to which they have been entitled. The same money amount is being paid as was being paid when Labor came to office. In these circumstances, how can Labor argue that it is concerned about Australian families, that it is concerned about the future of our overall population?

In fact, the Labor Party's approach to the average Australian family is to treat the children as though they were the indulgence of parents; to treat the children as playthings; to treat the children as consumption goods-to be paid for by the family that chooses to have them. I do not believe that any taxation policy that merely selects income as the criterion for determining capacity to pay is equitable or fair. It is my view that a taxation system properly reflects capacity to pay only when it takes into account not only the income of the household in which the taxpayer is living as well as that person's individual income, but also the cost of supporting those who are dependent upon that income-the dependent spouse or dependent children.

The tax system should make an allowance to taxpayers for the support of dependants no less than the allowance that the public sector would provide for those dependants if the taxpayer defaulted or, for some other reason, ceased to take responsibility for those children or for that dependent spouse. For to do otherwise is to have a tax and social security system that will inevitably influence social behaviour.

The Labor Party then comes along and says `Look, we have made some reforms in the maintenance collection area'. That is true, and to some extent the Labor Party should be commended for doing so. But it has made those reforms in such a way as to penalise the intact family while assisting the separated family. The formula that the Labor Government is going to apply means that the average Australian intact family, which is getting a modest, meagre or mean allowance for the support of children through the family allowance system, will go on paying higher taxes while the children of the principal income earner of the separated family, the non-custodial parent, with an income in excess of $34,000, will still receive additional benefits. His children will be getting additional benefits over and above the benefits that would be paid to an intact family supporting the same number of children.

So, I think that the whole taxation system needs to be reviewed. The concept of capacity to pay needs to be analysed. This Government has punished Australian families. It has pretended it is doing something by assisting those who have not been able to cope because of the punishment meted out by a hostile tax and social security system linked in with an economic environment which has caused the price of the family home, whether in the rental area or as a consequence of high interests rates, to rise.

I believe that the Liberal and National parties are absolutely justified in drawing the attention of this House to the desperate plight of Australian families. We are correct in urging that the Government take some action. I am sure that when the Liberal and National parties' policies in this area are fully developed, they will take account of the needs of Australian families. It is my hope that they will propose substantial and radical reform to acknowledge the fact that children are people, that children are the future of the nation. We do not want to be subject to the charge of ignoring the views that have been put to us. What kind of a spirit is there in a society that does not even have the gumption or interest to reproduce itself. I believe that Australians do have that gumption, interest and concern. Increasingly, that concern is being reflected by people recognising that the existing family allowance supplement scheme is totally inadequate, that the taxation system is totally unfair to Australian families and to taxpayers who are supporting dependants.

There needs to be a substantial increase in the spouse rebate and substantial increases in the family allowances for all families. Those who may be regarded as income rich families today can tomorrow easily be the income poor whom the system then has to assist. It would be much better if we, as a community, recognised that children are people, that children supported by private citizens, by Australian families, need as much support through tax relief and cash family allowances as they would receive if they were abandoned or, as a consequence of family breakdown, were looked after by a supporting parent with no other source of income who was dependent upon the public sector. The Australian Labor Party has failed Australian families and its policies make it quite clear that it does not have any vision for the needs of those families or of the needs of the future of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House recognises-

(1) that the question of human rights is a legitimate international concern, transcending national boundaries and rejects attempts to describe a concern for abuses of human rights as interference in the internal affairs of other states; and
(2) the contribution made by Amnesty International in defending human rights around the world.

Mr Deputy Speaker, my motion will be seconded in due course by the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). I might say, before I begin to comment on the substantive terms of the motion before the House, that this motion is being moved as private members' business. It is a credit to the Parliament that, since the adoption of revised Standing Orders, there is increased opportunity for back bench members to bring private business before the House. It is a very welcome development and one which we ought to develop further in the years ahead, because I believe-and I am confident that the other speakers participating in the debate on this motion share the view-that Parliament needs to roll back the power of the Executive and to make this forum and this place more vital and fundamental to the workings of parliamentary democracy.

Mr Deputy Speaker, having said that, I turn my attention to the motion before honourable members. What it first of all seeks to do is to restate what is, in my view and the view, I am sure, of my fellow speakers, a quite undeniable proposition. That is that no longer can any country claim that issues of human rights are not of international concern. The Australian Parliament has, of course, long taken an interest in human rights concerns. In the course of my informal remarks, I shall draw attention to some of the experiences of Australian members of Parliament in defending the cause of human rights. We have in this Parliament an institution which is by world standards regrettably unique. I refer to the Parliamentary group of Amnesty International. That group has among its members almost two-thirds of the members of the Australian Parliament. It operates without regard to ideology and includes among its members representatives of all the political parties represented in the Australian Parliament as well as the independents and has as its patrons the holders of the offices of Prime Minister, Leader of the Opposition, Leader of the National Party and Leader of the Australian Democrats.

Importantly, that organisation has sought by its work to influence the Executive Government of the country into changing its policies with respect to the defence of human rights. I am very proud to record that the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, his successor, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), have all agreed to give support to the work of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International in a very tangible way and in a way which falls squarely within the substance of the motion that I have moved today.

What the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International does is take up every single case of urgent action called on by Amnesty International in London. That means that, wherever Amnesty is concerned about an imminent execution, about the persecution, gaoling and potential torture of someone merely because of racial origin, his ethnic beliefs or his political beliefs, it sends out a message to the world calling on people who are supporters of Amnesty to apply pressure to those errant governments responsible for that inhumane treatment of our fellow human beings. What we are doing in Australia is sending that information to the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade under the hand of the Chairman and Secretary of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty. That Department then takes up every single case of urgent action that is put to it by the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty.

I ask honourable members to think of the implications for the world if that model of action were followed in other countries. What it means is that Australian diplomatic representatives are knocking on doors and are taking up in a very direct and hands-on way those violations of human rights as they appear around the world. That is unprecedented-unprecedented-in the history of the world. What I say is that it provides a model for action for other governments. At the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference, which was held in Canberra only a few weeks ago, a special session was devoted to the work of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International. I am pleased to report that there were very positive signs from a number of parliamentarians from a range of governments, but particularly New Zealand, which indicated some hope that New Zealand might be able to be moved towards adopting a similar approach. Now, if that happens and if we spread that model for action, what we will have is a coordinated and bipartisan approach from a whole range of countries around the world applying that diplomatic pressure on those errant governments and, I believe, effectively able to secure the release of prisoners of conscience.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as members of parliament, my colleagues and I are privileged people. We are privileged because we get the opportunity to travel, to represent our Parliament and sometimes our Government in foreign countries. We can see at first hand what political repression really means. Until one has seen what occurs in a number of countries, until one really starts to understand the misery, the repression and discrimination that people feel, one cannot really be an effective campaigner for human rights. Indeed, we from Australia perhaps can never understand the brutality of repression as do those who are the direct subject of repression.

Let me recount a couple of experiences that I have been able to observe and which have influenced my life. Firstly, as a representative of the Australian Parliament in a parliamentary delegation to the Soviet Union in 1986, together with representatives of the Opposition parties, led by Madam Speaker, I and others in that delegation had an opportunity to meet with the only people, so far as I am aware, in the Soviet Union who demonstrated in support of a moratorium on nuclear reactor construction following the tragic Chernobyl accident. Their only crime was to have a peaceful protest in opposition to further reactors until there was a broad inquiry. Some of them were gaoled because they simply took up that concern. I was able to see the incredible courage of those people who were prepared to put their necks on the line and suffered greatly as a result.

Recently I had an opportunity to visit Singapore and Malaysia, again on a parliamentary delegation. I attended the Parliament in Malaysia and was privileged to stand beside the seat of my friend Karpal Singh, who is currently in detention under the Malaysian Internal Security Act. That is an experience I will remember all my life. He is one of dozens of people, prisoners of conscience, who are imprisoned by the Malaysian Government. Their only crime, according to Amnesty International, was to dissent from the views of the government of the day. The case of Malaysia is being raised not to single out Malaysia, because it is one of over half the countries in the world that violate the principles of Amnesty International, but for two reasons: firstly, because it is one of our regional neighbours and for that reason we ought to take a special interest in it; and secondly, because Malaysia dares to say that principles and concerns about human rights are purely a matter of the domestic concern of the Malaysian Government. I say to Malaysia that that is an absolutely untenable proposition. People in Malaysia who are rotting in Malaysian gaols as prisoners of conscience are a global concern. I say to Malaysia that the pressure will not stop until such time as those prisoners of conscience are released.

I now turn my attention to the broader question of the role of Amnesty International. I would not want it to be thought that Amnesty International is about parliamentarians. It is not. Amnesty International is about mobilising people around the world to show active support for their fellow human beings. Amnesty is based on local groups which write letters expressing concern about the continued detention of prisoners of conscience. If two-thirds of the members of the Australian Parliament, ranging across the political spectrum, can give their support to that cause I say to the people of Australia, `We as a nation of citizens can do a lot more to mobilise and support the cause of human rights'.

Regrettably, Amnesty International in Australia is a relatively small organisation. It is growing, it has a great deal of support in some quarters, but it could increase its work and its effectiveness a hundredfold if all the people listening to this parliamentary broadcast who have a commitment to principles of justice joined Amnesty International and gave their support to the principles of that very great organisation. If people want to learn more about Amnesty International they should look at the most recent edition of Time magazine, dated 17 October, where there is a cover story about the work of Amnesty. It talks about the global tour of a number of the world's great pop and rock stars, who are travelling the world singing the praises of Amnesty International and trying to motivate people to give support to that organisation. I call on people in Australia to mobilise and give their support to the work of Amnesty.

There are two other things I wish to say in this debate. Firstly, although Amnesty does not concern itself with human rights in the country in which a group operates, I as a parliamentarian, speaking in my private capacity, am not so constrained. For that reason I wish to say that if Australia tells the rest of the world that issues of human rights are a global concern then we too must acknowledge that the human rights of Aboriginal Australians are equally of international concern. I believe it is to the credit of successive national governments of all political parties that they have been prepared to answer to the world for the human rights of Aboriginal and Islander Australians. I know that Aboriginal representatives, with the tacit support, or at worst acquiescence, of successive governments have taken the case of injustice to United Nations forums and no doubt will continue to do so. I say in relation to this matter, and I have said it before, that the world is watching us just as much as we are committed to raising concerns of human rights in other parts of the world.

Secondly, I want to raise in this debate about human rights something that is entirely unrehearsed and for which I am not at all prepared but which, in all the circumstances, I believe is a very appropriate matter to raise in the course of this debate. I will soon be followed by the honourable member for Dundas. In relation to human rights questions the issue of discrimination is of the essence. It is absolutely central to concerns about violations of human rights around the world. In this chamber the honourable member for Dundas displayed enormous personal and political courage in taking a stand in relation to matters of discrimination. He deserves the recognition and support not only of the Parliament but of his fellow Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, and it is with a great deal of pleasure on my part that I do so. I am somewhat embarrassed by the comments of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), who preceded me. Very often people comment outside the Parliament about how infrequently they hear debates in which there is general agreement on both sides of the Parliament and commendation of people on the other side from the side upon which the speaker sits. I thank the honourable member for Hughes for his personal comments relating to me. It perhaps inhibits me somewhat in terms of the comments that I was about to make about him. In a real sense people might think that we got together and had a unity ticket to work out what nice things we would say about each other. It is totally unrehearsed and the remarks he made were unexpected. It ought to be noted, in relation to the debate we are having about human rights and the comments that were made about the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International, that the honourable member for Hughes failed to mention that he is the Chairman of the Parliamentary of Amnesty International Group. He is one whose activities I greatly admire and respect. Again, I offer my personal commendation to him today in moving this motion and giving me the opportunity to second it. I hope in due course that the Parliament passes it.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion deals with two matters, the first being the question of human rights. It makes the point that it is a legitimate international concern which transcends national boundaries and that we as a parliament should reject attempts to describe the concern for abuses of human rights as an interference in the internal affairs of other states. Those of us who have an interest in human rights questions know that all too frequently it is assumed that countries can determine the way in which their populations will be dealt with without being judged by the international community. I do not think there is any basis upon which a country can determine of itself, without international sanction, a framework of law or a framework without law which denies to individuals within that country basic and fundamental human rights which have been described in international documents, particularly the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

I do not think there is any basis upon which governments can simply thumb their nose at the rest of the world and say, `You have no capacity to influence the circumstances, the course of events, in our country'. One of the organisations which have made a great impact and which the motion commends is Amnesty International. It is appropriate in this debate to put on record what the Amnesty statute says about human rights. It is appropriate to do so in this year which is the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I will read the objectives of Amnesty so that those who are listening to this debate and those who read about it will know what it is concerned about:
OBJECT

1. CONSIDERING that every person has the right freely to hold and to express his or her convictions and the obligation to extend a like freedom to others, the object of AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL shall be to secure throughout the world the observance of the provisions of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, by:

(a) irrespective of political considerations working towards the release of and providing assistance to persons who in violation of the aforesaid provisions are imprisoned, detained or otherwise physically restricted by reason of their political, religious or other conscientiously held beliefs or by reason of their ethnic origin, sex, colour or language, provided that they have not used or advocated violence-
those people are referred to as `prisoners of conscience'-

(b) opposing by all appropriate means the detention of any prisoners of conscience or any political prisoners without trial within a reasonable time or any trial procedures relating to such prisoners that do not conform to internationally recognized norms;

(c) opposing by all appropriate means the imposition and infliction of death penalties and torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of prisoners or other detained or restricted persons whether or not they have used or advocated violence.

In Australia we make assumptions about the freedoms that we enjoy but, at the time we are celebrating the fortieth anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, in an enormous number of countries people are imprisoned, people die by state imposed penalty and others have their lives taken illegally. Since the founding of Amnesty International there have been about 30,000 individual prisoners of conscience. Amnesty has been able to close some 27,352 of those files. Currently there are 3,126 cases open, including 711 added since 1 January this year.

Amnesty International is a small organisation. It has grown since 1961 when a gentleman by the name of Peter Benenson read about the sentencing of two Portuguese students whose crime had been to drink a toast to freedom in the darkest days of the Salazar regime. Realising that throughout the world there were thousands of people similarly imprisoned and tortured, he took up this matter. With some colleagues he published an advertisement in a London newspaper drawing attention to the fate of eight men imprisoned for their beliefs-the forgotten prisoners. Those eight included Agostino Neto, a poet who was to become the first President of independent Angola; Ashton James, an American minister and civil rights campaigner; Peter Duncan-perhaps the Minister for Employment and Education Services knew that I was about to say his name, but it was another Peter Duncan-a South African anti-apartheid activist; and Cardinal Mindszenty, the Catholic Primate of Hungary. That was the quality of the prisoners to whom Peter Benenson drew attention.

An organisation that started off in 1962 with a budget of $17,000 has ballooned now to an organisation with a budget of $43m. The most remarkable fact about that budget is that it is not contributed to by governments. In other words, even if the Australian Government determined that it would make a grant to that organisation, it would not receive it. Seventy per cent of its funds come from individual contributions-a $25 fee which half the members of this Parliament pay. The remainder comes from international foundations and institutions. The organisation won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1977. It now has an organisational membership of some 700,000 people in over 150 countries.

This most commendable organisation is one with which members of this Parliament are associated and, I think, keenly associated. I belong and contribute to it fully and actively because I believe in what it is about. I do so proudly as an Australian member of parliament in the knowledge that few issues are ever raised about human rights questions in Australia. If substantial issues were to arise about Australia I could not, in all honesty, be associated with the organisation. To those who are listening to this debate, to those who will read about it and therefore learn of this motion, I commend Amnesty International to them. In commending this motion to the Parliament I encourage the Australian community at large to associate with it and to work for its objectives. In doing so it is working for fundamental human rights, regardless of people's political views-whether their views are of the Right or the Left-and for the basic and fundamental freedoms which ordinary human beings ought to be able to enjoy, as we in this country enjoy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel privileged to follow the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in this debate. The words `freedom' and `democracy' flow easily from the tongue. We accept those principles readily in Australia, but they are much more difficult to achieve in practice. They are under great threat at all times, especially in totalitarian regimes. Immediately after the Second World War there was great enthusiasm for an end to barbarianism. As has been pointed out, this year we celebrate the fortieth anniversary of the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights. After the Second World War we wrote into international law a new principle. It was that the individual human being has the right to be protected by the international community. And so it was that the Universal Declaration of Human Rights-a 30-article document-was endorsed thoroughly, although not always observed, by all the 159 members of the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: We must recognise that there has been great progress in codifying standards of human rights in international instruments such as, as I have said, the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, 40 years ago; the United Nations Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples; the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination; the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the Optional Protocol of 1966; and the Convention against Torture, Other Cruel Inhumane or Degrading Treatment or Punishment. Reams and reams of paper mean nothing. It must be a matter of res non verba-deeds not words. Yet, as Amnesty International reported in its 1988 annual report, which was launched in Sydney two weeks ago by Justice Elizabeth Evatt, many governments continue to deny their citizens fundamental rights and treat demands for them as subversive. According to the report, 135 countries were guilty of human rights abuses last year-the highest number in 27 years of existence of Amnesty International. The report stated:

In at least half the countries of the world people are locked away for speaking their minds, often after trials that are no more than a sham. In at least a third of the world's nations, men, women and even children are tortured. In scores of countries, governments pursue their goals by kidnapping and murdering their own citizens.

This should not be taken lightly. We should keep in mind that even democracies where respect for the rule of law is taken for granted can run into trouble. It is not just the Romanias, Chiles, Cubas and South Africas of this world that need monitoring. We need to look at ourselves. No country should be able to avoid scrutiny.

The situation is dismal. There is still a long way to go. Some member states of the United Nations have not yet demonstrated their commitment to the international protection of human rights by acceding to the covenants that would bind them in law to protect the rights they claim to respect. Among these countries are two permanent members of the Security Council, the United States and the People's Republic of China. Only 39 states have ratified the optional protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which allows individuals to have complaints heard by the Human Rights Committee. Among those countries which have not ratified the protocol are states whose nationals are currently serving as members of the Human Rights Committee, including the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United Kingdom.

Here in Australia we have not carried through our legal responsibilities. When this Government attempted to codify the rights in a Bill of Rights, the Opposition organised against it and gunned it down. This is a bipartisan debate so I will not go any further, except to point out that it is a matter of bipartisanship abroad but not at home. It should be noted that recently the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia advised us that he had changed his mind and that there was a strong case for and value in enshrining these universal rights in law in Australia. Recently we had a referendum in this country. One of the questions put to the people was on religious freedom. That was defeated. We must ask ourselves and our community whether we are fair dinkum or whether the rules that we ascribe to and support internationally are for other countries only and not for home.

The greatest weapon that the international community has is to publicise instances of violations of human rights to expose the guilty governments to the glare of international publicity. Compared with 40 years ago, we now have world-wide coverage by television. This has given the public first hand pictures, unheard of when the United Nations Declaration first came about. Publicity and work by relief agencies in human rights have exposed violations.

What has been the response from governments around the world? Even the most repressive regimes are sensitive to criticism. Sometimes they modify their behaviour towards particular political prisoners. However, sadly, the most usual response by these governments is to become more secretive, to close the information channels and to attack those people who criticise them by accusing them of acting against the national interest. Amnesty International is hated by some governments for exposing violations. These governments accuse the organisation of being blatantly interfering.

As the honourable member for Dundas pointed out, the record of Amnesty International is extremely sound. It has stuck to a policy of impartiality. No action can be taken by an Amnesty International group in its own country. Amnesty International adopts prisoners from communist, non-communist and non-aligned countries. There are no partisan politics in Amnesty International because it is based on a belief in universal human rights. Jack Healey, the executive director of Amnesty International in the United States and the mastermind behind the organisation's Human Rights Now! tour, summed it up well when he said that the work of Amnesty International is one of building moral outrage. He speaks for the ordinary person when he says:

We want a world without torture, without killings . . . the Universal Declaration of Human Rights is our Magna Carta. It is not just a piece of paper; it's a fighting instrument. To governments we simply say, `behave, implement this document, restore a world of justice. If you don't we the non-violent are coming'.

That Amnesty International tour is about raising consciousness. It will be coming to Australia. As the honourable member for Dundas pointed out, Peter Benenson started Amnesty International in the early 1960s and 15 years later this growing organisation was able to boast that it had become so effective in its contribution towards political freedoms that it was awarded the Nobel Prize. A further 12 years later Amnesty International can claim a membership of 700,000 in more than 150 countries. As the honourable member for Hughes pointed out, we have a branch of Amnesty International in this Parliament. It is a unique branch-a parliamentary group. I am very proud to be a founder member and founding secretary of that branch. Still, we are the only parliamentary group. I hope that the efforts made by the honourable member for Hughes at the recent Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference come good.

I want to relate an incident when the honourable member for Dundas and I approached the Soviet Embassy here in Canberra on behalf of Amnesty International. We were making representations on behalf of a detained Ukrainian Roman Catholic priest who had been incarcerated simply for organising religious ceremonies. The response to our petition was that the priest's activities were seen as an anti-government, subversive act. The response was a rejection of Amnesty International as unreliable and our claims as bordering on misrepresentation. Our action was found to be offensive. It was seen as interfering. We were told, `You would not like it to happen in your country, would you.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-

(1) recognises the vital and creative role which public enterprise has provided in the development of Australia's economy and, in particular, the significant contributions made by the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom, Qantas and Australian Airlines; and
(2) places on record its view that public ownership is an important and essential ingredient of economic policy.

A myth which has been allowed to gain the status of a truth in Australia since the late 1940s is that public enterprise is inferior to private enterprise and that those people who work in public enterprise are less productive and lack the initiative of private enterprise employees. In a mixed economy system such as that of Australia neither the public sector nor the private sector should be considered as inferior to the other because each is dependent upon the other and each has an important role to play in our economic system. The fact is, of course, that the public sector is not inferior to the private sector and, as my motion recognises, significant contributions have been made by, for example, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Telecom Australia, Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines in the development of Australia's economy.

Let me deal first with the contribution to the national economy made by the Commonwealth Bank since it was established by the Fisher Labor Government in 1911. Over the years the bank's business activities were considerably weakened by directors with a private sector mentality, but the Curtin Labor Government's 1945 Banking Act gave the bank the opportunity to be more competitive and to help stabilise the Australian economy. As has been pointed out in the excellent publication by the H. V. Evatt Research Centre entitled The Capital Funding of Public Enterprise, the Commonwealth Bank, in underwriting the original loans for Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and General Motors-Holden's Ltd, played a crucial role in the early development of Australian manufacturing industry. The bank also became the largest savings bank and the largest institutional lender for housing. Large sums were lent to local government and to other public corporations for the provision of essential services such as roads, electricity, and sewerage. Most importantly, as well as performing such a primary role in economic development, the bank also ensured that wages and working conditions of its employees were improved to the extent that the private banks found difficulty in gaining their own work force.

With financial deregulation, with the introduction of new electronic procedures and with the staffing structures of the banks undergoing rapid change, the need for a central government bank which is prepared to lead the banks in combining efficiency with social responsibility becomes more vital than ever. In 1987 the bank had assets of over $43 billion and employed 38,000 staff in 1,270 branches. Let me quote from the H. V. Evatt Research Centre publication to indicate the recent substantial profit record of the Commonwealth Bank:

3. The Commonwealth Bank has made a handsome contribution to government revenue over the last few years. In the last two years it and its subsidiaries have returned by dividend an amount totalling $160 million to the Federal Budget. It has also expanded its capital base as a result of its profitable operations (as opposed to equity injections) by approximately $260 million over the same period.

This record has been achieved with the bank continuing to fulfil its role of assisting in the development of the economy by providing considerable loan support to the business and rural sector and lending and providing financial services in areas of social need such as housing and social security recipients. The provision of these services, apart from housing loans, is frequently not undertaken by the private banking system.

I turn now to the contribution to the economy made by Telecom. As one who has often ironically congratulated our founding fathers on producing 90 years ago a constitution which is so rigid that it continues to uphold conservative values of power and privilege, I can at least genuinely congratulate them on their foresight over Australian communications services. The Constitution gives the Commonwealth Government power in relation to postal, telegraph, telephone and other communication services. As a result of this power the Postmaster-General's Department was created to control the Australian Post Office. In 1975 legislation was approved by the Federal Parliament transferring the telecommunications functions of the former Postmaster-General's Department to the Australian Telecommunications Commission or Telecom.

It is particularly gratifying to note that since I first proposed support for Telecom in a notice of motion to the House the Government has made it clear that the ownership of Telecom is no longer an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —A victory?
—As the Minister states, it was a victory for the Government.
—It is very influential.

—It is an extremely influential body. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated on 5 September 1987 that `it would not be appropriate in Australia to sell those government business enterprises which operate as national monopolies-I refer in particular to Telecom and Australia Post'. Telecom's contribution to the economy means that it is the largest commercial enterprise in Australia and whilst some Australians complain about the costs of our telephones the plain fact is that, whereas the consumer price index increased by 164 per cent between 1976 and 1987, the cost of Telecom's services increased by only 36 per cent. Thus in real terms there was a reduction of 48 per cent in the cost of Telecom's services. Telecom services in Australia are among the cheapest and most efficient in the world. In the United Kingdom, France, West Germany and New Zealand telephone services are far more expensive. Telecom employs more than 90,000 people and all profits are reinvested in order to maintain and develop the telecommunications system. Over the past 10 years the Telecom network has expanded by 75 per cent while the staff has increased by only 3 per cent. Telecom is a highly profitable enterprise and, as can be seen from the figures I have related to the House, it has played an important role over the past 12 years in helping in the development of Australia's economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Qantas is another government business enterprise which has a strong reputation for efficiency and initiative. The company was originally privately established in 1920 as Queensland and Northern Territory Aerial Services. In 1946 and 1947 the Commonwealth Government became the owner of Qantas and provided capital increases over the years as Qantas grew to become one of the best airlines in the world. Last year Qantas employed some 14,400 people and made a record profit before tax of $104.3m. A total of 3,021,000 passengers were carried during the year and the company has an international reputation as a reliable, safe and efficient air transport carrier. Again the H. V. Evatt Research Centre publication is worth quoting:

In addition to its contribution to the positive international perceptions of Australia, Qantas also acts as a major promoter of tourism to Australia. In this and other respects, it also acts as a major earner of foreign exchange revenue. In terms of foreign policy, Qantas has been instrumental in opening up certain routes which have been deemed to be meritorious while it has closed down its operations to other destinations for the reverse reasons. In addition, the transportation resources of Qantas are readily available for use by the armed forces of the Australian government in times of threat to national security. It is far from clear that these roles could be played as easily or as willingly by a privately owned international airline in Australia.

Qantas is subject to strict regulatory control by the Commonwealth Government in the form of regulatory guidelines. These guidelines cover the airline's policies on industrial relations and superannuation, purchasing and expenditure, and its borrowing and investment plans. Despite the obvious disadvantage which such restrictions place on Qantas in comparison with privately owned competitor airlines our international carrier is undoubtedly providing essential and efficient support in the development of the Australian economy.

Finally, I turn to Australian Airlines. It is unfortunate that in this debate I do not have the time to go into detail on the attributes of the four public enterprises I have listed as examples of the importance of public ownership as an ingredient of economic policy. Australian Airlines was established in 1945 by the Chifley Labor Government as a fully government owned enterprise. It is more relevant to note in the context of this debate that almost from the outset Australian Airlines was so highly profitable that in 1952 the Menzies Government introduced the two airlines agreement in order to protect a virtually bankrupt private airline. The agreement not only sheltered the re-constituted private Ansett/Australian National but also regulated Australian Airlines from effectively competing against Ansett ANA Airlines. Australian Airlines, or Trans Australia Airlines, as it was then known, was in consequence negatively controlled in relation to the purchasing of equipment, lack of government contracts, restrictions on routes and an inadequate access to capital with heavy dividend payments to the Government.

Over the years various amendments have been made to the original Airlines Agreement Act but the net effect has been a continuation of the original restrictions which prevented the airline from effectively competing against the private airlines. Most serious was the failure of the Commonwealth Government to provide any new capital for 20 years up to 1981-82. During this period Australian Airlines continued to make good profits, but the Government insisted on a heavy dividend payout, thus restricting the ability of the public airline to use retained profits for its capital asset requirements and forcing it to rely on an inordinate amount of debt finance. Without a doubt the airlines agreement has helped to establish Ansett Airlines of Australia as an equal competitor to Australian Airlines, in both efficiency and quality of service. However, neither airline can claim that it is superior to the other on the basis of productive criteria. In 1986-87 the airline carried more than 5 million passengers and had a turnover of $878m with a work force of some 9,600, including those employed by subsidiary companies. Bearing in mind its long standing high performance, technical expertise and safety record, there is no doubt that Australian Airlines has made an important and significant contribution to the development of the Australian economy.

Whilst I have indicated the performance record of four of the leading public enterprises in Australia, which bears out the important role of public ownership in the continuing development of the Australian economy, I wish in the final stages of my speech to turn to some general observations and matters of concern. There has been considerable talk amongst Opposition members of a need to sell off some or all of many of Australia's public enterprises. There has even been some support for what has become know as privatisation of the public sector from people in the Australian Labor Party, although fortunately their voices are somewhat muted these days. In my description of the performances under public ownership of four of Australia's leading business enterprises it is very clear that they have provided immense benefits for both the general Australian public and the Australian economy. What benefits would the privatisation of such successful government enterprises produce for Australia? Apart from satisfying the ideological bias of members on the opposite side of this House that private is better than public, I would put to the Australian people that privatisation not only would be a disaster, but also would be a crime because public corporations belong to the people and should not be sold off to the business mates of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia.

I have spoken in this House on a number of occasions in support of public enterprises but one thing is very clear, and that is that the selling off to private interests of public enterprises will not assist the development of the Australian economy. The closest example we have of the disastrous results of privatisation is the situation in Britain, under the Conservative Government of Mrs Thatcher. I had intended to give examples to the House, but I want the honourable member following me to have more time to speak, so I will leave out those examples.

I have referred previously to the H. V. Evatt Research Centre publication The Capital Funding of Public Enterprise, and I recommend it as essential reading for those who wish to understand the fallaciousness of the arguments in favour of privatisation. One of the most fallacious of those arguments is that the Commonwealth Government cannot continue to exercise financial constraint while, at the same time, providing the necessary capital finance for public enterprises. As the H. V. Evatt Research Centre publication shows, many of the Commonwealth Government's macro-economic policy objectives have caused the specific micro-economic problems faced by public enterprises; such as a lack of capital, unfair regulation, and restrictive management practices. Let me quote from page 69 of the publication:

First, the argument that capital based expansion conflicts with fiscal probity is not well based, although it bears upon a number of issues. First, it is not clear that public investment in infrastructural services `crowds out' a similar (or lesser) quantity of private investment . . . Indeed, it is probably the reverse of what is actually the case. Public investment facilitates and encourages certain classes of productive investment. It is a necessary pre-requisite. Secondly, the contribution of the major Commonwealth public enterprises to the Commonwealth's total borrowing requirement is not very significant.

In the final analysis, the most important reasons why public ownership is so vital an ingredient of economic policy is that it has important ramifications for the social fabric of Australian society. I would like to end my comments by quoting from a speech I made in the old Parliament House in the 1987 Appropriations debate. In a sense, my comments today are an extension of that speech. I quote:

As part of a democratic socialist philosphy there were three underlying practical aims for the adoption of public enterprise policies by the ALP in the 1920s. Those aims are as relevant today as they were when they were adopted in the 1920s. First was the need to supply public services to the people when private enterprise was not prepared to risk its capital because it could not see an immediate capital or profit gain. Second was the aim that public enterprise, by providing good quality products and services, with satisfactory working conditions and wages for its employees, could prevent exploitation by private corporations monopolising the market. Third was the aim that the profits of public enterprises could be used to supplement government revenue and enable a reduction in overall taxation.
I ask honourable members to support the motion moved in my name as it represents the only rational economic and social recourse for a country with a mixed economy such as exists in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the pitifully small amount of time left to debate this motion, I say that it is nothing more nor less than a last ditch stand by the left wing to try to stop the inevitable process of privatisation in this country. The wording of this motion is so obviously farcical that the whole motion is rendered ludicrous. It talks about such things as the vital and creative role which public enterprises provide to Australia. I hardly think the word `creative' is appropriate. It goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: that public ownership is an important and essential ingredient of Government economic policy.

How public ownership becomes an essential ingredient is beyond me. The whole world is rapidly coming to realise that the less governments interfere in the lives of people, and the less governments own the assets of a country and run institutions which provide services to the people, the better it is for the country and the people who inhabit it. There is a realisation nowadays that if a government owns something everyone owns it but, in fact, nobody owns it. As a result of that, it is not looked after as well, there is no incentive to do better, things become very inflexible, and most importantly, the services to consumers are worse than if they were privately owned. One only has to visit a communist country to see this. If one walks down the streets of those countries to try to buy something, one has a job to find anything. If one does find anything, the service is appalling and the quality of the article is usually much less than that in free enterprise countries. Of course, in communist countries all enterprises are government owned. That is why we on this side of the House reject those things.

If a country has a high proportion of its ownership in government hands and a low proportion in private hands, then the standard of living of people in the country is inevitably low. If the reverse applies, the standard of living of the average citizen is much higher. One has only to compare the standard of living of the average citizen in the United States with that of one in Russia, and the standard of living of the average citizen in West Germany with that of one in Bangladesh. There is a very tight correlation between public and private ownership. The standard of living of people cannot be denied. Governments and people all around the world are coming to recognise this. In recent years Thatcher has led a revival of it. I am pleased to say that even the communist countries such as China and Russia are moving in this direction.

It was only mentioned in the media in the last few days that Gorbachev in Russia is thinking of turning ownership of land back to the people who should own it and run it, namely, the people of Russia. That is a very welcome development. Of course, in Australia also there is a movement. When we first talked about privatisation, the coalition was ridiculed. In May 1988, even the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said:
. . . is simply vandalism of Australia's great public authorities.
In July of that year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:

Privatisation is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. They will transfer them into the hands of a privileged few to the cost of every one of us.
Later, in November of that year, he said:
They know, as everyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares.

But the Treasurer and the Prime Minister have had second thoughts and are now amongst the strongest advocates of privatisation in Australia. I am delighted to see that they have taken the coalition's advice in that area. They want to do it, as we want to do it, because ownership of assets in private hands is more efficient-the enterprises become more responsive to the wishes of the consumers-it breaks down monopolies and, most importantly, it returns the ownership, the control, from the bureaucracy and the government to the individual. We on this side of the House trust the people to own assets. We have confidence in them that they will do it well and will do a better job. That has often been demonstrated all around the world.

Privatisation is an inevitable process. It cannot be stopped and it is welcomed by the majority of the people. No longer will profit be a dirty word. After all, profit made legally in competition with others can only happen if one serves the consumers well. If profit occurs, it allows further employment; it allows expansion; it allows provision of new services to the benefit of us all; and, of course, taxes are paid to governments from profits. This allows governments to lower overall taxes elsewhere. Privatisation is being talked about more and more. Only yesterday the Chairman of Australia Post was welcoming elements of privatisation into that institution. Air New Zealand has been privatised. Qantas Airways Ltd will follow when we win the next election. The most efficient sector of Australia Post is the private enterprise sector. One only has to look at the private mail contractors who run the mail between Bourke and Wanaaring in my electorate. God knows what it would cost if the Government were running that service. Also, the post office agencies are the most efficient sectors in Australia Post. Some of them even still open on Saturday mornings.

Telecom Australia is a monopoly. It is probably the institution I get most complaints about in my electorate. People complain about such things as slow services, outrageous work practices, and no area code map on the back of the directory. Some even complain about no service at all. In a town such as Enngonia in the far flung reaches of my electorate if there is a heavy dew on the lines at night time people cannot ring out. Government monopolies give the correction of that problem a very low priority. The Commonwealth Bank of Australia is relatively efficient by government enterprise standards but, as one of the four main banks along with the Australia and New Zealand Bank Banking Group, Westpac Banking Corporation and the National Australia Bank, it still comes up poorly. In 1987 it had only half the profit of the three other banks; it paid only half the tax; it had only little more than half the return on the funds and assets used; and returned only half the earnings per employee. There is no logic at all in a government owning a bank. In fact, the net return to the Federal Government over the last 10 years has been below zero.

It is better off for the government as well as for the Australian people if all the banks are privately owned. In conclusion, this motion is nothing more than a last ditch stand by the increasingly irrelevant quiche-eating Left against the privatisation process that will benefit all of us. The motion should be rejected.
