DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Valeriy Zemskov-War Veterans' Entitlements-Bicentennial Naval Salute Fleet-Mozambique-Style Manual-Protection of Environment-Privatisation-Western Australian Government-Iran

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has now been over 48 hours since Mr Valeriy Zemskov, Minister-Counsellor at the Soviet Embassy, was exposed as being the ranking KGB officer in Australia and a member of the KGB's elite Special Reserves. Since Mr Zemskov's exposure the Hawke Government has sat back and done nothing. Earlier Government inaction against KGB officers in Australia was recently highlighted when a respected journalist, Mr Laurie Oakes, revealed that the Government had refused to act on security advice to expel three Soviets identified as KGB officers because to have done so may have jeopardised the visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Moscow. This fear, this weak and cowering approach to our national security interests, was enough to ensure that no action was taken against the three identified officers. In the case of Mr Zemskov the Soviets have raised the stakes much higher. In his press conference yesterday, Mr Zemskov himself suggested that any further `fuss' on the issue could harm Soviet-Australian relations. He further implied that serious treatment of the claims would not be helpful to attempts to arrange a visit by Soviet Prime Minister Ryzhkov to Australia later this year.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, the Prime Minister's earlier inaction against KGB officers in Australia, coupled with Mr Zemskov's threats, augur ill for Australia's security. The visit by Soviet Prime Minister Ryzhkov has been thrown up as a bargaining chip by Mr Zemskov. In other words, Mr Zemskov is saying to Australia, `If you move to expel me, then you can forget the Ryzhkov visit', a visit that will throw the world spotlight on the Prime Minister of Australia. It is ironic that on the one hand this Government professes to be a reliable and committed member of the Western Alliance, yet on the other it is unwilling to deal decisively with Soviet threats to our national security, threats which ultimately erode the very fabric of the whole Western Alliance itself.

Other Western nations such as France, the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, when confronted with evidence of Russian intelligence service activities, act decisively. They expel the officers concerned. Even Labour governed New Zealand, considered somewhat of a pariah in the Western Alliance, moves decisively against identified KGB officers who are acting to the detriment of the country.

As late as 24 April 1987, New Zealand expelled Soviet Embassy Counsellor Sergey Budnik, identified as an officer of the KGB's First Chief Directorate. Budnik was the sixth Soviet diplomat to be expelled from New Zealand in the past 25 years. Indeed, in the period 1970 to 1987, 691 Soviets have been expelled from various countries around the world.

The one important question that remains unanswered is why this Government fails to act against identified KGB officers when confronted with the evidence of their damaging activities. Is Australia's failure to act through fear of jeopardising the Prime Minister's overseas trips or as a result of implied threats from Soviet officials such as Mr Zemskov, or as a result of the influence the Soviet Union is able to exercise in the uppermost echelons of the Public Service and the Federal Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is outrageous.

—It is quite outrageous. It is influence manifested in the shape of, among others, Mr Zemskov, who by his own admission has many contacts in high places. Until his press conference yesterday Mr Zemskov, despite suffering what is every clandestine intelligence officer's worst nightmare, had played his role admirably. In his contacts with the media, contacts in which he was under great pressure, he remained jovial, witty and charming, the epitome of the sophisticated diplomat he insists he is. However, in his answers to two of the questions posed by journalists at yesterday's press conference he totally destroyed his credibility. In answering one question he said that there were, to his knowledge, no spies at the Embassy. Then, in answer to the obvious question-why is Canberra the only Soviet Embassy in the world that does not have KGB agents?-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe what we are doing in relations with this country is all above board. There was no `playing' or `counterplaying'.
I have today sent a letter to the Prime Minister which I will now read to the House. It states:
Mr Dear Prime Minister,

I draw your attention to reports of an article by the respected Mr John Barron in the current edition of the international magazine, Readers Digest, identifying Mr Valeriy Zemskov as a member of the KGB's elite Special Reserves.
Mr Zemskov's official position is Minister-Counsellor at the Soviet Embassy in Canberra, which is the next most senior position in the Embassy after the Ambassador.

Since Mr Barron's allegations became public there has been rising public concern and debate as to what action the Australian Government intends to take to redress this major threat to our national security.
Accordingly I ask you:
1. What confirmations have you sought concerning Mr Zemskov's alleged activities from Australia's security and intelligence services, and from friendly Western security and intelligence services?
2. If such confirmations substantiate the allegations made by Mr Barron, when do you intend to expel Mr Zemskov from Australia?

3. Will you as a matter of the gravest urgency establish an inquiry to determine the damage done by Mr Zemskov to our security interests, especially in view of his admitted ready access to contacts at the highest level of government and the Federal bureaucracy?
Your response would be appreciated at the earliest opportunity.
Yours sincerely,
Ken Aldred
Member for Bruce

Mr Zemskov has played his role well. He has served his own country well and for that he deserves some admiration. However, the fact remains that he is an undeclared hostile intelligence officer acting to the detriment of Australia's national interests and because of that he should be expelled immediately. In concluding, I seek leave to table my letter to the Prime Minister, which I have just read, and a partial alphabetical listing of Soviet officials expelled worldwide during the period 1970 to 1987.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the entitlements and remuneration of prisoners of war taken by the Japanese. Before I begin, let me say that I have great admiration for the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Arthur Gietzelt, and a great deal of respect for the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Ben Humphreys. Anything I have to say today is no direct criticism of them. However, my remarks today are strong criticism of those Ministers in the Hawke Cabinet whom I have often described as having cash registers for hearts and little understanding or compassion for war veterans or their widows.

SPEECH.PARA: Five hundred and fifty thousand Australians served in all theatres of war in the Second World War; 19,000 of them were killed in action. Eight thousand prisoners of war were taken by the German and Italian forces; 7,700 of them returned to our shores. No more than 300 died. Of the 22,000 prisoners of war taken by the Japanese, only 14,000 returned.

I want the House to dwell on those startling statistics. It is difficult at any time to deal with the issue of assistance to war veterans. It is particularly difficult when one has to take into consideration the Australian men and women who were taken prisoner of war by the downward thrust of the Japanese in 1942. One really could not describe the barbaric and subhuman conditions that many of our people had to endure. I want to make it quite clear that I am not trying to re-open old wounds regarding Australian-Japanese relations. I am not anti-Japanese; I am anti-fascist and anti-militarist. This speech is not about reparations from the Japanese Government but about justice from our own Government.

In the 1974-75 Budget the Whitlam Government made available to all Japanese, German and Italian prisoners of war free medical, hospital, dental and optical treatment irrespective of whether their injuries were war related or not. Since March 1983 the Hawke Government has eroded many of the conditions which had been gained, particularly under the Whitlam Government, and honoured by the Fraser Government. My argument is that the current Government should be more compassionate and more understanding in its policies towards the dwindling number of former Japanese prisoners of war. I emphasise the words `dwindling numbers'. Of the original 14,000, less than half would now be living.

One of the deepest concerns is that now if a former prisoner of war ceases employment or reaches the age of 65, that person is not entitled to apply for the totally and permanently incapacitated pension. I know that the bureaucrats and some Cabinet members will say that that is the case with all veterans. I am talking not about all veterans but about the veterans who suffered like no other group did in the Second World War. The Government has already shown flexibility in establishing the extreme disability adjustment legislation to correct the anomaly whereby severely disabled veterans have failed to qualify for special pension rates because they were beyond retiring age. This will raise the pension up to 150 per cent of the general rate to veterans over 65 years of age who are receiving the full general rate and who meet the criteria. I commend the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Government on this new action. If those positive adjustments can be made for the normal war veterans, the Government must also review the special position of former Japanese prisoners of war.

Other detrimental changes have either reduced the benefits or tightened the eligibility of former prisoners of war. The entitlement to pharmaceuticals has been removed from the repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme and placed under the ordinary pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Further changes introduced in this year's May statement require prior departmental authority for the prescription of a wide range of expensive drugs. From 1 January this year all veterans, including former Japanese prisoners of war, admitted to nursing home care for war related conditions, have been required to pay a statutory patient fee. Previously this was free of charge.

The Government has limited the expenditure that veterans, including former Japanese prisoners of war, can spend on dental treatment to $300 in any one year and we all know that $300 a year will not go very far with dentists these days. It is argued that if the amount is not limited, veterans will obtain modern dental treatment such as capping and restructuring, which is very expensive. What understanding do the people putting those arguments have of the living conditions that former prisoners of war suffered for 3 1/2 bloody years, on starvation rations? In some cases there was no medical or dental treatment whatsoever. It is those people who need this kind of expert treatment today. It is about time that all the pennypinching, miserable and narrow-minded people with cash register hearts had some compassion for some of the conditions of these ex-servicemen. Again, I ask that special consideration be given to former Japanese prisoners of war.

I well remember receiving a note from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during a Cabinet meeting a couple of years ago. He had seen on the weekend prior to the Cabinet meeting a television program which attempted to illustrate the conditions under which our servicemen suffered on the Burma-Siam railway. He expressed in his note to me the horror of what he saw. I have always felt that the Prime Minister is a very compassionate person. But I say to Bob Hawke and to the House: we need government action directed towards former prisoners of war now. There should be a review and compassionate programs and allowances created to fill the urgent need. The Government has a moral and social responsibility to provide justice to those who served our country under such extraordinary conditions. The Government must honour that responsibility and provide them with at least some justice.

I gave the figures earlier but I will repeat them: Five hundred and fifty thousand Australians served in all theatres of war; 19,000 were killed in action. Even under the barbaric Nazi regime of Germany, of the 8,000 taken prisoner of war, 7,700 came back; in fact fewer than 300 died in their camps. But of the Japanese prisoners of war, 22,000 were taken and only 14,000 got back. I hope that that really is graphic, descriptive and imprinted into the minds of all members of parliament and that they understand the conditions which those prisoners of war had to suffer. Of those 14,000, fewer than half are left and it is about time that the Government itself-it has been in government now for five years and has eroded the conditions of those people-re-examined that situation to rectify it, to give justice to those prisoners of war and to stop being so mean and miserable.

I am aware of the problem of the deficit balance on the current account. But there is also a very healthy Budget surplus and I think that the sharing of that productivity, the sharing of the wealth of this nation, should be looked at to rectify some of the problems and illnesses of those former prisoners of war and to give them real justice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) for his penetrating comments on an issue vital to all Australians today and encourage the bipartisan support for the thrust of what he has said.

SPEECH.PARA: In his well-known work On Liberty, John Stuart Mill observed:
The liberty of the individual must be this far limited; he must not make himself a nuisance to other people.

Mill believed that the primary duty of government was to guarantee freedom of thought, expression, religion and action to its citizens. He believed that all opinions, assenting or dissenting, representing the majority or the minority viewpoint were important and should be valued. He added, however, the necessary and significant proviso that in expressing an opinion, no person or group is entitled to harm the interests of another.

I believe that Mill was on the right track and it is in this context that I speak today about the unfortunate occurrences which took place in Melbourne last weekend in relation to the visit to Victoria of the Bicentennial Naval Salute fleet. These issues have already been widely canvassed in both Houses of this Parliament, in Victoria by the media and, indeed, throughout the whole of our community. This recognition and publicity have, for the most part, been extremely critical of the tactics of the Seamen's Union; the rowdy and disgraceful behaviour of some of the demonstrators; and the `Don't blame us, it was not our fault' attitude adopted by two Labor governments directly involved. It indicates very clearly that decency and dignity and a fair go are still important to the vast majority of Australians.

It may help, at least to some extent, to restore our battered image in the eyes of those who took part in this international naval gesture of good will. However, it in no way lessens the deliberate insult to our friends and allies which has been perpetrated by people who pretend to be motivated by a desire for peace, and concern about the so-called nuclear arms race and related issues. These same people demonstrate their sincerity and commitment to the causes they say they espouse by adopting abusive, irrational, insulting, disgusting, and, in some instances, violent behaviour and tactics to get their message across.

It in no way excuses the politically motivated action of the Seamen's Union in imposing its ban on assisting two British ships to berth in Melbourne and instead, leaving them to cope with the adverse weather conditions of Port Phillip Bay. One would have thought the potential for an accident to occur under these conditions would have been far greater than had the ships been securely tied to the dock.

It in no way lessens the dismay and embarrassment experienced by the vast majority of Australians, in particular Victorians, who have watched guests invited to this country by our Government treated in a most despicable, unreasonable and unacceptable manner and then deserted by those who issued the invitation in the first place when the going got a bit tough. We have learnt by bitter and all too frequent recent experience that there simply are not any `tough to get going' on the Government benches when it comes to controlling the Socialist Left unions.

It in no way excuses the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who dismissed a totally legitimate question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in regard to this matter as `stupid and irrelevant'. Under the circumstances, it is neither stupid nor irrelevant to ask for an apology or to question who is really in control of this nation and its affairs. There are millions of Australians who share my belief that an official and sincere apology should have been immediately offered by both the Federal and Victorian governments to the men of the Ark Royal and Fort Grange, to the captain and crew of the USS Ingersoll, and others who were the target of this reprehensible behaviour of a group of irrational and irresponsible demonstrators and left wing controlled unionists.

It does not absolve the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) who obviously, and quite rightly, regrets the incidents which occurred in Melbourne but unfortunately tempers his regret by trying to shift some of the blame from the unions and the lily-livered Cain Government on to none other than the Good Lord for failing to provide the right weather conditions on this particular occasion.

The solution proffered by the Prime Minister and Minister for Defence is that the Government should not confront the unions and order them to do what they are told, but instead should capitulate to Mr Halfpenny and his henchmen and use Royal Australian Navy tugs, still to be purchased and years away from operational service, to do the job the unions should be doing. What a shameful and outrageous farce!

It is hardly surprising that the community is demanding to know who controls this country, the Government or the Socialist Left unions. Let us look at the evidence. The Government invited these ships and their crews as guests to our 200th birthday party and when they got to the door allowed them to be turned away by extremists who acted as unofficial, self-appointed, but nonetheless very effective, bouncers. Unfortunately, and to their lasting shame, it is now obvious that the Hawke and Cain governments have cravenly surrendered their authority and control to the Socialist Left union leaders.

Many of us have suspected for a long time that Labor governments have been the pawns and playthings of the socialists, the communists, the Fabians-call them what you will; they come in many guises and disguises but their motives are the same and certainly not in the best interests of this nation and its people. This latest effort serves only to reinforce the fact that these suspicions are correct.

It is deplorable and intolerable that the Cain Government has effectively been allowed to wash its hands of this matter and that the Hawke Government does not even display the intestinal fortitude to apologise for what Mr John Halfpenny, the Secretary of the Trades Hall Council, has described as an `important victory'. An important victory for whom, or for what? Such victories should be and are condemned by those who value freedom, security, international goodwill, justice and democracy; but then, none of these concepts are important to those of Mr Halfpenny's ilk and political persuasion.

They care not at all if our relationship with important and loyal allies is jeopardised. They are delighted to find a government so apparently ready and willing to abrogate its responsibilities in favour of appointing union extremists as de facto managers of the nation's affairs in regard to vital and sensitive defence and foreign policy matters. They rejoice as Australia's international reputation and standing are threatened by illegal strikes and the intimidatory, perverse and revolting behaviour, including spitting and the throwing of condoms, of protesters who say they are concerned for the future of this country.

As we learned this morning, Mr Deputy Speaker, the trade union movement in Western Australia is also gearing up to disrupt the arrival of Ark Royal in Fremantle. Evidently, the Seamen's Union is still deciding whether or not its tug boat crew members will provide assistance for the British naval vessels. Hopefully, sanity and common sense will prevail. However, in an interview on AM, the President of the Construction, Mining and Energy Workers Union, whose members have decided to withdraw necessary support services from some of the naval salute vessels visiting the port of Fremantle, said the trade union movement needs to `make a statement', to show that its members are concerned about visits of nuclear capable ships.

There is a big difference between making a statement and making a nuisance of one-self and a laughing stock of the Government and the nation. One wonders whether the same concerns will be expressed by those unions if, and when, vessels from the Russian fishing fleet seek to utilise the facilities of the Fremantle port. To his credit, the Minister for Defence has already stated that the Melbourne port fiasco will not happen again. He has said that the Navy would provide any services withdrawn by the unions. But that is not the point. The Minister should be ordering the unions to do the job they are meant and are paid to do. He has legislation at his disposal to ensure that his directions are being followed. Why is he not using it?

There was a time, Mr Deputy Speaker, not that long ago, when Australians were relieved and grateful to see British and United States warships in our ports. They symbolise the protection and security that good and loyal friends may provide in times of trouble. The Bicentennial Naval Salute was a gesture which demonstrated to us that this loyalty and friendship still exists, although we hope and pray that they will never again be needed in the same context as they were those 40 or so years ago.

It was a gesture by the very countries which are committed to the preservation and protection of the rights and freedoms which are so vigorously claimed, so frequently exercised, and so blatantly abused and exploited by politically extreme unionists and demonstrators such as those who thumbed their noses at our bicentennial naval fleet visitors, the Government, and the community of Melbourne.

These ships and men sailed thousands of miles to join in our birthday celebrations. They were treated scornfully and discourteously by a small section of our community who, in expressing their opinions, imposed their will to the detriment and harm of others. On behalf of those Victorians and other Australians who are understandably appalled by the actions of the Seamen's Union and the irresponsible element amongst the demonstrators and the weak-willed governments which stood by and watched their authority usurped by the rabble, I extend an apology to those who came in peace and friendship to participate in the Bicentennial Naval Salute to Australia: We hope that they will forgive the appalling manners and politically motivated actions of the few and remember instead that the majority of Australians offered them a warm welcome and recognised them and the nations they represent as they deserve to be recognised-as our friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, Mozambique is a country which is little known in Australia. People are vaguely aware of a civil war going on there. Some remember that it was once a Portuguese colony and earlier this year it gained some publicity when an Australian missionary, Ian Gray, was arrested and put on trial. There was some ill-informed and unjustified media criticism of Australian aid to Mozambique earlier this year and we heard the usual rubbish from the apologists for the racist regime in South Africa on the Opposition side.

SPEECH.PARA: Mozambique, with a population of some 14 million, should be better known and better understood in Australia. What should also be better understood is the activities of the South African backed terrorism that is bringing such misery to Mozambique. Their activities have made Mozambique one of the poorer countries in the world and have given it one of the world's highest infant mortality rates. They have caused large parts of its economy not to function.

South Africa, by its support of the rebels, intends that Mozambique will not reach its full potential. Indeed, Mozambique has great potential. It is a huge country with much unused fertile land and, like much of Africa, it has considerable possibilities for irrigation and substantial mineral resources. Its railways and ports are vital to its neighbours and it is an important and valued member of the regional economic development organisation, SADAC.

Portuguese colonial rule was ineffective and brutal. For four centuries Portugal maintained little more than a trading network stretching inland from the seaports. The Portuguese did little on education or services. They simply exploited and raped the country; at independence Mozambique lacked even the rudiments of a modern economy.

The new government inherited a large external debt and a currency that was virtually useless abroad. With independence, most of the 250,000 Portuguese inhabitants fled, taking with them Mozambique's limited fund of administrative and technical expertise. The Mozambique work force was untrained and uneducated. The illiteracy rate at independence was some 96 per cent. The civil war is not only one of the most vicious in Africa but I would say one of the most vicious in the world. The terrible murders, mutilation and destruction are being carried out by the Mozambique National Resistance, known as Renamo.

Renamo was created by the Rhodesian secret service in 1977 to punish Mozambique for that country's assistance to the Zimbabwe liberation movement. With Zimbabwe's independence in 1980, sponsorship of Renamo was taken over by the South African Defence Force. What makes Renamo different from other groups is its deliberate destructive nature.

I can understand rebel forces. I do not always necessarily agree with them, but be they in Ethiopia, Angola, Nicaragua, El Salvador or wherever, basically they are saying, `Our philosophy is better suited to the economic needs of this country', or `Our economic policies are better', or `We as individuals are better suited to running the country than you are.' As I said, we might not always agree with this philosophy or what they are fighting for but we can understand it. Renamo has no philosophy, no economic policy, and no scheme for an alternative government. Its members are determined to bring chaos and destruction. They bomb hospitals, schools and health centres; in fact, they have bombed over 30 per cent of the health centres in Mozambique. They bomb the railways which are so vital to Mozambique; they kill and maim-and all this with the support of the racist regime of South Africa.

Of course, the apologists for the racist South Africa regime cry, `Where is your evidence?' The evidence is in the many documents captured from Renamo. On a recent visit to Mozambique I spoke with the United States Ambassador and there was no doubt in her mind of the South African support for the rebels. There was no doubt in our Australian officials' minds, or in the minds of the aid workers there; Margaret Thatcher, not renowned for supporting left governments, has permitted since 1986 British Army personnel to train the Mozambican Army.

Chester Crocker, United States Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, testified to the United States Senate hearing on Renamo's activities, putting the blame well and truly on South Africa. In fact, throughout the world, people of all political shades agree on the destabilising activities of the South African Government in Mozambique; that is, except for the apologists for racist South Africa on the Opposition benches, especially the National Party members in this House. It is no wonder that they invited the South African Ambassador to address their recent conference. He must have felt very much at home.

Why, people might ask, would South Africa wish to destabilise one of her neighbours? Would it not be in South Africa's own interest to have a peaceful, prosperous neighbour, reaching its full potential? But Mozambique, like Zimbabwe, is a multiracial country. If there were a successful multiracial country next door, people, even in South Africa, would ask: If in Mozambique or if in Zimbabwe, why not in South Africa?

The racist regime in South Africa therefore is determined to see that a multiracial country cannot exist as its neighbour. Australia can assist Mozambique more. We must bring diplomatic pressure on South Africa to stop its destabilising activities. We can give more aid, especially technical aid; we can understand better the situation in that country. Many Australian-owned organisations and our Government are distributing food, clothing and tools to the distressed and displaced people of Mozambique. Yet time and time again these efforts are being destroyed by vicious Renamo attacks,

Farming projects are ransacked, food convoys ambushed and development workers murdered. I have recently been involved in two campaigns directed at the South African Government, urging them to stop the killing and maiming in Mozambique. A group of Uniting Church ministers from South Australia on 1 September laid a wreath at the gates of the South African Embassy here in Canberra. This was the culmination of a week's activity in Canberra to draw attention to the plight of Mozambique. Also in September, I launched a campaign at the Pitt Street Uniting Church in Sydney for the Concerned Citizens of Mozambique. Both these campaigns are urging people to write to the South African Ambassador here in Canberra, urging South Africa to stop the killing and maiming of innocent people in Mozambique.

Mozambique has the potential to be a self-supporting country, but effective aid and lasting development can take place only where there is peace. The tragedy is that racist South Africa, by her brutal destabilising activities, is preventing Mozambique from achieving its full potential and the peace this country so richly deserves. I am pleased to see two National Party members in the chamber because it is their Party that is usually supporting the racist regime in South Africa.

I would ask these people to consider just by giving support to the South African regime exactly what they are involved in, in countries like Mozambique, Zimbabwe, and the surrounding frontline states, because South Africa is determined that these countries will not reach their full potential. She is determined to continue destabilising-destabilising in Mozambique as she is destabilising in Zimbabwe. While South Africa continues these activities--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Mozambique Government?
—The evidence is there. The evidence is there and you can shout and yell and shake your heads--
—Anything to do with the Mozambique Government?
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson will stop interjecting.

—Do what you like. The evidence is there through captured documents; through evidence before the United States Senate; through visits by the current United States Ambassador to Mozambique; and through evidence given at the trial of Ian Gray, who was a runner for the rebels there. He is lucky, I must say, not to have faced a firing squad. In most other countries he would have faced a firing squad. The evidence is there. I call on all members of this House to put pressure on South Africa to stop her destabilising activities and I especially call on the National Party in this place to stop giving aid and comfort to the racist regime in South Africa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It goes without saying that I reject utterly the comments of the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), especially in relation to the National Party. Today I bring to the House this dreaded Style Manual released by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) a fortnight ago and I want to address grievance on the matter of the ability of governments to communicate at all levels with the people in a simplistic, constructive way, rather than in the arrogant and out of touch manner which seems to be emerging from this Labor Government in office.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to be that bureaucrats, academics and governments which perpetrate these acts upon people are taking it on their own to say that they know best, that they know what should be done with our English language, and that people will have to put up with the types of communications that they draft in accordance with their Style Manual. I, of course, refer to the artificial decision and the objectionable priority to delete the word `man' from the English language and to replace it with some extraordinarily convoluted phrases. Mr Deputy Speaker, as I speak to you at this moment, `The Flying Scotsman, a very historic steam engine, is moving from Sydney to Melbourne on its first major visit to Australia. The Government will end up renaming `The Flying Scotsman' as `The Flying Scotsperson' before it arrives at Spencer Street this afternoon. That is how incredible and how arrogant the Government is getting as it lays down preferred manners for deleting the word `man' from our language.

Before dealing in detail with the Style Manual, let me turn to another example which is in part related, and which comes from the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Repatriation Commission. I am pleased to see the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) at the table. This is the all time classic; it must take out some form of record. The veteran involved has given me his permission to utilise this example. The file number is MSS7841 and I am now going to read to the House a 266-word sentence, a single paragraph sentence, the size of which defies examination, let alone understanding, for the veterans who have to put up with this type of phraseology.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote it?

—It comes from the Repatriation Commission, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, all of which is under the responsibility of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who is in the chamber at this time. Let me quote this extraordinary sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to determining this aspect, section 9 of the Act states in effect that an injury or disease shall be taken to be war-caused if it resulted from an occurrence that happened while the veteran was rendering operational service, it arose out of, or was attributable to any eligible war service rendered by the veteran, it resulted from an accident that occurred while a veteran was travelling, while rendering eligible war service but otherwise than in the course of duty, on a journey to a place for the purpose of performing duty or away from the place of duty upon having ceased to perform duty, it was, in the opinion of a question, due to an accident but would not have occurred, or were due to a disease that would not have been contracted, but for his having rendered eligible war service or but for changes in his environment consequent upon his or her having rendered eligible war service, or the injury suffered, or the disease contracted, was suffered or was contracted while the veteran was rendering eligible war service, but did not arise out of that service or suffered or contracted before the commencement of the period, or last period of eligible war service rendered by the veteran but not while the veteran was rendering eligible war service, and, in the opinion of the Commission, the injury or disease was contributed to in a material degree by or was aggravated by, any eligible war service rendered by the veteran being service rendered after the veteran suffered that injury or contracted that disease but not otherwise.

What an incredible example, Mr Deputy Speaker! That is the sort of nonsense-type drafting of communications, from a Department that does try and a Repatriation Commission that does try, that the veterans of this country have to put up with. That is the classic example of all time-a 266-word single sentence in the middle of a determination-advising letter which does not make life easy for veterans. That is what we should be on about. Certainly as shadow Minister for veterans' affairs I can say that that is what the coalition policy is all on about-a fair go for veterans. I can ease the mind of Hansard by saying that I will make available the exact copy of that 266-word sentence or paragraph.

Let me hark back to this incredible Style Manual and the incredible chapter which I highlighted in the national media over the last fortnight as being a ridiculous priority by government. It is chapter 8, `Non-sexist Language'. We now know from our further questions in the Senate that the direct cost of this little chapter was some $3,691. What does it set out to do? It sets out to rewrite military history. It sets out to rewrite our heritage, so far as our language is concerned. So `manpower' is to become `human resources'; `labour', `labour force'; `personnel', `staff'; `staffing', `work force'; `man-size' is to become `big, huge, large'; `manhours' are to become `labour hours, working hours, work hours'; `manhole' is to become `access hole' or `utility hole'; `bushman' becomes `person from the bush'. `Bushpeople', is allowable but not `bushman'. What would the Bush Tucker Man say about that, in terms of his contribution to this nation?

`Middleman' is an acceptable and reasonable term but it now becomes `an intermediary' or a `wholesaler'. Sportsmen, our fine Olympic athletes who have come back to this country, are not now sportsmen. They are `athletes, players, sports competitors, sportspersons, men and women in sport', but not `sportsmen'.

`Statesmanlike' is an expression which we hear in Question Time from time to time from members of the front bench of this Government, but we see very little of it, because they are not anything like statesmen; they, of course, are on the left of the chair, but that is to go. It is `authoritative, diplomatic, experienced, skilful, tactful', and so I could go on.

The poor old engineman, the poor old postman, the poor old milkman, the poor old newsman are to go; and, above all, the ombudsman is to go as well. He is to become `ombud, attorney-ombudsperson, parliamentary commissioner, protector, representative or watchdog'. How much reprinting of legislation is associated with that one change and the add-on cost that will be involved? I come now to the one that I object to most, and I know my colleague the shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), joins me in this. Such terms as `seaman' are to be replaced by `mariner' or `seafarer', but `serviceman', part of our military heritage, is to be dispensed with. We are going to have `servicer' or `military member of a service'; anything, in a sense, but `serviceman'.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one will take any notice of it.

—It is absolutely objectionable. It is artificial. it reflects the priority of an arrogant and out of touch government that does not understand what grassroots Australia is thinking. Let me assure the House and the nation that the coalition recognises just how out of touch a priority it is, how much waste of money is involved, money which would be better spent on roads such as the terrible road between Deniliquin and Wakool and beyond.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me call on the Government to review this total rewrite of our heritage, of our language. I respect their right to demonstrate on the forecourt. I object to their claiming a right to block access to and from the main doors of our Parliament House. I think it is disgraceful. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to use my time in this grievance debate to address what I regard and this Government regards as an extremely important issue in terms of the future of our country. I am talking about safeguarding our environment. Recently I was privileged to give an address to the Northern Territory Institute of Quarrying. In part of that address I discussed with the Institute questions on the environment. I said that in my view we need to assess carefully the impact of development on our environment.

SPEECH.PARA: The conservation debate is less and less the preserve of any minority group in our society as the consequences of pollution that can be unleashed by industrial development become apparent around the world. It is my firm view that a strong economy depends on a healthy environment. We will not survive if we allow pollution slowly to destroy our countryside, cities and oceans. We will not survive if we use the land in ways which are not sustainable nor even if we allow every piece of land to be open to human activities. By doing so, it is my firm view we become poorer and not richer.

Today we are beyond facile arguments to pretend to trade off economic growth against environmental and social well-being. We have to be. We cannot afford to mess around with our environment the way we have in the past. The Federal Government is paying increasing attention to environmental issues and, in particular, the question of land use in the context of environmental needs; industry, I might say, is also to its credit taking this issue seriously. For example, the Australian Mining Industry Council (AMIC) recently held a conference in Darwin on mining in the environment and various environmental issues were raised at the recently held north Australian development conference in Alice Springs.

Valuation of different land uses from a community point of view is a complex task. Priority for different uses from an overall economic viewpoint may vary over time due to changing economic, social, environmental and technical circumstances. Some uses of the land are flexible; they can be easily changed. Other types of land use, as I am sure you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, are inflexible because once they are applied the land cannot be restored to its pre-existing state.

In between these extremes a number of combinations of uses may be possible. There are, however, some basic objectives that need to be recognised and understood as ground rules in the development game. We need to acknowledge that development should not occur if these objectives and basic ground rules are not met. The first of these is the maintenance of essential ecological processes and life support systems. The second is the preservation of genetic diversity. The third is the sustainable utilisation of species and ecosystems. The fourth is the maintenance and enhancement of environmental qualities. Indeed, AMIC, the peak mining body, has endorsed these principles. These are, in fact, the basic objectives of the national conservation strategy of Australia.

There are five relevant strategic principles guiding these objectives and they are: firstly, to integrate conservation and development and emphasise their interdependence and common ground; secondly, to retain options for future use; thirdly, to focus on causes as well as symptoms; fourthly, to accumulate knowledge for future application; and, fifthly, to educate the community about the interdependence of development and conservation.

The purpose of this national conservation strategy for Australia is to provide nationally agreed guidelines for the use of living resources by Australians so that the reasonable needs and aspirations of society can be sustained in perpetuity. The Federal Government's message is clear: economic development and environmental protection must be seen as compatible rather than conflicting objectives. It is a message which is being adopted on a continuing basis by various groups around Australia.

I have already spoken about the Australian Mining Industry Council. I am pleased to say that two other groups have been recently formed in the Northern Territory in the pastoral industry. One is a central Australian group; it is called the Central Australian Land Management Association and comprises pastoralists of the central Australian area. One of the members of this group is a Mr Bob Purvis and I have spoken about Mr Purvis in the past in this House.

Mr Purvis is the owner-manager of a property 200 kilometres north-east of Alice Springs. This property has been in the family since 1920 and was previously known as Woodgreen. When Mr Purvis took over management of the station in 1960 it was very badly eroded and degraded. Wholesale pasture and land degradation had resulted from poor management practices. When he took over the situation in 1960 he had determined to establish a productive breeding herd, to reclaim degraded country, to manage debt in the short term to survive and to develop his own philosophy, a key philosophy, of management because the only advice that the industry or government could offer at the time was the conventional wisdom which had produced the crisis he was in. Fortunately for Australia and, indeed, for Mr Purvis, he disregarded that advice.

Mr Purvis, apart from being educated at a public school in Adelaide, has spent his entire life in the Northern Territory. After schooling he returned to the Northern Territory first to work at Atartinga, his family property, and then to assume management of that property. During the 1950s the drought brought Atartinga close to ruin. But, as I have said, rather than adopt the widespread conventional wisdom of the time, that the deterioration of land and economic crisis of the pastoral industry could be attributed solely to drought conditions, Mr Purvis saw something wrong with the overall production system and realised that he had to change his management techniques radically if Atartinga was again to be productive.

He embarked on a system of pastoral management which would-it had two aspects to it-minimise his dependency on climatic windfalls; and secondly, minimise his dependency on government handouts when the windfalls failed to materialise. He did not seek the assistance of government every time that drought struck. He saw the benefits of providing appropriate management strategies to land management.

The biggest myth prevailing in the pastoral industry is that the country comes back regardless of the regional ecosystems. The widespread view is that the climate is solely responsible for the condition of land and therefore its carrying capacity and those who support this view can always find evidence to support their case. It is, after all, always easier to blame the climate than to blame poor management. While it is true that in some parts of Australia the country is resilient and will bounce back, it is not true of the Northern Territory pastoral lands which require careful management and analysis to be productive.

Society, as I have said, cannot afford to gamble with arid and semi-arid lands. Neither can it afford to support the risk takers in pastoral management by bearing the cost of land degradation and government handouts. The Central Australian Land Management Association is, I believe, a very important step in addressing the concerns of land degradation and land management in central Australia. A similar group has been set up in the Victoria River district of the Northern Territory.

I think this all bodes well for the success of the Government's program in managing soil conservation and land degradation. It is important that we recognise that some of the most productive and profitable areas in this country reside north of the Tropic of Capricorn and we need to direct more of our research attention to land management techniques in these areas. Finally, I would like to conclude by giving the House some aspects of Mr Bob Purvis's personal philosophy about land management.

These are: firstly, nurture your land and it will repay you; secondly, abuse your land and it will break you, sooner or later; thirdly, manage your land first and the stock will respond; fourthly, avoid large concentrations of stock; fifthly, run more mobs of smaller numbers. Next, aim for stock quality, not quantity and have no rogues in your herd. Wean calves and supplement cows. Take water to where the palatable feed is. Cattle graze a shorter distance from water during summer. Supply clean water; cover tanks and clean out troughs regularly. Repair degraded land with ponding banks and pitting.

Muster at six-monthly intervals to facilitate weaning, quieten cattle and shift the herd to allow pasture spelling. Matches are cheaper than dozers for scrub control. Avoid division fences through watering points; this aids stock control, reduces stock pressure on fences and reduces the grazing pressure on pastures close to water. I believe that Mr Purvis provides a good example of the type of land management practices that ought to be adopted in the arid zones of Australia.

There is one aspect of his management system which I believe is deserving of particular attention and that is his use of a fire regime to control his environment. Mr Purvis has no compunction in using fire. He said that the first major bushfire that he fought was almost his last. Now he uses fire. He says he progressed to the use of savage fires lit on 40-degree centigrade days, with a strong north-westerly wind to assist him in managing the environment. It is a demonstration to all people in the pastoral sector of arid zones.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When he is not basking in the self-deluding glory of foreign officials who are paid to flatter their guests, our arrogant, out-of-touch Treasurer (Mr Keating) would have us believe that his shallow rationalisations for a failed and flawed policy, which he trots out every day, are some sort of evidence of a degree of economic rationalism unprecedented in Australia. The idea that any government has the solution to all or most of the economic problems of Australia is as prevalent today amongst members of this Labor Government as it has been amongst any government in the past. I was sorry not to have the opportunity to debate a motion brought on this morning by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), dealing with the general topic of privatisation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is in this debate over privatisation that we see Government speaker after Government speaker asserting that it does not matter whether the government owns a business or whether it is privately owned. They argue that what matters is the management of the enterprise or the degree of competition in the market. The same apologists cannot see the difference between the actions of government supported by taxpayers' dollars and coercive legislation and the actions of private individuals investing their own money and trusting their own judgment. To everyone other than honourable members opposite, with their pretence of omniscience and arrogant insistence that political control by them is the same as control by all Australians, it is clear that government ownership is very different from private ownership. Remember the old gag, that the worst possible type of firm to deal with is one which is run like the post office. That reflects people's perceptions of government involvement in the running of businesses.

The most obvious difference between government-owned firms and privately-owned firms is that, while government firms might make large losses, they almost never fail and they never go bankrupt. They will always be bailed out by a Labor government; indeed they are likely to get additional funding and support as if by way of reward for their incompetence.

Government trading corporations have other advantages because they have the ear of government as to regulation of the industry in which they operate and frequently they benefit from a degree of protection from competition which no private firm does or should receive. Any government owning and operating firms when it does not need to costs both the taxpayer and the consumers who must deal with them. So does the practice of the Labor Government in Western Australia, my own State, in bailing out its rich mates in private business; but that is a matter for another day. There is absolutely no hard evidence, Mr Deputy Speaker, to suggest that government ownership offers any advantage in price or service to the Australian public, unless those advantages are paid for by taxpayers or other consumers whose choices are restricted by government enforced monopolies.

The issue of privatisation helps to demonstrate two important features of the modern Labor Party which the Treasurer claims to have moulded in his own Grim Reaper image. The first is the arrogant assumption that government knows better than anyone else what is really in their interests; the second is the deliberate blurring of the difference between private affairs and the role and actions of government. Amongst the senior Ministers of this Keating-Hawke Government it is difficult to pick the most self-righteous and most arrogant. Is it, for example, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) who, after suffering the severest referendum defeat ever, appeared on national television to berate Australian voters for their lack of understanding and for listening to the campaign mounted by the Opposition?

Is it the same Attorney-General who seriously expects the Parliament to accept a nationalised company scheme which adds to the power of his Department, when he finds so many flaws in the Bill himself that 280 amendments were proposed at the very time the Bill was first debated in this House?

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is a candidate with his continuing belief that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) should choose to stand down as leader now, and for his attempts to dictate the future direction of all higher education in Australia. Or is it the lame duck Prime Minister himself, who recklessly uses the status of his office to ensure a comfortable retirement for his mates and for others to whom he feels indebted?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or wants to get out of the road.

—Yes, after he has inserted the knife. There is one particular example we all remember. Perhaps it is, as most people think, the Treasurer, who, in his relentless plunder of tax revenue, is led to believe that he is above the law. It is the Treasurer and would-be Prime Minister who preaches to a miserably attended session of the International Monetary Fund, even though Australia has an inflation rate well above that of other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries; a balance of payments deficit which underpins a persistent and enormous foreign debt problem; a sclerotic labour market; poor productivity growth; and perilously low investment. The gall of such preaching, when his only achievements have been to deregulate the financial markets in line with worldwide trends and to balance a Budget through massive taxing of the Australian public! It is incredible.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I should express a degree of sympathy with the Treasurer. He is stuck with the burden of a lame duck Prime Minister who will probably last only long enough to ensure a coalition win at the next election. It is clear that the writing is on the wall for the Hawke-Keating Government, or the Keating-Hawke Government as it is becoming known, and, as the last days of Labor rule pass, it becomes more apparent that its goals have more to do with maintaining power than with securing the peace, order and good government of the Federation. If ever evidence were needed that the end is near, observe the unholy rush to deliver the fruits of office to as many supporters as possible, before the gravy train comes to an end.

There is also this abiding inability of the Labor Party to distinguish between the private and public sectors. Actions which are perfectly legitimate for private individuals take on an entirely different character when pursued through government. Hoping to secure the odd directorship on retirement is reasonable, when it is offered by a private firm which, after all, itself will bear the cost and benefits of its decision. But the spectacle of political apparatchiki forever being maintained on the public payroll is quite another matter.

I instance just one: the former Premier of South Australia, Mr Don Dunstan. The pursuit of ambition is laudable when it is achieved by voluntary actions of individuals, but it takes on a very different character when it becomes the means of empire building by Ministers and parts of the government. Honourable members opposite could, at least, have the honesty not to repeat the fallacy that what a Labor government does is somehow, and by their definition, in the interests of all Australians. After all, the present Government was elected in 1987 by slightly less than half of the electorate.

It is time that the same fallacy which is used to argue that government-owned enterprises are really owned by all Australians was exposed; they are not. If they were, there would be a stampede, a rush, because many, many people would want to sell their shares of these underperforming assets very quickly. What the Australian Labor Party fails to realise is that everything which it does as the Government is paid for by someone else, the taxpayers. What do they get for their trouble? The Government treats the taxpayers with arrogance and contempt. Few will be sorry to see the back of this tired Government, led by a man who, win or lose the next election, is living on borrowed time, time which is on loan from a Treasurer who is not giving up the fight and who is increasingly desperate to assume the mantle of Prime Minister of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I must say that I have always thought that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is a reasonable fellow. He certainly creates very little in the way of ripple in this House; in fact he seems to do very little, but today's diatribe from him indicates that when you can fathom his somewhat rambling rhetoric, when you can fathom the gist of it, it seems that he is straitjacketed by his ideological prejudices. I suggest to the honourable member that, if he really is concerned about impropriety in government, he should look at the performance of the Court Government when it signed the take-or-pay contract to take gas from the North West Shelf and supply it to Perth at prices which were very high.

SPEECH.PARA: It was warned by every private sector consultant not to do it, but it proceeded to do that. The gas is cheaper in Perth than it is at its point of origin. In fact the gas is cheaper delivered to Japan than it was when available in the Pilbara. That, of course, meant that the Government had no alternative but to use the gas to generate electricity, which meant closing down the coal mines. A Labor government could not be so irresponsible. The Labor Government has been forced by that irresponsible action of the Court Government-I would say that almost criminal action of the Court Government-to seek other uses for that gas.

I might also add, when we are talking about wasting public money, that the Court Government agreed to provide a pipeline at the cost of $1 billion of Western Australian taxpayers' money to bring that same gas for that company to Perth, so that the company could have the privilege of selling it at high prices to the Perth population. When the honourable member for Curtin talks about impropriety in government, it is the grossest hypocrisy that he never mentioned that incident at all.

I got up today to speak about an important matter. I refer to the Australian newspaper of 9 October, which carried an article which said, `Iran cracks down ruthlessly on rebels'. This article sets out how the forces of the Ayatollah were using the Mujahideen as shooting galleries and had killed thousands upon thousands of these people, virtually wiping them out. It is interesting because that article was a reprint of a Guardian article in late September. The Guardian did have the decency to publish an article by the Mujahideen which completely refutes the allegations of the Ayatollah.

I think the Mujahideen make some very good points. They say that their forces were very successful, were able to wipe out nine of the Ayatollah Khomeini's crack revolutionary guard and got a lot of support from local people. They also say that their casualties were severe, something like 1,400, greatly reduced on the figures produced by the Ayatollah, but the Ayatollah's casualties were much higher. Given the performance of the Ayatollah and the enormous abuse of civil liberties and human rights that has occurred in Iran, I would suspect that there is more than a grain of truth in the Mujahideen claims.

These people are leading a war, a battle for human rights and for civil liberties in Iran. I am sure that in the long run they are going to win. It does give me some concern that the world and Australia, and I refer to Australia particularly because it is my country, seem to turn a blind eye to the atrocities committed by the Ayatollah's regime, perhaps because we have a very large trade surplus with that country. I am often concerned at the apparent hypocrisy that we have in our attitudes to, say, Iran and the abuses of civil liberties that are going on there and our attitude to the situation in South Africa.

We see in the newspapers that the Ayatollah is saying that when people from the Mujahideen whom he has had in gaol for terms of five or seven years finish their terms, he then executes them. It seems to me to be the ultimate double jeopardy. I think it is something that we really should be asking some serious questions about. I do not believe that consideration by Australia of civil rights and human caring issues worldwide will affect trade. I believe that Iran deals with us because we supply the best quality products at the best prices and it will continue to do that. I also believe that in the long run, and I think we should think in terms of the long run, it is going to stand this country in much greater stead if we are seen to be always fearlessly standing up for these issues regardless of immediate initial cost.

I might add that I am unhappy also about the situation that is occurring in Iraq in respect to the way it is treating the Kurdish people. The situation that is occurring in Iran is probably beyond comparison anywhere else in the world. Certainly, I do not think that Pinochet in Chile could be accused of conducting anything like the abuses of human rights that the Ayatollah is conducting, nor is it for such a narrow purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is orchestrated genocide.

—Yes, I agree with my good friend, it is orchestrated genocide. It is something which the world should be making very loud and very concerned noises about. The fact that we do not do so I think makes us a little suspect when we do take on these issues in other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I would certainly implore this Government, the Government of which I am part, to take a very strong line with Iran and to argue that those people who have served gaol sentences be released, as they should, and not subjected to this double jeopardy of instant execution on completion of their terms.

I might also add in this context that women seem to be singled out and to suffer disproportionately. This is, no doubt, because of the peculiarities of the particular culture in which they live. This might be a very useful lesson to many of the multiculturalists in this country who tell us that we have to honour and respect and have regard for the cultures of other people. I think culture should be seen in the context of human rights and, where human rights are not compatible with that culture, we should have no hesitation in condemning that culture.

I would like to hear the Multicultural Commission and the people who drive the multicultural industry in this country come out very strongly and say just that-that where there is a conflict between human rights, individual liberties, there is no place in this country for those aspects of those cultures.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday of last week, 10 October, the Third National Prayer Breakfast was held in the Great Hall of this Parliament House, hosted by a number of members and senators. The thrust of the purpose of the gathering is expressed in 1 John, chapter 1, verse 3:

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen and heard we declare to you so that you also will join with us in the fellowship that we have with the Father, and with the Son, Jesus Christ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to a young man who died in the early hours of Sunday, 16 October 1988. His name was Matthew Francis Nelson and he was aged only 17. I speak on his behalf because he was a young attendant who had worked in this Parliament House for 2 1/2 months and during that time I had come to know him as a friendly, cheerful young man who worked on the wing where I am presently accommodated. Of course, those who are also attendants in this House knew him much better than I and, rather than express my rather limited tributes, I thought I would read two notes that have been given to me by some of his colleagues. The first of those notes said:

SPEECH.PARA: Matthew, your young carefree happiness and friendliness made everyone here smile. It is hard to say what we really feel because we miss you so much. We all knew you as a happy, generous, smiling person and you often made those around you feeling down, feel good again. You were great to work with and have as a friend. We will always remember you as Matt, the one who made us laugh. We will never forget you, mate.
The other note stated:

Underneath Matt was an unreal guy, who when you were around him made you laugh and smile. He was a guy that really cared and was happy himself at the worst of times. Matt had what really counted underneath and there will always be a happy memory, not only to me, but to everyone else who knew him.

I understand that in the galleries today there are a number of his colleagues, the attendants who shared his short time with us in this Parliament House. I know they join with me and I am sure other members of this House in paying tribute to a young man so tragically taken from us. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that so many of the nursing homes in this country are having to cut their costs right to the bone that they do not have any spare money and because they happen to disagree with the ruling of the Minister's delegate on what their fees should be it is a case of blatant injustice that nursing homes which are not filled with money should be asked to pay a fee of $500 to have their situation reviewed in terms of fees and further to pay a fee of $500 per half day for any sort of hearing.
