TALK.START.PARA: —It galls me to have to raise in this place yet again and highlight an incident in which Telecom Australia has blatantly disregarded its statutory community responsibilities. I refer to the Australian Telecommunications Commission's enterprise projects policy, relating to semi-rural residential subdivisions. The aim of this policy is to make someone else pay for what Telecom should be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: Specifically, Mr Green began developing in 1982 a semi-rural subdivision just 15 minutes from the city of Bunbury in Western Australia. Telecom brought in its enterprise policy in early 1986, almost four years after Mr Green started his development and several years after first blocks were sold. Yet Telecom wrongly enforced its policy retrospectively and refused to cable the area unless Mr Green contributed thousands of dollars to pay for it.

In February this year I referred Mr Green's case to the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Eight months later the Ombudsman has not been able to make a ruling because Telecom will not respond to his investigations. Meanwhile the first resident to apply for a phone service, Mr Grahame Humphreys, advised last week that he had been too late to the bedside of his dying father because relatives could not contact him. Mr Acting Speaker, it is a scandal that such a situation exists in civilised twentieth century Australia.

I note from Telecom's report that the responsible Minister did not have cause to direct Telecom on any matter of public interest in this previous year. This is certainly a case for the Minister's intervention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the failure of the New South Wales Greiner Government to recognise the importance of proceeding immediately with the construction of the proposed Caloola Pass road, thus putting in jeopardy the economic development of the Illawarra region. With the downturn of the steel and coal industries in the Illawarra, our region suffered greatly. Thanks to the intervention of the newly elected Hawke Labor Government, the steel industry was saved, but 12,000 jobs have still been lost in this industry.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the great signs of hope for the future economic development of the Illawarra has been the work of the Port Kembla Harbour task force. This organisation has worked hard and effectively to develop the port of Kembla as a significant outlet for the Australian export trade. This is rightly seen as one of the most valuable ways of diversifying our local economy, thereby ensuring more jobs. To date, the most notable achievement of the task force has been the construction of the grain handling terminal at Port Kembla. For Port Kembla to reach its full potential as an export development port, it is absolutely essential that there is put in place a suitable road infrastructure to get the product from inland New South Wales to the coast quickly and effectively.

Caloola Pass road is an essential part of this plan. The road meets all the criteria of a national arterial road, but the Greiner Government refuses to see this. The refusal of the New South Wales Minister, Mr Murray, to recommend an immediate start to this road is, I believe, an act of deliberate spite against the people of the Illawarra.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 October there occurred a momentous occasion in the history of Latin America and certainly a watershed in the history of Chile. It was the free and democratic elections. I am saddened that sufficient credit has not been given to either, one, the Government of Chile or, two, the people of Chile for the freely exercised vote, in which some 57 per cent of the population decided not to continue with the incumbent president beyond another 18 months, according to the 1980 Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: I have personally visited Chile in recent months. I have seen the trend towards democracy in that country. Quite frankly, I met with members of the Government and the Opposition, including the church. That Government and that country deserve the support of Australia rather than just our hungry dollars, given that Australia is the biggest foreign investor in Chile.

Why is it that this Government will not encourage and support the forces at work for democracy in that country, instead of using every opportunity to slander a government that organised the same free and democratic elections that have seen its President voted out of office?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a diatribe from the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) about the virtuous aspects of the Pinochet regime in Chile. Let the honourable member know that what the Pinochet regime has done in Chile has been an abuse of human rights, and this week is Human Rights Week-Amnesty International Week. Ask Amnesty International how it views the Chilean junta. Ask Amnesty International about the invasion and denial of human and civil rights in Chile. Ask Amnesty International how many people have been murdered under the Chilean regime.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to press reports that the British Government has initiated a review of Britain's military cooperation with Australia following union bans imposed on the Ark Royal and the Government's weak response to those bans. Can the Prime Minister tell the House whether the Government has ascertained the correctness or otherwise of those reports? Can the Prime Minister guarantee to the House that Royal Navy and other visiting naval vessels will be given complete freedom of access to and facilitated entry into other Australian ports, including the ports of Perth and Fremantle?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. I have not seen those reports. It may be that my Defence Minister has been made aware of them. Let me say this in general terms: During the recent visit to Australia of the British Prime Minister, Mrs Margaret Thatcher, we had the most useful discussions covering every conceivable aspect of the relationship between our two countries. I can say that I was very pleased to be informed, by Mrs Thatcher directly and then subsequently by our High Commissioner, that Mrs Thatcher had indicated that she believed that her visit to Australia was the best organised visit that she had had overseas during the period of her prime ministership.
—What has that to do with ships?
—Order!
—Mr Acting Speaker, I regard the question as a serious one. I am trying to give a serious answer and I hope that I will be allowed to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of Mrs Thatcher's visit and the very useful discussions that we had, I responded positively to her request that I should visit Britain in June of next year and take with me a number of my senior Ministers. I indicate that one of those Ministers will be the Minister for Defence. Mrs Thatcher has given instructions that those discussions are to be prepared with the greatest detail. She is committed to making those talks successful.

I give that background to indicate that I would be totally surprised if the attitude which was displayed and followed through by Mrs Thatcher would in any way be changed as a result of the action, which is repudiated by this Government, of a union in this country in regard to a visit by the British Royal Navy. But, in deference to the Leader of the Opposition, I will have the matter taken up to see whether there is any substance in the report. I indicate that I doubt it very much.

As to the final part of the Leader of the Opposition's question, both I and the Minister for Defence have made clear publicly, outside of this House and in this House, that we are taking steps to accelerate the acquisition by the Royal Australian Navy of those facilities which will ensure that, should there be in the future any refusal of facilities or services by seamen that could in any way preclude the proper berthing and servicing of ships in similar circumstances, the Royal Australian Navy will itself have the capacity to provide that service.

I conclude my answer by making the point that I made before. In the last three to four weeks more than 30 ships have been accommodated in 12 Australian ports. As I have said publicly and strongly, I regret that the attitude that was adopted in Melbourne did prevent the berthing of some ships there. To conclude the answer to the honourable gentleman's question, I understand that should the action of one union in question mean that the facilities that Fremantle can provide will not be available, action has been taken to ensure that facilities of the Australian defence forces will be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the advances made in achieving the Government's social justice objective, together with consequent benefits for the majority of Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cowan for her question. Very briefly, let me make the point that the Government is committed to the achievement of a fair and just society based on these principles: equity in the distribution of economic resources; equality of civil, legal and industrial rights; equal access to essential services such as health, education and housing; and the opportunity for participation by all in personal development, community life and decision-making.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's economic and social justice strategies are equal partners. This is nowhere more clearly apparent than in the area of job creation. I would remind the honourable member of the fact, of which she is no doubt well aware, that in the period since we have been in government we have been responsible for the creation of over 1,100,000 jobs, which is twice the rate of job creation of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average. May I say-without wanting to rub it in too much-that it is four times as fast a rate of job creation as existed under our predecessors. I remind the honourable member that there is nothing more useful that one can do in directing oneself to the question of poverty that we inherited in this country than creating jobs. We have done that better than has ever been done before.

But we have not been satisfied with that alone. We have taken historic steps to direct a battle against child poverty. For example, I would point out-and I think this is truly a remarkable statistic; it is one which should give pleasure to all members on both sides of the House-that payments through the Government's family allowance supplement will mean that by December of this year a low income family with three children will get a supplement which is worth more than a wage rise of $100 a week. This is truly an historic step.

I quickly refer to what has been done in the area of educational opportunities. The honourable member will be aware that we have done and achieved the following things: We have given assured real funding increases for recurrent purposes to both government and non-government schools. We have more than doubled the rate of the education allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds. We have boosted the year 12 retention rate from the miserably low 36 per cent that we inherited in 1982 to 57 per cent this year, which is a truly remarkable increase. I give this statistic, which perhaps the honourable member is not aware of, in regard to the creation of tertiary education places: In our period of government we have created 46,400 new tertiary education places. I ask the honourable member to compare the creation of 46,400 places with the 14,900 in a similar period when the Opposition was in government. That is, there are 211 per cent more places under this Government.

We have also provided the free and universal health cover, Medicare, which has removed the disastrous fact that two million Australians had no cover. We have increased the age pension in real terms by 8.3 per cent. That is the achievement of this Government-an increase of 8.3 per cent in real terms which compares with a 2.5 per cent real reduction in the real value of the pension in the period when the current Leader of the Opposition was Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Speaker. Two questions have been answered in 10 minutes. I ask you again whether you could please try to get Ministers not to make statements during Question Time.
—Order! I call the Prime Minister.

—I can understand that the Opposition does not want to hear the facts. May I say finally to the honourable member for Cowan-I know that this matter is of particular interest to her-that in terms of trying to ensure that we give women in this country a fair go, a fair chance and a fair opportunity, we have ensured the provision of another 30,000 child care places over the next four years. This will mean a trebling of the number of child care places in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Acting Speaker, I conclude by saying that in those statistics there is an indication that the combination of this Government's economic and social justice strategies have been and are working to create a fairer and more prosperous Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support. In October 1986, the Government announced that it proposed a panel to review regulatory changes affecting the aviation industry. Who is conducting this review and what has been done?
—Quick, Gary. What page is it on?
—Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber.
—There was an inquiry in the period mentioned by the honourable member for Richmond. I think he mentioned aviation charters-did you not? Is that what you said?
—No.
—Well, would you mind repeating the question?

—Mr Acting Speaker, from the top: In October 1986, the Government announced that it proposed a panel to review regulatory changes affecting the aviation industry. Who is conducting this review and what has been done?
—I do not have that information with me. I will get a response and get back to the honourable member.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister aware of remarks attributed to Mr Richard Butler concerning Australia's cooperation with the United States in the operation of joint facilities in Australia? I ask the Minister to inform the House of the Government's plans regarding the continued operation of the joint facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen those remarks attributed to Mr Richard Butler and I understand that, in fact, Mr Butler has indicated to us that his remarks are inaccurately reported. I might say that there is no intention by the Government to review or to run down joint facilities in this country. Those joint facilities, in the circumstances where arms control verification is required as arms control agreements are reached, become more and not less important.

ANSWER.PARA: As was indicated by the Prime Minister in this Parliament last year, there is a role being played by those joint facilities in the verification of the arms control agreements currently being achieved between the Soviet Union and the United States. Of course, some of those other facilities are not directly related to arms control agreements in the tasks they perform. North West Cape, for example, is a communication facility for ships but principally for submarines. In that particular instance, of course, arms control issues simply do not arise when the future of that station is considered. I might say, however, that that station is growing in importance to Australia. We are now in the situation where we utilise that facility for some 25 per cent of its time, which, when the relative sizes of the Australian submarine fleet and the US submarine fleet are considered, is a pretty fair indication that we indeed gain a great deal of utilisation out of that facility. As our submarines become the most significant striking arm of the Navy and as our submarines become more important to our own defence requirements overall, that joint facility becomes more and more important to this country.

So, as I said, there is no intention to run down those joint facilities in any way. It is a case of that particular joint facility's value increasing to Australia. In the case of the others, arms control agreements or otherwise do not alter the importance of the tasks they perform.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. I remind him that, in the first quarter of this year, the general government sector paid $648m of interest to foreign lenders compared with $590m for the same period last year. Nevertheless, the Treasurer claimed yesterday that the repayment of government debt was an important reason for the apparent improvement in total net income-that is, official and private payable overseas. I ask the Treasurer: How can the repayment of government debt be an important reason for a decline in total net income payable overseas when, for the nation as a whole, an increase in private foreign debt was required to finance the repayment of government foreign debt plus the current account deficit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, the indebtedness of Australia as a whole has, over the last year-I would need to check the number to be precise-if not declined certainly slowed in its growth, given the fact that the dollar, of course, has appreciated and that the balance of trade and the current account have improved. That being the case, there are, of course, naturally savings on the income and transfer system, as was revealed in the current account figures yesterday. That is in the low net income deficit which is recorded for September. That deficit reflected the seasonal low in non-official investment income payable abroad as well as, as I said yesterday, a decrease in official investment income payable abroad.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of that matter is that under this Government-I have made this point clear before and I will make it again and there is some reference to it in Budget Statement No. 2-the debt which we are aggregating is now higher than the debt we would otherwise aggregate for the current account condition. We are aggregating now higher levels of debt simply because we are now repatriating equity. We are delivering equity offshore to fund the growth of this constellation of companies and our private assets abroad. In the Budget analysis it will be seen that, in the 5 1/2 years since 1983, the growth of Australian assets abroad has gone from something like $5 billion to just on $37 billion, which stands in some respects in contrast and offsets the growth of our private debt abroad.

To the extent that when we had a current account deficit of about 2 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product through the 1970s, which was not aggregating any debt simply because it was funded by equity, we are now in fact acquiring more debt than we would otherwise need to acquire by virtue of the fact that we are exporting equity. In other words, the basic conditions have changed. We are not in the position we were in the 1970s when we were simply taking equity in satisfaction of our current accounting balance. We are now as well exporting equity and of course, therefore, the current account debt is higher by virtue of the value of that equity being exported. But that said simply makes the point that whatever is seen in the level of Australian indebtedness abroad today does not necessarily reflect absolutely and solely the current account condition. As the Government diminishes its own debt abroad, there is therefore a gain on the net income transfer and that gain was reflected in yesterday's current account figures, as I made clear yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware that unscrupulous insurance sales people are doing the rounds of pensioner and senior citizens groups and inveigling retired people into taking out insurance policies by alleging that the age pension will be reduced or phased out in the near future? What is the status of the age pension under a Labor government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, in recent weeks there have been a number of groups which have been peddling rumours that have no relationship to or any basis in fact whatever. The Government's commitment to the age pension is a strong and quite fundamental commitment. As the Prime Minister has indicated, we have sought to provide real increases in the age pension in the period that we have been in government. We have, of course, also made adjustments in the income test free area to increase the amount of income that aged persons might receive without loss of their pension. We are the government that has addressed the issues of fringe benefit limits and ensured that those limits are indexed so that, as people's incomes move, they still have access to extremely important fringe benefits that provide quite a significant part of the real income of so many aged pensioners. The Government is about to receive from Professor Cass a paper on retirement incomes policy. It will provide the Government with an opportunity to think long and to look to the future of our retirement system.

ANSWER.PARA: We have been facing the very difficult circumstances where the dependency ratios, particularly in the late 1970s and early 1980s-that is, the proportion of people who are dependent on social security payments-rose from 30 for every 100 people employed in the work force to 44 people at the time we came to government in 1983. That massive rise in the dependency ratio has meant that the social security budget has had to be spread across a much larger group of people. Notwithstanding the cost of supporting the unemployed and the increasing numbers of sole parents, notwithstanding the restraint that has been exercised in terms of wages in the community, we have delivered to aged people a real increase.

It is the intention of the Government, in framing its retirement income policy, to build on the very strong basis of the Australian pension system-one that is the envy of a number of other countries-and certainly not to diminish it in any way. At the same time it will ensure that we have a retirement income policy that will lead to much higher standards of living for aged people in the future than has been possible in the past. It will have to overcome the fact that we are dealing with an ageing population. We will move from something like 10 per cent of the population over the age of 65 to 16 per cent of the population by the year 2011. We are going to have to cope with that ageing population, but we will do that by recognising that we have a well targeted pension system, one that we believe can be built on to ensure that over a period we deliver to aged people in Australia, both in terms of the pension and in terms of the increased proportion of the population who will have access to superannuation, a retirement income system that I believe is now the envy of many countries but will be more so in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations tell the House how many containers presently remain uncleared at the ports of Sydney and Melbourne due to the current state of industrial chaos on the waterfront? What effect has this industrial strife, including the recent Customs dispute, had on the import figures and hence on yesterday's current account number? Has this number been distorted as a consequence of these delays?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I cannot give an answer in respect of the last point the honourable member raised. I do not think he seriously expects me to.
—Why not?

—It is part of his presentation. The honourable member and I know very well the reason he asked the question. In respect of the other items he raised, there have been a series of problems affecting the waterfront. There was the dispute in relation to the Australian Customs Service that originally began the delays. There have been subsequent disputes which have contributed to the delays and the build-up of the container backlog. Naturally, I am not able to give a figure on what number of containers are delayed, but we do have a great deal of concern about the interruption to our export and import services.
—What are you doing about it?
—We are doing what the Opposition did not do. On the waterfront, of all areas of activity the area that offers greater potential--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister will get back to the question he was asked by the honourable member for Ryan.

—I was addressing myself directly to the question, Mr Acting Speaker. I was asked about the delay in the movement of containers. Fundamentally, the question asked about the organisation of the waterfront, the organisation of the methods used on the waterfront, and those who are responsible. One of the problems on the waterfront that contribute to these kinds of difficulties is that there is no direct relationship between the people who pay for the containers to be moved and the people who move the containers. There is no direct relationship at all. That is a reflection on past practices in the industry. That is a reflection on previous governments, where everybody at the time--
—That line doesn't work any more, Peter. It did when you came in but not any more.
—Order! The Minister might bring his answer to a conclusion.

—I am doing that, Mr Acting Speaker. All the practices on the waterfront that have led to these kinds of disputes arising are the result of their not having been addressed in earlier years. The changes and the reform of the waterfront which are in progress and which have been instituted by this Government, through the activities of the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee but more recently the activities and report of the Inter-State Commission, should all help to create a much more efficient movement of those containers and make a major contribution to the improvement of our trade competitiveness.

ANSWER.PARA: It is much easier for people to grandstand on this issue than it is to address the really difficult structural and established problems that are inherent on the waterfront. This Government is doing that. We will continue to press ahead with the task. As the honourable member for Ryan would know, the direct responsibility in that area rests with my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy advise the House of recent movements in major agricultural commodity prices? Will he inform the House of the implications of these changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, which goes directly to many issues of debate today. The Opposition is saying that we will have big tax cuts now and that will increase living standards. At the same time it is saying we are doomed on the export front. The Australian newspaper even echoed that today, saying that some of the estimates on commodities are shonky. The Opposition is saying that we need big cuts in spending now but somehow that is not going to lower living standards.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me get this into some sort of perspective. What I am running on, as opposed to the Treasurer's estimates, is the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, which gave me four years of bad news. It is saying quite plainly that the relatively low commodity exports in July and August were quite consistent with the Bureau's forecasts. Rural sector exports are expected to increase sharply in the remaining three quarters of 1988-89. The value of commodity exports in 1988-89 may well exceed the Bureau's latest published forecast by around $750m, or another 2 per cent. That is why I have been saying that the Treasurer's forecasts are, if anything, at this stage, from my perspective as the Minister for commodities, conservative.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to have his job.

—I am just giving the facts. The Opposition is talking of doom and gloom and shonky estimates. What I am saying is what I am advised-that is, that there has been a strong upsurge in world agriculture commodity prices in recent months. In Australian dollar terms, even after allowing for the currency appreciation, prices since the 1986-87 slump have increased by 75 per cent for wool, 40 per cent for wheat, 25 per cent for dairy products and sugar, and 10 per cent for beef. Parenthetically I add that we are now starting to see increases coming through in the coal market-21 per cent on the steaming coal settlements recently and 9 per cent real. Those increases are the major reason for the more than doubling of the real net value of rural production over the last three years. As I have said, they validate the Budget forecast of a 9 per cent terms of trade improvement.

ANSWER.PARA: Another major reason for improved farm conditions is that farm cost inflation was only 4.5 per cent in 1987-88 due to an 8.6 per cent fall in interest paid and an increase in fuel prices of only 1.6 per cent. That was the lowest rate for 17 years and can be contrasted with an 11 per cent increase in farm cost inflation in the last days of the Fraser-Howard Government. So the Government's policies are bettering the farm sector. I should mention-I am not one of those boom-bust men who say, `That is always the way it is'-that the farmers themselves have changed their product mix and improved their efficiency.

As the Treasurer and all Government members freely acknowledge, this improvement in rural conditions is of great benefit to the economy as a whole, but it only accrues over time. In particular, there is a lag between the time commodity prices improve and the time farmers get the money, and then there is a further lag before tax is paid on it. For example, wheat growers are seeing some of the improvement in world wheat prices only in their first advance for the current season. The full benefit will be contained in the first subsequent payments for the 1987-88 crop early next year, and in advances in subsequent years as earlier low prices wash out of the averaging formula. Similarly, the Australian Wool Corporation has large financial reserves arising from the sale of its stockpile over the last two years.

Both the provisional tax system itself and the effect of tax averaging will delay the revenue effect of the commodity price increases until next year. Of course, such niceties never worry the Opposition. It is interested in cheap propaganda-doom and gloom, boom and bust-about tax cuts without caring about economic responsibility, as this Government does.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Acting Minister for Community Services and Health by saying that in Australia there are regions that have a high incidence of arbovirus or mosquito-borne diseases. These diseases include encephalitis, Ross River fever and other diseases, some of which are still to be identified. Given this situation, will the Minister give this House and the people of the Murrumbidgee and Coleambally irrigation areas a guarantee that the mosquito eradication and research program initiated after the 1974 Australian encephalitis epidemic will continue to receive adequate funding from the Federal Government to allow this crucial research program to continue, particularly in those irrigation areas I have mentioned?

—I thank the honourable member for Riverina-Darling for his question. As Acting Minister, not having full carriage of this area, I will ensure that when Dr Blewett returns this question is addressed by him and, before that, by his Department.
—Can the Treasurer inform the House of the progress that Australia is making in restructuring our economy and overcoming our trade imbalance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was obviously a question which the Opposition should have asked yesterday, but did not do so because it does not like the answers given by those on this side of the House, particularly on matters of substance. Yesterday it engaged in an attack on you, Mr Acting Speaker, instead of asking questions about the current account imbalance or any matter relating to the fundamentals. Yesterday's current account figure shows that the progress the Government is making in terms of its strategy of changing the structure of the Australian economy is very much on track. Yesterday's current account figure was down $337m from last month and down $1,228m from the same month last year.

ANSWER.PARA: The fundamentals show that imports were down and that there is scope for further improvements in export earnings coming off higher volumes. I refer briefly to the answer just given by my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in relation to commodity prices, commodity exports and commodity volumes, and make the point that while we had a couple of high figures in the current account in the early part of the year, this is the part of the year when figures are prone to be higher than at other times, particularly as we have now run down agricultural stocks. As a result of a pretty good season we may see that product going to export markets and, given the prices which prevail at the moment, a decline in the deficit; that is, a pickup in our export figures over the balance of the year-so much so that it is entirely possible that the current account forecast in the Budget could be realised, which was the point made by my colleague. I said yesterday that it is getting harder to realise that projection with the two high numbers in the first two months of the year, but it is not out of the question that, with these lower numbers and higher export volumes, it could be done.

The main point is that this is part of the continuing structural change. A great deal of the progress which we are making now is built around good commodity prices and good export prices. Competitiveness is still there; we are still highly competitive. The general competitiveness of the economy is being maintained by a real depreciation of the exchange rate and a decline in our inflation rate, coming from the Government's wages policy. As the Budget indicated, the investment is there, pumping the supply capacity of the economy along. With 10 per cent real growth in investment last year and 12 per cent real factored in for this year, the supply side response that will effect such a transition on the current account and the balance of payments is there.

While we might have had some higher figures than we would have either expected or wanted in the earlier part of the year, the fact is that the structural transition is there, which was the essence and point of my colleague's question. Progress is being made and it is built on these fundamentals-good commodity prices, strong competitiveness and a strong investment response, which we are seeing coming off a particularly big decline in public sector demands on financial markets and Australian savings; in other words, a strategy which is working to change the balance of Australia's industrial production, its current account deficit and hence its indebtedness. That is what people on the other side of the House thought they could not do and did not need to do. They simply relied upon commodity prices and did not worry about selling intellectual product, selling a restructured Australian economy or seeing a better balance in its secondary and tertiary sectors to offset the dependence on the primary exports sector.

It has fallen, as usual, to a Labor government to pick up the ball and run with it and make the changes which were left for nearly 40 years by lazy, indolent coalition governments. Here we are now a fair way through the current Parliament still with no structure in policy from the Opposition. There is still no indication of a fiscal policy-a basic thing like a fiscal and tax policy-no clarity about wages policy and, therefore, no structure about how the continuing necessary transition of Australia would be undertaken by a coalition government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order concerning relevance. Mr Acting Speaker, I thank you for the wonderful show we have had today. We have actually heard some answers. The Treasurer is now--
—Order! The honourable member will get to his point of order.
—My point of order is that the Treasurer is now breaking the golden rule. He has given us the information. He now wishes to make a historical attack. If he wants to do that, we are back to yesterday.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The point is that you can ask him to bring his answer to a conclusion.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Honourable members opposite have a quaint understanding of the Standing Orders. They think that the only answer is the one they like; otherwise all other answers are out of order. Is that the proposition?
—Order! The Treasurer will answer the question and not respond to interjections.

—The fact of the matter is that we have an important and an entirely fundamental transition taking place in the Australian economy which the numbers reveal month by month, including yesterday's. That is being delivered only through a coherent economic policy structure, a structure which belongs to this side of the Parliament alone. There is no such structure on the other side of the House. Not to have such a structure means that honourable members opposite could not go to the Australian public at an election proposing anything which resembles something which would change the Australian economy to remove our dependence upon commodities, to get off the large current account imbalances and reduce our overseas indebtedness.

—I ask the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support whether it is a fact that the Government signed off the new Brisbane Airport terminal prior to its opening earlier this year, thus negating responsibility by contractors to guarantee their work. Is the Minister aware of major security risks now involved with the terminal? What is the Government doing to solve the scandal, as the Federal Airports Corporation seems not to be accepting any responsibility?

—Brisbane Airport is under the auspices of the Federal Airports Corporation. The matters raised by the honourable member quite properly are in the Corporation's domain. I am quite aware that there are a number of problems with Brisbane Airport-first of all, the terminal; secondly, the noise problem-all of which have to be addressed. In terms of security, in recent times there has been a full-scale attempt to upgrade security around airports in Australia, relating not only to perimeters but to internal areas as well. The honourable member's question about the problem of security at Brisbane Airport is one that I will refer to the Federal Airports Corporation as the body concerned.

—My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask: Is the Minister aware of reports suggesting the possibility of Australia Post being privatised? Can the Minister advise the House of the correctness of these reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a report in the Canberra Times yesterday in which it was stated that the Chairman of Australia Post, Mr Lansdown, had said that privatisation of Australia Post was an option. In fact, Mr Lansdown assured me that he said no such thing in his address to the seminar and nor did he say anything of the kind in the discussion that followed. His speaking notes indicate that he spoke generally in support of the Government business enterprise reform packages as they apply to Australia Post, although he did say that he thought there were some ways in which the package could be taken further. He instanced things such as auditing arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: I assure the House that the Government has no intention whatever of privatising Australia Post. That statement has been made clearly by my predecessor in his portfolio as well as by the Prime Minister. What we are doing, of course, through the Government business enterprise reform package is making Australia Post, along with all other Government business enterprises, much more dynamic organisations and much more efficient organisations through providing for those bodies to be incorporated and for other various steps to be taken which will ensure that they operate in a more businesslike fashion.

In the case of Australia Post, of course, we have to bear in mind that it performs not only a business undertaking but also very important social obligations, especially the obligation to provide a universal service at a universal price. Of course, that requires it to do things which a fully commercial organisation simply would not do. If we had a fully commercial Australia Post, we would certainly not get a lot of the services we currently get-or, at least, we would get them at a much higher price.

What we are doing with Australia Post and the other Government business enterprises is incorporating them. Where there are community service obligations involved, where there is, as I have mentioned, the kind of social obligations of Australia Post, we will be taking those into account in setting the financial targets for these organisations so that we will have full accounting for their community service obligations. They will have a paid up capital structure. They will be required to establish a corporate plan and financial targets. They will provide a dividend to the Government. They will be subject to normal business taxes and charges and, in most respects, will operate in a fully commercial way.

What we are seeing with Australia Post is a very substantial development to make this already quite efficient organisation, which has earned profits in every one of its last 12 years except one-which marks it out uniquely in the world as a post office which actually makes profits-even more efficient with the Government business reform package in the legislation before the House now, and the second element, which will come through next year, will bring about a much more dynamic organisation.
