DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The threat that the precarious balance of payments and huge foreign debt pose for living standards in Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have proposed this matter for discussion for the obvious reason that yesterday, with the publication of the current account figures, we saw that the current account deficit for September brings the deficit for the first quarter of 1988-89 to $3.8 billion compared to $3.4 billion in the same quarter last year. We heard two very interesting answers from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Question Time today. In one answer, in response to a question I asked, he absolutely confused the nature of the question. The second, which was in answer to a dorothy dixer from his own side, was a repetition of allegations made yesterday at the press conference, which are simply unfounded. I went through the transcript and, on the first reading, found five, and I am assured there is a sixth. Yet the Treasurer came in here today and stood before us as bold as brass and said that there is an improvement in the current account deficit. Quarter by quarter, this is not so. This year it is $3.8 billion and last year it was $3.4 billion. Yesterday's figures means that we have added nearly $1 billion to our foreign debt. Of course, official capital outflow was over $1 billion, but a private capital inflow of nearly $5 billion was required to finance the current account deficit, plus the Treasurer's debt repayments. This puts into perspective the spectacle of the Treasurer paying off a bit here and a bit there while travelling the world paying off a bit of debt. He neglected to mention any of this yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that as I read the transcript there seemed to me to exude through that press conference a complacency which does not serve Australia well. I know what he is referring to when he refers to the triple somersaults with pike. That is not a bad illustration because he performs in that manner. But I would have thought that for a government that is doing more somersaults over taxation than any government I have ever seen, it was not the most apt description at present, with or without the pike. The bottom line is that the Australian economy is extremely vulnerable in the world economy. In the 13 or 14 months I have been in this shadow portfolio, I have constantly used the theme of the need to speed the pace of adjustment because of that vulnerability. The pace of adjustment to our huge foreign debt is already slow. The reality that it is already slow is shown by three examples which I will cite. Perhaps the Treasurer would be good enough to listen to them and address them and tell us whether he agrees with them.

When I say that the pace of adjustment in the face of our huge foreign debt is already slow, it is shown by: fact No. 1, that net exports are projected to make yet again a negative contribution to the gross domestic product in this financial year; fact No. 2, that imports of capital goods, as a share of total imports, fell again in 1987-88; and fact No. 3, that investment in the mining and manufacturing sectors is expected to show little, if any, real growth in 1988-89. It would be helpful to the House, in terms of the pace of adjustment, for the Treasurer to address those three crucial factors.

I do know from reading the press release yesterday-and it was interesting to note-that there has been a change in the labelling or the rhetoric that the Treasurer uses on the capital goods point. He no longer talks about `capital goods' as imports, but rather `producer equipment imports'. A mere change of labelling by the Government does not disguise the fact that imports of investment goods, as a share of total imports, fell again in 1987-88. No wonder Moody's Investor Services Inc. continues to refuse to restore Australia's AAA international credit rating. In fact, according to Moody's, `nothing has really altered' its thinking since it downgraded our credit rating in 1986. In other words, despite the statements of the Treasurer, Moody's has said that the Government's rhetoric is no indication of change and indeed is no substitute for sound economic policies.

Despite the undeniable vulnerability of the Australian economy, the Budget strategy is based on continued strength and commodity prices. I listened with interest to the Treasurer's colleague today trying to talk up the question of commodity prices. We in this House do not know whether those commodity prices will rise or fall as that is outside the Government's control. We also do not know, because it is also outside the Government's control, whether there will be significant economic policy changes-I cite the United States of America alone, with the transition that will occur shortly-in a major economy in the Western world. What is not out of our control is our capacity to get our own house in order, for example, to address fiscal policy. Senator Walsh, in his now oft used post-Budget addresses, has indicated this is a prime concern to be addressed.

When we talk about vulnerability, it is not rhetoric from this side. The riskiness, the reliance on factors that are outside our control, is in fact highlighted by available indices. The riskiness of the strategy is certainly highlighted. Notwithstanding what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) says, the International Monetary Fund says in its forecasts that 1989 will see an easing of commodity prices due to slower world economic growth. The recent decline in the commodity price index of the State Bank of Victoria, which has fallen 12 per cent in United States dollar terms since 10 June, hardly augurs well for Australia. But the nub of it is the riskiness and the vulnerability for this economy caused by the Government relying on factors totally out of its control when it could be addressing factors over which it has purchase and leverage to put us in a sounder position to weather any storm should the economy, either for cyclical reasons because of a downturn in commodity prices or because of changes in the presidency of the United States, be affected.

It is against that background that the Treasurer still plans, as he said yesterday, to give tax cuts but in the absence of substantial cuts in government expenditure. Indeed, the Treasurer made it clear recently that the tax cuts would be funded from the Budget surplus. The irresponsibility of this is absolutely clear. Without offsetting reductions in government outlays, the Government cannot possibly provide the proposed tax cuts without blowing out the balance of payments even further. We call for the tax cuts, but funded primarily by cuts in government expenditure. Senator Walsh has again endorsed this approach, or at least he hinted at it last Sunday week. Meanwhile, other Ministers are tying themselves in knots through their gyrations over the wage-tax trade-off, and we have been subjected to some remarkable contradictions and vacillations about those tax cuts.

Only a few weeks ago they were to be, in the words of a man of great influence to the Treasurer, Mr Kelty, the `biggest tax cuts in the history of this country . . . We're after nothing less'. Then the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) said it was `inevitable' that there will be tax cuts from 1 July. But four or five days later he said they will be conditional on the state of the economy. I asked him about this yesterday, as, to me, these statements were mutually exclusive. If it is inevitable, it is just that. If it is conditional on the state of the economy, the inevitability is somewhat circumscribed. Yet he confirmed the validity of both statements. When we talk in terms of gyrations and somersaults and confusion, they are coming every day from the mouths of Ministers.

We have said in the House before that Australians deserve better than this. They have illustrated in the by-elections in Adelaide, in Port Adelaide and in Oxley that they do not believe-they may not articulate it this way-that this Treasurer is executing the two basic duties of his job. What are they? Those two duties are: to increase the living standards of the people in this country and, secondly, to manage a growing and adequate economy competently. During the period that the Treasurer has been in office, living standards for the majority of the population have fallen; unemployment is almost 8 per cent, that is, more than double the average rate under the Whitlam Government and well above the average for the Fraser years; inflation is stubbornly high, with little prospect of a serious reduction; investment is low; foreign debt is out of control-it has quadrupled in the period of the Government-and for middle and low income earners life is certainly meaner and the focus narrow. Those last few words I quoted from a journal which I was going to use but will not go on with. It illustrates why Australians are protesting and why they will not cop the claim the Treasurer made just the other day when launching his book that his life had been `dedicated to the interests of Australians of basically low to middle incomes'. It is precisely those people who are suffering today.

I said that the Treasurer has fundamentally two duties: to leave a healthy and resilient macro-economy, and to improve the living standards of Australians. The reality is that the Government has failed to do this. The truth of the matter is that responsible economic policies can strengthen our balance of payments position and improve living standards at the same time. That is not magic. One does not have to be Mandrake. It is simply responsible economic management which will achieve this. There are two ways to achieve sustainable improvements in living standards: first, with tax cuts funded by reductions in government spending and, of course, secondly, improved productivity. The coalition can do both. The first, reductions in government outlays, releases resources of both labour and capital to the private sector, including export and import competing industries. Tax cuts, as I have said time and again, increase disposable income and improve the incentives to work and to invest. The cuts in government spending curb the growth in public sector demand, permitting a rise in private sector demand without risking a further blowout in imports.

Again, our industrial relations policy addresses the second issue, productivity. Productivity can be improved through more flexible and decentralised labour markets through privatisation and genuine micro-economic reform. Micro-economic reform-remember that? It was to be the hallmark of the third Hawke Government. It is gone. The Government has again failed on those fronts. There has been a lot of talk of reviews, of committees, of inquiries and so on, but there has been hardly any action at all. The Treasurer has clearly failed in his twin obligation to strengthen the economy and to improve living standards. This matter of public importance is brought before the House today to rip asunder the facade that was sought to be presented yesterday by the Government with the figure that was produced. This is worse than the first quarter of last year. A $9.5 billion projection was put forward in the Budget. We have achieved 40 per cent of that in 25 per cent of the time. Some improvement! I hate to see what the hell would be happening if we were allegedly going backwards. The reality is that underlying all of this there is grievous vulnerability, not just in the short term for those who might like to make some commentaries on this issue, but also for our country. One is either interested in ensuring that Australia is in a secure position should there be any downturn, or one is not. After the Government talked up its stuff yesterday it failed miserably on the test of ensuring that Australia can weather the storm should there be any downturn in the coming year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), employed all the skills of a seasoned parliamentarian-someone who has been around in public life, both in and out of parliament-that is, the easy resort to the interpolative interpolations, the sentences and juxtapositions such as `I have said often' and `I repeat the point' as he read the text in front of him, written of course by someone else. No amount of oily slickness on the floor of the House will conceal the point that the shadow Treasurer does not understand the structure of economic policy or the economic policy ramifications of what he is saying--
—I ask the Treasurer to hold on a minute. I say to the honourable members on the left that the Chair will not tolerate interjections--
—It is not a kindergarten.
—The honourable member for Menzies will heed the Chair. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition was heard in silence. I expected that courtesy to be extended to the Treasurer.
—Who interjected?

—The honourable member for O'Connor has interjected twice. The honourable member for Menzies will assist the Chair by remaining silent. I say to the honourable members on my left that the Chair will not tolerate interjections.

—The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) goaded the honourable member for Kooyong into accepting the shadow Treasury job, which he did, to preserve his own position within the coalition parties. The honourable member for Kooyong then went through a sort of pro forma set of statements and words about what Opposition policy ought to be. But when it comes to the point there is no understanding, no comprehension, no structure, and no detail. In other words, there are no ideas. We know that, the whole of the Opposition knows that, and, of course, all the onlookers including the press gallery know that. We had this diatribe about the Australian economy being vulnerable and the pace of adjustment. The coalition is arguing that we ought to be adjusting faster. That means that fiscal policy ought to be tighter; monetary policy ought to be tighter, as indeed the shadow Treasurer is now arguing these days; interest rates ought to be higher; and wages ought to be lower.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the argument from the other side of the House. That is what honourable members opposite call the pace of adjustment. We, on this side of the House, know that they would not have the guts to do any one of those things. They never did when they were in office. They had no structure and no courage. It fell to a Labor government to remove the big structural imbalances, to turn the Budget deficit to a surplus. It fell to a Labor government to repair the profit share in gross domestic product, to restore investment and employment. It always fell to a Labor government to make these adjustments. Yet we have these glib words about the pace of adjustment around policies that they would never-not now, not in the past, and not in the future-have the courage or the wit to implement. We have this sort of arid recital of what we need to do and what is required of us when they have no structure at all. We are almost a couple of years-18 months or more-into this Parliament. I have some quotes on tax policy which goes to fiscal policy from the Leader of the Opposition, who said:
I have said all along that the timetable for the policy release by August is going to be adhered to.
August was months ago. He said that in February this year. In April Mr Peacock said:
Well, I think that if you contain your enthusiasm you will see a tax policy before the end of the year.
Again in April he said:
We will be announcing a tax policy later in the year.

They do not have a clue. As they do not have a tax policy, they do not have a fiscal policy. They are a bunch of hapless professional parliamentarians picking up their 48 grand a year-or whatever it is-and getting their travel entitlements, here there and wherever it takes their fancy, and getting a ride to Sydney or Melbourne. But on essential matters they do not have a clue what to do with Australia.

The shadow Treasurer mentioned exports. He said that there will be a negative contribution to growth from net exports this year. One of the reasons why that is so is that we are being deluged with income this year from a lift in the terms of trade. If one gets more income-that is, higher wheat prices, higher wool prices, greater volumes for wheat, and higher prices for commodities-one cannot say, `Oh no, we won't have this income. This is shocking. Someone wants to pay us more. No, we won't have it. We don't want this income because what we want is to protect the next export position, so we'll knock the income back'. The fact is that, if there is a surge of income, we end up with more spending and more demand and that tends to blot out net exports. But that same net income is cutting the current account deficit, which is what the net exports are about in the first place. It is a bit puerile for honourable members opposite to be saying `Oh, this is shocking; we have got a negative contribution from net exports', when they really do not know what it means. What it means is that net exports will reduce the current account deficit, but that is otherwise reduced by a lift in the terms of trade, the very thing which is blotting out the net exports. Those opposite should not make stupid points.

The second point about net exports is that if the terms of trade were to go off somewhat-and that seems unlikely at the moment-the strong supply side response going into investment would keep the net exports coming through. In other words, we would still be competitive. We are still seeing high levels of investment in the whole trade and goods sector of the economy, in tourism and what have you. That will push net exports through if demand is held in check. That is what the Government is doing-cutting public demand by cutting the Budget imbalance and keeping a decent wage and monetary policy in place. That is the role of that structural change on net exports. But honourable members opposite do not have that degree of comprehension because they do not understand the concepts. They just do not understand what they are saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —Professor Hewson will tell you all about that in a minute.

—We know all about Professor Hewson. He and Mr Howard ruined a nice middle-sized Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) economy in five years and now honourable members opposite, as a party, are inviting the two of them back to try to do it again-the John and John show. We had that for five or six years in the late 1970s and early 1980s and those opposite took a place with a terms of trade lift-that is, with higher coal and oil prices-and put it into a massive recession. Those opposite should not tell us about any professional skills on their side. Australia can do without them.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kooyong, the shadow Treasurer, talked about imports of capital goods. He said in a great stentorian voice that this month's figures show that machinery and transport fell again. Yes, they did fall again. After we abstract motor vehicles and aircraft, they fell by a modest 2 per cent. But what does the trend show? It shows investment in the whole trade and goods sector in the economy. It shows strong plant and equipment imports and machinery imports-that is what it shows. A large part of these imports is plant and equipment-producer goods, the very things which will produce more import replacement and exporting products; in other words, the very stuff of which an economic transition is made, of which a transformation is made. That is happening now, coming in with those imports.

The honourable member for Kooyong referred to one month's figures and said, `That game is in trouble'. He did not make any reference to the hotels going up at a rate of knots, the tourism deficits turning around at a rate of knots and all the other elements of the supply response and the response to competitiveness on real depreciation and economic policy. He has no comprehension of that. That is why the facts murder his point. The current account deficit peaked at 6 per cent of gross domestic product in 1985-86. It went to 5 per cent in 1986-87 and 4 per cent in 1987-88. This year we have forecast it to be substantially lower again. In other words, we will have halved the current account imbalance. But the Deputy Leader of the Opposition says, `Oh no, we are not going fast enough'. We have actually picked up the horrible mess that was left by 40 years of total dependence on commodities. When they fell apart there was a greater exposure on debt. We have actually got the place fixed up; we have reduced the size of the Australian public sector by 10 percentage points; we have turned a massive Budget imbalance into a surplus by cuts in government outlays; we have fixed the wage-profit share in the economy; we have fixed the competitiveness of the economy; and we have cut the current account deficit in half. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition says, `Oh no, that is not good enough. You have got to be like us'. The `us' refers to those who gave this Government the debt exposure, the rickety industrial structure and the wage mayhem. Those opposite are unbelievable.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to Moody's Investor Services Inc. If he wants to look at the people who punt, the people who buy and sell Australian stocks and bonds, he should just go and look at the markets-he should not worry about Moody's-and see what they say. They are not worried about what Moody's says; if they were they would not be making any money. He then talked about the people who buy and sell Australian stocks and bonds.

TALK.START.PARA: —You did say the punters?
—The international punters, that is right; that is, the people who fund the current account imbalance.
—I just wanted to know.

—The honourable member thinks of punters as people on a racetrack. We actually fund a current account imbalance of the order of, in recent times, $10 billion to $11 billion by people who buy and invest in Australian stocks and bonds and who do not particularly wake up every morning and worry about what Moody's has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member then went on to say that there should be no tax cuts without offsetting cuts in government expenditure. Those opposite do not know what they want to say about fiscal policy. The shadow finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), said the other day that members of the Opposition preferred to keep the surplus and provide any tax cuts from cuts in government outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—`That is right', says the honourable member for O'Connor. Nothing specific has been said about where these cuts would be or what their orders of magnitude would be. We are nearly two years into another Parliament. Those opposite are a bunch of intellectual layabouts. They will not do the work. They have no policy. They are up at Question Time taking points of order on relevance-phoney points of order. I have seen these phases come and go so many times in the 20 years that I have been here. Those in the community could not care less. Out there in the big economy where it really matters the people who would naturally support those opposite think they are basically lemons. They will not have those opposite on again. They are going to keep on thinking honourable members opposite are lemons because basically they are right. Those opposite do not have any structure or any policy detail. A little bit of pouncing around here about points of order, about the Standing Orders, and driving the Speaker mad is supposed to take the place of decent, reasoned economic debate and having some structure. Members of the Opposition ought to get used to the comfort on that side of the House because they are going to be there for a while.

SPEECH.PARA: I have the task of increasing living standards. Let me make a couple of points. Since 1983-84, per capita household disposable income in Australia has risen in each year except 1986-87. The cumulative change over the years 1983-84 to 1987-88 has been 4.4 per cent. Household disposable income has risen despite falls in average earnings in each year except 1984-85 because employment growth has been so robust; in other words, there have been so many more incomes in the one household. In rebalancing the wage-profit share, declines in average earnings have made way for the strongest employment growth in the OECD. The point is that there are simply more people in jobs. Household disposable income is higher, notwithstanding a cut in real wages. That is why members of the community did not vote for those opposite in the last election. They are not silly; they understand these points. People know if they have more income coming into the one house.

I do the right thing by coming in here and trying to answer the points which the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raises, but they are just an arid, empty recital of cheap political points laced with some economic language, pieced together by a less than enthusiastic staff and put up by coalition parties-an Opposition-which do not have a clue about economic policy formulation. Those opposite do not have the courage or the guts to do the things that need to be done and they do not even have the decency at least to acknowledge the things the Government has done. We have cut the size of the public sector and rebalanced the Australian economy, and those opposite do not even have the decency to acknowledge what we have done on picking up the mess of their 30-odd years in office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the new boy in this place, having listened to the world's greatest Treasurer (Mr Keating), I guess I am supposed to stand over here and shake in my boots and thank him very much for what has been a wonderful lesson in fundamental economics. But the facts are that all he has done is what he usually does, which is to come into this place and prattle on and carry on a treat, throwing basically historical anecdotes at the Opposition, making accusations that are totally unfounded, and really not dealing terribly much with the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me pick up two or three things that he has said. I have only 10 minutes and I will be as brief as I can. The first comment was in relation to net exports. He attacked my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), about what he said on net exports. The Treasurer said something like, `Don't worry, boy. Don't make stupid points'. It is interesting to draw the Treasurer's attention to the words on this subject of one of his principal advisers, the Reserve Bank of Australia, when he talks about making stupid points. I would refer the Treasurer to what it said in its annual report, released about the time of the last Budget. It stated:

The higher commodity prices should be regarded as a windfall which provides the opportunity to reduce markedly the balance of payments deficit. It would be tragic if they were absorbed in an overly rapid increase in domestic demand, with the pressures that would unleash, or if we were to be deflected from the long-term task of adjusting the structure of the economy.

However, it is disappointing in that context that Australia's high economic growth in the year just closed largely reflected strong domestic demand with no further gains in volume terms in net exports.

I put it to the Treasurer that one of his principal advisers, the Reserve Bank, totally disagrees with him, as does Senator Walsh, who has mentioned that he believes the pace of economic change is disappointingly slow; indeed the suggestion is that micro-economic reform has stalled. The reason that net exports are not playing a significant part at the present time is that the Treasurer overheated the Australian economy and forced down interest rates last year prematurely on the back of a commodity price explosion. This Treasurer, who is now walking out, probably off to the opera or somewhere else, overheated the economy and created the difficult economic circumstances we are in at present. He, more than anyone else, is directly responsible for the current state of our balance of payments from the domestic demand point of view.

The second point I would like to take the Treasurer up on is what he said fairly loosely when he mentioned in passing that I am apparently interested in increasing interest rates. I am not interested in increasing interest rates. I have been saying that interest rates are on an upward course under this Government and this Hawke Government has shown a great capacity to play politics with interest rates over its life in government. I particularly remind the Treasurer of the 1984 experience, but let us just look at the current experience to which the Treasurer has drawn attention.

Before focusing on what has happened in the past few weeks in relation to official interest rates, we should remind ourselves of a couple of quotes and performances of the Treasurer when it comes to speaking openly in this House on interest rates. He never tells the truth and never comes up front and says that interest rates are going up. He never admits, at the time, that monetary policy is being tightened. Only down the track does the honourable gentleman begrudgingly admit to any of that. At the time he is never prepared to say what is happening. For example, on 20 April, in his Press conference in response to the March balance of payments release, the Treasurer was asked an explicit question, `Will you tighten monetary policy?' and he gave an emphatic `No'. As I pointed out in the press release of about the same time, 21 April, the Reserve Bank had already begun to tighten monetary policy by increasing cash rates, probably from the end of March but certainly from the middle of April. However, by 30 May the Treasurer had changed his mind and finally he admitted that monetary policy has been tightened. I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 30 May:
We have tightened monetary policy but as I said on Friday, we are not tightening it any further.

Against that background, it is interesting to look at what is happening at present in regard to monetary policy and interest rates. The Treasurer has been creating the impression in recent days, including in his press conference yesterday, that he is not tightening monetary policy and that he is not putting up interest rates, but if one looks at what has happened to both official and unofficial cash rates in the last few days and, as it happens, since the Oxley by-election one finds that there has been a sizeable increase across the board in cash interest rates, be they official or unofficial.

Through September and into the pre-Oxley days of October the official cash rate averaged about 12.84 per cent. Since the Oxley by-election it has averaged about 13.38 per cent, about 0.5 per cent up. It is a tightening up of monetary policy and tightening up another notch. Unofficial cash rates averaged a little over 13 per cent in the pre-Oxley period from the beginning of September, but since the Oxley by-election they have been increased to 13.5 per cent. Will the Treasurer come clean on that sort of development? Is he authorising the Reserve Bank to tighten monetary policy? Has he instructed it to do so? He is not yet prepared to admit it. It is difficult to know. The honourable gentleman has not yet come out and said in any explicit way what he is on about. The closest we got was a question put to him yesterday during his press conference when it was pointed out to him that cash interest rates had risen over the last couple of days, and that some in the market see that as a slight tightening of policy. He said:

Cash rates can do all sorts of things without that implying that there is any official tightening happening. There is no further discreet tightening on the Government's part. We had a lift in rates after the second big balance of payments number, that's a month ago. And well, the market made that judgment, that's fine, we're happy with that.

What is actually happening? Is the Treasurer prepared to admit that interest rates have been tightening officially or not? Clearly official interest rates, to which I have been drawing attention, the ones the Reserve Bank often admits in its publications are the key indicator of monetary policy, have been tightened significantly since the Oxley by-election. The exact quote that I picked there is really quite misleading. The Treasurer tried to date the rise from 28 September, when the last balance of payments number was released, but the fact is that the rises in interest rates started, surprisingly, on the Monday morning immediately after the Oxley by-election and have been sustained ever since.

The third point which the Treasurer made in his remarks, on which I will briefly comment, relates to the idea of tax cuts and the use of the Budget surplus. I would be fascinated to know exactly what the Treasurer has in mind when it comes to next year's Budget surplus. Senator Walsh has been very helpful in this, unlike in some other areas in recent days, namely in his personal attacks on me. He has been particularly helpful in relation to the Budget surplus for next year. Senator Walsh has said that it could well be $9 billion or even $10 billion next year and that the bulk of that could well be spent in the form of tax cuts. How much? He said that something has to be kept in the surplus. His suggestion is that `at least $1 billion' ought to stay in the surplus-so some $7, $8 or $9 billion, depending on which projected number comes in, will be spent on tax cuts. If he is right in those numbers, that is about the same size tax cut in today's dollars as we received last time. So much for `the greatest tax cut in history'. It will be a miserable tax cut for the average Australian.

Today we have seen a clear demonstration of just how out of touch this Treasurer is in current economic debate in Australia and how arrogant he is in that when he comes into the House he is not prepared to do any more than just prattle on and make some loose attacks on the Opposition. He is not interested in genuine economic debate. Indeed, when somebody tries to make some substantive economic points, the Treasurer turns his back and walks out, rather than address the fundamental issues that are of significance to the average Australian. He cannot deny the fact that under this Government the standard of living of the average Australian has fallen dramatically. The Opposition has put a figure of $56 a week as the extent to which that standard of living has fallen and, although the Government attacks the Opposition for saying this, the Government never denies that it is $56 a week. The Opposition could make the number higher and include housing costs, which would add about another $14 a week to the bills of the average Australian, and yet the Treasurer has the hide to come into this House and act as arrogantly as he has done in this debate, failing to address any of the very serious and substantive arguments put by my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he understand them?

—My guess is that he does not have any understanding at all. He learns his lines, he has his staff sitting in the House, he comes in here, stumbles over a few words, throws a bit of abuse and sits down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most useful ways of seeing the inherent absurdity and inherent contradictions in the economic policies put forward by the Opposition is to juxtapose the matter of public importance submitted yesterday by the shadow finance spokesman, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who has just spoken and the matter that has been put forward today by the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Yesterday's matter of public importance from the shadow finance spokesman referred to:

SPEECH.PARA: The threat of higher interest rates and their adverse effect on living standards as a consequence of the economic mismanagement of the Hawke Government.

In other words, yesterday the Opposition raised the living standards issue, and claimed to be concerned about it and said that its policy mix would produce a better result for living standards. Today the terms of the matter of public importance read:
The threat that the precarious balance of payments and huge foreign debt pose for living standards in Australia.

The implication is-and this is the thrust of the speeches we have just heard from the shadow Treasurer and the shadow finance spokesman-that the Opposition would in fact advocate and prosecute a more rapid pace of adjustment. It is fairly obvious that those two propositions are incompatible, particularly in the context of the overall economic policy mix, such as it is and such as it can be discerned, that the Opposition has put forward.

Today's proposition implicitly argues for a more rapid pace of adjustment to correct our external balance problems and to reduce our external debt. The interesting question to pose is: What exactly would the Opposition do differently? In what way would its policies differ from those of the current Government? There are three possibilities here. The first obviously goes to fiscal policy. Today we heard the shadow Treasurer say that if he were Treasurer he would in effect run a tighter fiscal policy and he would constrain spending more than it is already constrained. The implication is that it would then be fiscally responsible to give tax cuts because by doing so one would be counterbalancing the impact of tax cuts on domestic demand by corresponding cuts in government expenditure. That is the argument that is put forward. But is that a credible claim? I submit to the House that it is not. It is an absurdity for that particular individual and for that particular Party to come in here and put forward that sort of proposition.

What we have had since the current Government took office is perhaps the most substantial turnaround in fiscal policy engineered in any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country. We were left with a very substantial deficit. That was the legacy of the Government in which the Leader of the Opposition acted as Treasurer.

The shadow spokesman for finance was his monetary adviser. The legacy of the massive fiscal deficit that they left us has been turned around. This financial year we are looking at a substantial fiscal surplus. No other OECD country has had that sort of turnaround to a zero public sector borrowing requirement. So the Opposition spokesmen have a rather tough job of convincing us that they would be able to run a yet tighter fiscal policy and constrain expenditure yet further.

What about their claim that they would cut expenditure further? The fact is that time and again-most recently on Budget night this year-the Opposition has been challenged to state exactly where it would cut expenditure. The Opposition has isolated certain areas which it says it will not touch. These include defence, measures which might adversely impact on living standards, and foreign debt interest. The Opposition has said that it will take those areas out and that they will not be the subject of cuts. But it has consistently failed to identify or even hint at areas where major cuts can be made.

The one exception to that, of course, is the health area. Some members of the Opposition are proposing that the transfer of health insurance from the public to the private sector would provide a superficial cut in outlays of a substantial order. However, the obvious point to make there is that if the concern and the task of macro-economic management under current economic circumstances is to limit growth in domestic demand, simply switching that area of expenditure from the public to the private sector will have absolutely no impact on domestic demand. That is the one substantial area in which the Opposition has given some hint of how it would cut expenditure. But in macro-economic terms, this will totally fail to do the job which the Opposition claims.

There is no question but that the Opposition's claim to be able to run a much better and tighter fiscal policy is just an utter absurdity and can be dismissed out of hand. So that is the first possible area in respect of which the Opposition presumably argues that it would have a more rapid pace of adjustment than what is happening at the moment.

The second possible area is wages policy. The Opposition says that it would run a tighter wages policy. Of course, the Opposition has consistently over a considerable time opposed any wage increases. The fact is that the Opposition has no coherent wage policy at all. Its constant opposition to wage rises sits oddly with its professed concern about living standards. One highly significant aspect of this in the current circumstances, in which we are looking at the prospect of substantial tax cuts, is that in the absence of the ability to negotiate a wage-tax trade-off, the effect on domestic demand and, hence, on the inflow of imports, of large tax cuts of the order of what the Opposition is talking about or hinting at would be utterly catastrophic and would lead to a substantial exacerbation of the very problem that it claims to be concerned about-the balance of payments problem. The clearest illustration of the way in which that effect would operate is the case of Great Britain under the Thatcher Government, where we have seen precisely that done-substantial tax cuts producing a very serious balance of payments problem. The Opposition has no coherent answer to that whatsoever. I do not think any serious weight can be attached to their pronouncements in the wages area either.

That leaves the third possibility-monetary policy. Of course, we are getting a bit warmer in respect of this area. Yesterday a matter of public importance was proposed-unfortunately it was not debated-in which the Opposition professed to be concerned about interest rates and their impact on living standards. What exactly would the Opposition do in the monetary policy area? If we are to take seriously today's matter of public importance that involves a further tightening of policy and a more rapid pace of adjustment, logic would tell us that the Opposition would advocate a tighter monetary policy in order to further dampen domestic demand with the obvious implication of higher interest rates. That is the Opposition's policy prescription in the monetary policy area. It is the only instrument that it has left, because it has no credibility in the fiscal or wages policy areas. The only policy instrument that the Opposition has at its disposal is one in which it would have to tighten monetary policy. That would mean higher interest rates than we have now, and that would have a serious adverse impact on living standards.

It is interesting to note that yesterday the Opposition finance spokesman proposed the matter of public importance yesterday which supposedly expressed concern about interest rates. I have a copy of the letter which he sent to the editor of the Australian Financial Review on 5 October 1988. Throughout this letter he makes it explicit and clear that he favours a tightening of monetary policy and higher interest rates. I quote directly a few passages:
. . . I was concerned that by responding to the editorial-
this was a reply to an editorial-
rather than just lying low, I might sustain the issue, with the practical effect that the much needed-
I emphasise the words `much needed'-
further tightening of monetary policy would be even more delayed.
The shadow spokesmen went on to say:
Now to be clear, I am not arrogant enough to imagine that the Reserve Bank and Treasurer could be small minded enough to delay the needed-
I emphasise the word `needed'-
tightening of monetary policy . . .

In other words, it is absolutely unambiguous that the shadow finance spokesperson, presumably speaking on behalf of the Opposition, advocates higher interest rates, higher mortgage repayments and reduced living standards. Yesterday the Opposition expressed a totally contradictory concern about living standards, implying that its policy mix would produce lower interest rates. There is no evidence for that whatsoever. Opposition members then come in here today and advocate a faster pace of adjustment when their bankrupt economic policies imply that the only possible instrument of adjustment would be a tighter monetary policy-again, higher interest rates, reduced living standards and higher mortgage repayments. The Opposition policy is an utter farce and should be recognised as such by all members of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the National Party introducing and moving the second reading of the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill 1988 forthwith.

I so move because of the concern on this side of the House that follows the announcement this morning, to which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has promised to give his attention, that a review of Britain's military cooperation with the Australian defence establishment started in London yesterday in the wake of a ban imposed by Melbourne unions on HMS Ark Royal. We are dealing with this matter in this way and at this time because, from a review of today's program, no effort is being taken by the Government to ensure that it has the power-not that it need use the power-to ensure that we can maintain in a proper and appropriate way not only our defence relationship but also the honour of this country in extending to the United Kingdom and other countries an invitation to participate in Australia's bicentennial celebrations.

This is the last occasion that this Parliament will meet prior to the Ark Royal's scheduled berthing in Fremantle at 9 a.m. on Sunday. If this action is not taken and this Bill is not passed through this House, there will be no provision except the standby powers of the Government to take HMS Ark Royal down to HMAS Stirling in Garden Island for it to be berthed there. The Government will say, `Yes, but that ensures we will be able to handle the Ark Royal'. The reason why we have to suspend Standing Orders to consider this Bill is the time factor. This is Thursday afternoon. HMS Ark Royal was due to berth in Port Phillip. She did not do so. HMS Ark Royal was due to berth and participate in bicentennial celebrations in Adelaide. She did not do so. HMS Ark Royal is now sailing and due to berth in Fremantle on Sunday morning. Will she do so? Of course, the Government says that it has two naval tugs in Western Australia, that it has standby arrangements and it can guarantee it can handle the situation. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a matter of propriety and the honour of Australians.

This afternoon at Question Time we heard the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris). They are not concerned about a few statistics and about containers that have not been discharged in Sydney and in Melbourne. They are not worried about the fact that industrial disputation is threatening and prejudicing our reliability and reputation as an international trader. What is happening is that this Government is saying, `Look, our defence and our honour are going to be put on a table as part of an industrial negotiation'. That is not good enough. Honourable members on this side of the House believe that it is about time that we reconsidered the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill 1988, which is similar in form to a Bill I introduced into this House in 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you were in government.

—Precisely. I am glad the Minister spoke about that because the circumstances were that in government we were prepared to ensure that we had a capacity, should it be necessary, for the Federal Government to exercise its defence powers. We did not do so because we understood that it was possible for us to come to conclusions, but we did not deny the capacity to have the power.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why we want to introduce the Bill this afternoon is that we would hope we would not have to use it. I would have thought that the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) would understand that the purpose of having a defence force is not to use it but to create a climate in which those who are in our region know that we have sufficient capacity so that they will not want to attack us; they are not going to prejudice our national interest.

The whole concept of our defence arrangements relates to the deterrent effect. We consider this relationship at this time of the celebrations of our Bicentenary. But, in a wider sense, because of the threats that are obviously there, not just for the British but also the Americans, there is every reason for them to ask: `What earthly use is there in us trying to rely on you?' We see this Government going down the New Zealand course. Let no-one in Australia be mistaken. The product of the change of government in Victoria, as I would describe the result of the recent election there, is that for the first time the Socialist Left of the Labor Party has assumed office in a major State government. The Socialist Left was the reason the HMS Ark Royal did not dock in Flinders Dock in Melbourne. The Socialist Left is out there telling the Victorian Premier that it is not going to have a bar of overseas naval vessels in Australia. The Socialist Left is laying down the agenda and that is exactly what has happened in New Zealand.

On this side of the House, we are not prepared to accept the undoubted good intentions of the Minister to try to maintain our defence arrangements with the United States and the United Kingdom. People should remember that ANZAM, the Australian-New Zealand arrangements that involve Malaysia, Singapore and the United Kingdom, is a quite critical part of our defence arrangements. Under that particular agreement, we maintain our arrangements in Butterworth. The whole concept of the United Kingdom arrangement, of course, is not as significant as it used to be, but we seek to maintain and ensure our reliability as a nation. We want to put into place an insurance policy.

We would hope that through negotiations the comments that were made by Mr Bill Ethel this morning on AM were not fulfilled. Let no-one be fooled. The Minister will say that of course there are contingency arrangements. We know the ships can go down to HMAS Stirling. We know that there are facilities there. We know there are tugs there. We know the Army has the provisions and the capacity to be able to handle any naval ship should she go into dock there.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are our allies.

—They are our allies, as my colleague says. The point is that the Ark Royal could not berth in Melbourne. The sailors could not go ashore. The Ark Royal could not berth and in fact is not visiting Adelaide. The Ark Royal will visit HMAS Stirling but she ought to be berthed in Fremantle. I hope the Minister and the Prime Minister succeed in persuading WA Incorporated and the Western Australian Premier to allow the Ark Royal to berth as she should. But, if we do not introduce and pass this Bill this afternoon, the Government will not be able to do anything except rely on a wish and a prayer; and that is not good enough. The Government has to be able to ensure that the threat that undoubtedly lies behind that Advertiser article is not in any way realised. Our defence arrangements are not there as a matter for industrial negotiation.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot have the Bill Ethels or the crane drivers of this world saying that they are not going to allow the ship to be prove- dored and refuelled and that they are going to create obstacles in every possible way. We all know there are a few radical elements in our community who will do everything they can to embarrass overseas sailors in Australian ports. We saw the absolutely appalling sight of things that were done in Melbourne to visiting sailors. That is just not good enough! This Government has a prime responsibility to ensure that it exercises the constitutional power that it has to have a piece of legislation available but not necessarily to exercise it. That is what this suspension of Standing Orders is all about.

We know the Minister says, `Yes, we have naval tugs; we have facilities; and we believe our industrial negotiations are going to succeed'. But did he hear AM this morning? Does he really believe that the Bill Ethels of this world will just lie doggo? We heard about this at Question Time. We know the doubt about the tax-wage trade-off next year. We have all these diverse views from the Government. At the moment the Treasurer tries to dampen down the tax cut expectations. The realisation within the trade union movement is that this Labor Government is welshing on its responsibilities. The left wing of the trade union movement is quite prepared to assert its rights and, if it can embarrass this Government, it will. What is wrong with it all is that they are going to embarrass Australia.

We on this side of the House are not prepared to have that threat overhanging the British Royal Navy, our invited guest, on Sunday morning. There is a very easy way by which that situation can be overcome. It is not the contingency of having Ark Royal berth down in HMAS Stirling, but of having the guarantee that the Government can ensure she berths in Fremantle. It is not just a matter of a wish and a prayer. It should not be a matter of industrial negotiation. It should be a matter of Australia's prime obligation to maintain the defence relationships and to maintain the honour of this country.

This is our bicentennial year. For goodness sake, why cannot the Government come in here, accept the piece of legislation which is designed to give it the power should it need it and, if it is successful, good luck to it! But, for goodness sake, do not let the Minister come in and say, `It doesn't matter. We have contingency plans that might work'. So far as we are concerned, our relationships with our friends are too important for that. Why cannot we, in our bicentennial year, be assured that we can at least maintain our probity, our integrity and our international honour. It is an important issue. It is not something the Minister can dismiss as being irrelevant. It is important. It is critical. I have moved to suspend Standing Orders so that this particular piece of legislation, the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill 1988, can be introduced into this House this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable member's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion. This motion is necessary because of the weak and gutless action of this Government over the last two years and, to some extent, in preceding years. It is essential to suspend the Standing Orders to allow the introduction of the Bill, to allow the Government-indeed, to force the Government-to exercise control when visiting warships come to this country and to allow them to enter, to berth, to repair and to be supplied fuel and stores. What has happened in the last couple of weeks has brought great shame and disgrace to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now regarded in Britain and America as an unreliable ally. While the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), who is at the table, might have made his personal efforts, he has been rolled and has been unable to convince either Britain or America that we are any longer a reliable ally. They see us going down the New Zealand road. About two weeks ago the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) raised the spectre again. The Minister for Defence said in his White Paper last year and he has said it on subsequent occasions-along with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) whenever he gets a chance-that the cornerstone of our defence is for us to be a strong member of the Western Alliance. As the Minister well knows, the British High Commission and the United States Embassy are now questioning that, as are their governments. They are asking Australia whether it really wants to be a member of the Western Alliance and whether we are to remain a member of ANZUS.

We look forward to the Prime Minister coming back to answer the question the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) asked today and telling us whether the reports from the United Kingdom are true. Is the British Government conducting a review of the Australian-British relationship? It is an absolute disgrace that Britain, our oldest friend and ally, would be considering a review of its relationship with Australia. That has been brought about by the Government's inaction. We have had the spectacle of two British Navy ships sitting in Port Phillip Bay for three days waiting to berth, having been invited to this country by the Australian Government. What did the Minister do about it? Nothing. The Minister's spokesman said, `It is in the hands of the unions'. In Sydney HMS Edinburgh arrived with a damaged propeller. Did we put it in dry dock, as the British wanted us to do? No. And why? Because the unions had the Minister bluffed. The Minister knew that if it went into dry dock the unions may not have taken it out. Did the Minister give the guarantee asked for? No, he did not. So the British did not make a formal request. In addition, the Ark Royal and the Fort Grange were sitting in the middle of Melbourne harbour waiting to berth. They were our guests, having been invited by the Minister. The fiasco in Adelaide is being fixed. How is it being fixed? By negotiation with the unions. Is every warship visiting this country going to be subjected by the Government to negotiations with the unions on whether it will be allowed to come into an Australian port?

Before this incident we had HMS Invincible in 1983. Who could forget it? No wonder the British are worried. In 1985 we had the MX missile fiasco. No wonder the Americans are worried. The Minister is inviting people to come, abusing them when they arrive, and casting into doubt our membership of the Western Alliance. The unions are winning hands down. The Minister claims that he can do it by negotiation. That does not convince the American or British governments because they have lost confidence in him. We say to the Minister and to the Government that they should allow this legislation to go through so that, once again, all of us can stand up like proud Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not agree to this motion and rejects both it and the cant and hypocrisy which underlies it. I will go into that in some detail in a minute or two. We do not have to stand in this House and make any apology to the Opposition for the way we conduct our relationships with our principal allies. We can go to the plethora of statements that our allies have made about the nature of the relationships they have with this Government as evidence of that fact. The Opposition is attempting to introduce the Defence (Visiting Warships) Bill. It is worth looking at a bit of history in order to find a basis for rejecting it. The Opposition comes in here big-noting itself about legislation it put forward in this House six years ago, in 1982. That legislation was brought into this House and, to the Opposition's horror, it discovered that we were prepared to support it. The Bill received its second reading in the Senate and then disappeared for the remaining two or three months of that session. It was never brought back. There was no interest in it. There could be a couple of reasons for that.
—On the word of the Premier of Victoria.

—The honourable member should not give me that `word of Victoria' nonsense. That was given within a week of the issue being raised and within about three months of its being introduced in this Parliament. Do not tell me about the `word of Victoria' suddenly appearing in this place. What a load of nonsense. The word of Victoria was given publicly months in advance of that Bill coming in. The fact is that when the Opposition discovered that we would support it, it did not want to proceed with it. It did not want to proceed with it either because it did not think it was necessary or because it did not think it was enforceable.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, when one looks at the Bill, there are distinct problems of enforceability associated with it, implying as it does, effectively, the Minister for Defence taking over every port in the country when a foreign ship visits, at least potentially. It would mean that when these goodwill visits occur, on which the Government places great importance-I will demonstrate that point in some detail further-we would be placed in a position of having them occur on a basis of extraordinary squabbles over jurisdiction, extraordinary squabbles over who exactly we should prosecute, and extraordinary squabbles over who exactly we should gaol, going through the process ever time a ship visits of gaoling a few hundred people here and there. What a terrific idea the Opposition is now foisting upon us! This is how we are supposed to sustain the support of our population for the ship visits policy of this Government.

We have discovered the Opposition's policy, since we have had the opportunity in office, and the doubts it was riven with at the time. We have had the benefit of it since we got ourselves into office. We now look at the points at which its policy was successful but which we have made universal. The point of the policies the Opposition pursued when it was in office was to evade confrontation by avoiding the east coast and ensuring that when port visits took place in Western Australia they were sustained by the only two naval tugs manned by naval personnel in the naval inventory. There were no Australian naval ships there. There was the odd patrol boat and survey vessel. The destroyers that are there now, with one extra coming in another week or two, and the submarines that are there now are the products of the decision of this Government. The tugs preceded the ships. On the east coast there were no tugs.

I will give a few interesting statistics because, as I pointed out in this place a long time ago, I have been trying to change a few minds on port visits so that we do not have Finland east coast and ANZUS west coast, which was the policy of the previous Government. In 1981 we had 48 visits to west coast ports and 19 to east coast ports. In 1982 we had 54 visits to west coast ports and 18 to east coast ports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever heard of Afghanistan?

—In 1986 there were 34 west coast port visits and 24 east coast port visits. In 1987 there were 33 west coast port visits and 27 east coast port visits. The right honourable member heckles me about Afghanistan. Afghanistan never imposed the obligations on the United States Navy that the Persian Gulf imbroglio imposed on it. United States activity in the Indian Ocean has been vastly greater over the last couple of years, as a bit of common sense would tell him, than in the immediate aftermath of the Afghanistan crisis. But on port visits they are turning up here on the east coast. Why? Because this Government said it was politically intolerable, on the basis of the relationship we have with the United States, that it should be assumed for one minute that the Government of Australia, by sleight of hand or any other means, was scared to put the ships of its allies into east coast ports. That was the subtle position adopted by our predecessors and it is one which we reject. Over the years we discovered that by and large, irrespective of any demonstration, irrespective of any industrial opposition, we have been able to berth those increased numbers of warships on the east coast.
—What about Melbourne and Port Adelaide?

—In the case of Melbourne, for the first time we were proved incorrect. As a result of that we have decided to address the matter in exactly the same way as the previous Government addressed it in Western Australia-no more and no less. We will address it in exactly the same way as the previous Government addressed it in Western Australia and we will provide the wherewithal to berth those ships should the need arise. That is all there is to it. We thought that the previous Government's subtle policy or its underhand, underground, unannounced policy, probably ought to work and maintain a reasonable degree of peace and acceptance of ship visits among our citizens. We have come to the same conclusion that the previous Government reached, only we will apply it to our total Australian participation in ANZUS policy-as opposed to the Finland policy for the east coast and the ANZUS policy for the west coast. We reject the nonsense and the necessity for the legislation that the Opposition is trying to tout here.

SPEECH.PARA: Our relationship with the United States and the United Kingdom could not be better. The right honourable member talked about ANZAM. If he were current he would have been aware that that disappeared ages ago. We are talking about the five-power defence arrangement in which we are significantly upgrading our participation by rotating a ship through Singapore and in which we participated in the first ministerial meeting, Britain included, that has happened with the five-power defence arrangement since it was founded in 1971. We are engaged in a process of breathing real meaning into five-power instead of running away from it. What it faced under the previous Government was a subtle continual rundown: `It is not really all that relevant to regional security; it is not really all that relevant to the politics of the region; let's just let five-power drift quietly away'. That was the previous Government's policy. We have said that that is not good enough, that as far as we are concerned five-power provides a substantial input into regional affairs and we should nurture it.

Opposition members know nothing about defence and our relationships with our allies. They have kept themselves in deliberate ignorance over the last four or five years by failing to give any area of foreign policy serious attention. The Opposition says in this place that it is serious about defence matters and that we should suspend Standing Orders. The shadow Minister, who has been a shadow Minister for three or four years, was put into the defence portfolio recently. So little does the Opposition think of defence and its defence spokesman-who travels around this country's bases like a long lost soul remembering his past lives but basically having nothing to do with the politics of defence-that it will not put him in the shadow Cabinet. The Opposition is not serious about defence matters. The fact that it is not is well and truly amplified by the nonsense that it has spouted on this occasion.

We welcome those visitors to our shores: we invited them to come here. This country provides access to ports like no other and it will continue to do so. We will continue to have the support of our citizenry for those port visits because we will exercise common sense in our dealings with people on these matters to sustain maximum possible public support for ship visits. On the basis of tried and true experience, we believe that we have the means by which we can do that. We are gaining the additional means by which we can do that by the processes already announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We reject the motion.

That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 1 November 1988, at 3 p.m., unless the Speaker fixes an alternative day or hour of meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this motion. However, I want to take the opportunity again to make a plea to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in relation to the conduct of Question Time. Again today there were only six questions asked by the Opposition in the time available. That means that there was a total of 12 questions asked by members of the House of Representatives. I said on another occasion when there was a motion in relation to a special adjournment that in the five years 1975 to 1979, when the Fraser Government was in office, no fewer than 5,555 questions were asked. —Mr Deputy Speaker, I think it is relevant, because if the Government is going to continue in this way I submit that the House ought to be meeting two or three hours earlier in order to provide the Opposition and, indeed, the back bench members of the Government, with adequate time to ask questions. Under the Westminster system it is traditional for the government of the day to make itself available for a period that is called Question Time so that Ministers may be questioned in relation to their administrations. Slowly but surely under this Government the number of questions that can be asked is diminishing. Today is a classic example. The Opposition refrained--

—Order! I again draw the honourable member's attention to the fact that the motion before the House deals with the time of meeting of the House and not with the business to be conducted at that particular time. I ask the honourable member to be relevant, otherwise I will have to ask him to resume his seat.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I heard what you said. I have a reputation for respecting the Chair and the person who occupies the Chair. But I believe what is happening in this Parliament is disgraceful. It is time that the Government took stock of the situation. Whilst the motion relates specifically to the time that the House will meet on Tuesday, 1 November 1988, and whilst I have indicated that the Opposition on this occasion will not oppose the motion moved by the Leader of the House, I am saying to you, sir, and through you to the House, that if the Government continues down the track that it has pursued this week, we will get to a point at which there will be very little time available for questions to be asked. In that event, unless the Government is prepared to do something about the period allocated for questions, then the time suggested for the meeting of the House will be opposed by us because we will move an amendment to enable the House to meet earlier.

SPEECH.PARA: I say with great sincerity, through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Leader of the House, that today I think there was only one point of order taken by the Opposition. Notwithstanding that, Ministers, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), took an inordinate time to answer questions. At the very least seven questions from both sides of the House ought to be asked. Indeed, on one occasion a few days ago there were 10 questions from both sides of the House, so it can be done if the Government wants to cooperate.
