SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing orders 45, 46, 47, 199, 200 and 285 be amended by omitting ``two'' (wherever occurring) and substituting ``four''.

As honourable members would realise, this motion basically maintains in Standing Orders the practice we have adopted since being in this House of ringing the bells for four minutes for votes and quorums. I think we have been running informal tests on how many people have made it, on both sides of the House, for a division by the conclusion of three minutes, and the tests would suggest that this is not the most athletic House that has ever been elected in the history of Federation and that four minutes is unquestionably necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the motion. Indeed, because of the reasons that the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has referred to, it is necessary to continue ringing the bells for four minutes to give members adequate time to answer the call, be it for a division or a quorum. I suggest to the Leader of the House that the Government, in cooperation with Madam Speaker, give consideration to the installation of electronic equipment for the recording of divisions. I understand that the building is wired for the electronic equipment, and I also understand that the idea was put aside at some stage during construction or during the design stages because of the cost. I do not know what it costs to keep this House in session for one hour, but I imagine it is quite considerable. I am sure that any cost-benefit survey would show that in this day and age the House of Representatives and, indeed, the Senate would be able to complete the business of recording a vote much quicker with the use of electronic equipment and that there would be an overall cost saving.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not making these remarks in any critical way, but in a cooperative spirit and in the sincere hope that Madam Speaker and the Government will give consideration to this idea. Four minutes are required because of the distances between ministerial suites and the suites of members and the chamber, but, when we get here, we should be able to record votes much more quickly than we do under the present system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) on the matter of electronic voting. Those of us who have had the privilege of visiting the United States House of Representatives will have seen that during a division suddenly one section of a wall of that chamber changes colour and up come all the names of the members. Their votes are shown and totals reached in a very quick and efficient way, without in any way taking away the need for the member to be present to cast his vote. This motion before the House does set in concrete the time of the ringing of the bells for divisions and quorums.

SPEECH.PARA: One other point I want to raise is that I hope the powers that be, the Speaker, the President, the Government and the House managers on both sides, will look at the severe problem that has now been created for those who take more than a passing interest in the proceedings in the other chamber, be they senators visiting this lower House or be they lower House members visiting the Senate. Due to the need to compartmentalise the first floor for the public, members end up having to fight their way through a series of china walls and man-made obstructions-in fact the more attractive the door, the more likely it is to be locked. The best located lifts are designed to confuse members and prevent them making it to a particular level of the House which they want to get to because access to that particular floor is ruled out. I do not dwell on this unduly because we are privileged to be in a fantastic building-perhaps one of the most magnificent buildings in the Southern Hemisphere-and our conditions have improved greatly. I dare say that efficiency has improved as a consequence of being able to have one's own desk without one's secretary sitting on the desk top, because there is no other room for her, as was the case in the old Parliament House.

In the situation where members and senators cross over, especially with debates on certain legislation where we have shadow representations, when the division bells ring there is a physical problem in complying with those bells, especially as we are watching the proceedings of the other chamber from the compartmentalised first floor which, due to a series of man-made barriers-and I am very pleased to use the term `man-made barriers' and not `artificial barriers' as is laid down in the Government Style Manual, which I absolutely reject-make it difficult for members to cross over in a constructive and positive way and thus contribute to the efficiency of the running of this Parliament.

I hear on the grapevine that there is a suggestion that a small section near the main door of both chambers, at ground level, might be roped off and made available for senators and members in their respective cross-over situations in each chamber. I understand that that suggestion needs to be evaluated and considered by the leaders of the parties in both chambers. That problem certainly needs to be addressed because a danger exists that if members take more than a passing interest in the proceedings of the other House, as some of us are required to do as part of our duties as shadow Ministers, they will not be able to do so without running the risk of not being back in time to vote on a division in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the comments of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). This is a matter I have discussed. There is a very serious problem in the workings of the security of public areas in this new Parliament House. It is not uncommon for members to find themselves in one of the function areas or a committee room when a division or a quorum is called, and it is very difficult for them to get to the chamber. I think we have put a high priority on security and given the lowest priority to the needs of members getting to and from the chamber. When members are in what I would call the House of Representatives precincts-that is, in their office area-access to the chamber, except for the distance, is not too difficult. But as soon as we move out of the precincts of the House of Representatives side of the Parliament, access to this area is extraordinarily difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: Members might recall that the other night a quorum was called at about 8 o'clock and it took some time to form a quorum. That delay was not due to the tardiness of members. I have checked with many of them and I have found that they had to come from committee rooms and other areas. It took longer than expected, due to the reason that the previous speaker has referred to. When we come, for example, from the second floor to the first floor we find the door is locked. This is a serious safety hazard because some of these fire doors should open, but they do not. Also committee rooms have electronically locked doors. That is totally unacceptable because, if there is a fire alarm, the system will prevent the unlocking of those doors. As the previous speaker said, if we wish to go from here to the Senate side, we are asked not to proceed by the senators lobbies which are on either side of the chamber. Again we have to go through the extraordinary exercise of making our way up through the first floor before getting back to the ground floor. I know of no institution that deliberately designs such obstructions, except this one.

We have to ask ourselves whether this place is working properly. I think the answer, in the short time that we have been here, is that it is not. I believe members in this place have good intentions at least to stay in contact with one another and to do their part in making the Parliament work. But there are real obstacles with the current arrangements with lifts and staircases.

TALK.START.PARA: —And arrangements for meeting guests.

—The honourable member is quite correct. One finds that if one wishes to speak to one's guests in the gallery, getting up there is a long, difficult exercise. Again, that is a nonsense. Again, this has happened because the architects have been allowed to design the inside after they have designed the outside of the building. They have not looked at the normal, public usage of this area. Quite honestly, it is a serious matter that we, as a parliament-certainly those in the House of Representatives-need to address. One finds that it is very difficult under the current circumstances for members to get to and from the chamber. I would think that that is the primary issue. Bear in mind that honourable members are not always in their offices and in the House of Representatives precincts. Very often they are at committees, public hearings, or in the functions area at an official function. It is extraordinarily difficult to get back to this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure I speak on behalf of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer, whose remarks I endorse. Members' interests in this respect have not been properly served by the current arrangements. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to convey on my behalf and, I assume, on behalf of other members, the need to review the current arrangements as far as lifts and doors are concerned. I believe that security has been given a priority and the needs of honourable members for getting to and from the chamber when they are outside the House of Representatives precincts have been given very little priority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure those comments will be relayed to the Acting Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not to prolong the debate in any sense but simply for an abundance of caution, I say for myself and, I am sure, for many others that many honourable members share the views expressed by the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). There is no need for me to repeat them. I simply want to emphasise the fact that the views that he has expressed about the difficulty of moving around this building are held by many other members, and certainly by me. Although there is no need to repeat the arguments, I would like it recorded that I hope that those views are seriously considered and put into practice because this business of locking every door that one needs to use as one walks around the place is absolutely absurd.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains amendments to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Veterans' Entitlements (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1986 and the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940. The amendments contained in this Bill include measures to address the reports of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee and to implement decisions provided for in the 1988-89 Budget. The Bill also contains a number of minor non-Budget measures. This Bill is primarily aimed at giving effect to those major recommendations of the Veterans' Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee accepted by the Government and requiring legislative amendments to implement.

The Monitoring Committee was set up on 18 May 1987 to determine the extent to which the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 met the stated intentions of the Government at the time of its passage through Parliament. The report of the Monitoring Committee was presented to the Government on 23 May 1988. Details of the Government's initial response to the report were set out in a response booklet sent to all members and senators in September. The Government has accepted 28 of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations in full, four have been accepted in a modified form and another 20 are receiving further consideration. I will advise of the outcome in due course. Nine of the 32 accepted recommendations are considered to require immediate legislative amendment and are presented in this Bill.

The first initiative arises from a committee recommendation which the Government accepted in full. The Bill provides for the introduction of an extreme disablement adjustment (EDA) to assist those frail, aged veterans who are not adequately compensated by the present disability pension structure. These are veterans who are receiving the 100 per cent general rate disability pension, are severely incapacitated by their war or defence-caused disabilities, have passed the normal retirement age and are not eligible for the intermediate or special rate of pension. The EDA will be an addition to the maximum general rate pension received by the veteran and will be equal to 50 per cent of the rate. It will mean an extra $42.15 a week for eligible veterans at current rates. A major focus of the Monitoring Committee's report was the eligibility criteria for intermediate and special rate pensions.

The criteria for these higher rates of disability pension were changed by the Government in 1985 when it became clear that the outmoded terminology in the old Repatriation Act was enabling these pensions to be paid to veterans who had completed a full working life, often retiring on good superannuation payments. Nevertheless, the Committee was critical of these criteria, arguing that the requirement for war-caused disabilities to be the sole cause of a veteran's inability to work was too harsh. In arguing this way, the Committee was perhaps overlooking the original intention of the intermediate and special rate pensions. This was to provide a higher level of pension to compensate those severely disabled veterans who could not work to support their families on their return from service. These pensions were never intended to be retirement pensions. That is why the Government took the steps it did in 1985 and why the changes to the eligibility criteria for these pensions were carried through to the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The Government does not agree with many of the views expressed by the Committee about those changes and in particular with the Committee's assessment of the intention behind the changes. The Government could not, therefore, agree to recommendations made by the Committee for major changes to the eligibility criteria. However, the Government has not rejected the Committee's recommendations on the intermediate and special rate provisions outright.

The Bill proposes major changes to the first of the eligibility criteria for such pensions and to procedural aspects of the scheme of the Act for assessing rates of pensions. These changes will be of significant benefit to veterans. Currently, the first of the criteria for eligibility for an intermediate or special rate disability pension is that the veteran be receiving or be eligible to receive a disability pension at 100 per cent of the general rate. The Monitoring Committee had recommended abolition of this requirement altogether. This was not acceptable to the Government as the requirement for a high degree of incapacity has been an intrinsic part of the intermediate and special rate pensions since their introduction. However, the Government recognises the Committee's argument that a veteran can be unemployed and unemployable due to war or defence-caused incapacity when the incapacity is as low as that attracting a disability pension at 70 per cent of the general rate. The Bill will therefore provide for a reduction in the required degree of incapacity from 100 per cent to 70 per cent. The Committee also criticised the `application day' provisions which were inserted in the legislation in 1987. The Government does not agree with many of these criticisms.

Under the provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act, as interpreted by the Federal Court, the day on which a veteran's eligibility for the special rate pension is to be determined has always been the day of his or her application. However, a decision of Justice McGuire of that Court would have permitted decision-makers to examine the right of a veteran to continue to receive pension at the special rate even though the eligibility criteria had been satisfied on the earlier application day. The Government acted quickly by introducing amendments to overcome the effects of that decision. The effect of the 1987 amendments were twofold. The first was to confirm the application day as the relevant day on which to examine a claim. This prevented factors occurring after the application date, such as deterioration in non war-caused disabilities or increasing age, from being taken into account as reasons why the veteran would have not been working at that later point in time. Such factors would have had a disentitling effect on the eligibility of any veteran for the higher rates of pension. The second was to ensure that, subject to certain exceptions, once granted on the basis of eligibility at the application day, a pension could not be taken away on a subsequent review. That is, the special rate pension was preserved for life.

A veteran who was not eligible for intermediate or special rate pension on the application day was precluded from being granted a pension prior to the 1987 amendments and continued to be so precluded after those amendments. Where a veteran became eligible for a higher rate of pension after the application day, the Act required the veteran to lodge a fresh application for increase in pension. Many veterans for a variety of reasons failed to lodge a fresh application. The failure to follow this procedure has had an adverse effect in some cases and has meant the issue of a fixed `application day' assessment has continued to be a contentious one. Even recent decisions of the Federal Court of Australia indicate a misunderstanding of the scheme of the Act and the intention behind the application day provisions. Due to its contentious nature, I specifically requested that this issue be considered by the Monitoring Committee.

Having regard to the confusion and misunderstanding and the views of the Monitoring Committee, the Government has decided that the application day provisions will be amended. The new provisions would enable a veteran to qualify where he or she meets all the eligibility criteria at a date between the date of lodgment of the claim or application and the date of the decision of the Commission or any review body. While this will not have the effect of altering the existing eligibility criteria under the Act, it will mean that it will no longer be necessary to lodge a further claim or application for increase between the date of application and the date of determination of the claim when circumstances change during that period.

The Committee cited the example of a veteran who is employed at the time when his or her claim is lodged, who expects to and who subsequently does retire due to war-caused disabilities before the claim is determined. This veteran would not be required under the new scheme to lodge a fresh application upon retirement. Such a person will be entitled to special rate pension for life, provided of course that all the eligibility criteria continue to be satisfied in all respects at the date of his or her retirement.

These amendments will allow decision makers to take into account significant variations in the degree of incapacity a veteran may suffer from his war-caused disabilities during the assessment period. At present, review bodies see themselves as restricted to looking at the veteran's situation at the time of the initial decision. I believe that these amendments will allow a commonsense approach to be taken in the consideration of pension assessment applications and will have a significant beneficial impact.
This Bill also makes a number of minor amendments arising out of recommendations made by the Monitoring Committee. These include:

Clarification that the determination of the required degree of incapacity of at least 70 per cent need not be made by a previous decision-maker before the Commission, Veterans' Review Board or Administrative Appeals Tribunal proceeds to consider eligibility for the intermediate or special rate of pension;

provision to ensure that veterans receiving pension at 100 per cent of the general rate for tuberculosis are deemed to meet the required degree of incapacity for intermediate and special rate pension purposes; and

provision to ensure that matters which were commenced prior to the commencement of the veterans' entitlements legislation are, for the purposes of the application of that legislation, treated as if the initiating action was a `claim'.
Through this legislation and administrative measures, the Government has acted quickly to implement as many of the Monitoring Committee's recommendations as possible.

This Bill does not just deal with Monitoring Committee issues. This Bill will also provide for increases in the rates of specific disability allowance, clothing allowance, attendant allowance and recreation transport allowance. Further minor amendments include:
Clarification that a war widow's pension may only be paid to a remarried widow where she remarried after 28 May 1984;
a change to the definition of `severely handicapped veteran' for carer's service pension purposes to bring it into line with the equivalent definition in the Social Security Act; and
a change to ensure that overpayments arising under the Social Security Act and recoverable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act are subject to social security rights of review.
Financial Impact

The introduction of the extreme disablement adjustment, the changes to the intermediate and special rate pension criteria and the application day/up-to-date assessment changes will cost approximately $3.15m in 1988-89 and $8.85m in the full year 1989-90. The increases to minor benefits will cost approximately $168,000 in 1988-89 and $335,000 in the full year 1989-90. The other amendments are revenue neutral. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF SHELL FILLING FACILITY FOR ST MARYS MUNITIONS FILLING FACTORY, NEW SOUTH WALES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of a shell filling facility for St Marys Munitions Filling Factory, New South Wales.

The proposed work now before the House is for the construction of a new facility for the filling of high explosive shells at the St Marys Munitions Filling Factory. This factory, which is located 45 kilometres west of Sydney, is one of the three main explosives manufacturing factories operated by the Department of Defence. The factory is a self-contained facility for manufacturing, filling and assembling a wide range of service ammunition and other explosive stores. It is the only establishment in Australia capable of filling shells.

The factory site consists of approximately 800 buildings made up of explosives processing buildings, storage magazines and support buildings, such as offices and engineering services. Within the proposed new shell filling facility shell cases will be filled with high explosives. This is a specialised operation involving a casting process in which the explosive is melted, poured into the shell case and allowed to solidify under controlled conditions. The existing shell filling facility at St Marys is over 30 years old and as a result of high usage, general wear and corrosion the existing plant has reached the end of it economic life. In addition, the health and safety standards with respect to fumes, dust and noise are substandard.

The proposed new shell filling building and plant have been designed to minimise exposure of employees to dusts and vapours and will provide a safer, more efficient environment, better suited to meet current and future needs of the Department of Defence. The proposed work comprises a new process building containing: shell preparation, fill and probe sections and a shell finishing section; earth mounds for safety protection; associated engineering services and site works; a trade waste treatment system; and process plant capable of filling medium to large calibre shells to meet current and expected production requirements. This plant, which does not form part of the proposal being referred to the Committee, will be installed during the building construction phase of the process plant.

The estimated cost of this proposed shell filling facility is $7.7m at April 1988 prices. Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended that construction commence in mid-1989 and be completed by early 1991. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the reference of this work to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. The St Mary's factory is a very old facility. I am not sure how far it goes back. It looks as though it is of World War I vintage. It is necessary that the facility be upgraded because whether one likes it or not, the filling of shells and the manufacture of ammunition is very much a part of our self-sufficiency in defence. We would all like to see a peaceful world. In the last few days we have had protests against the visit of nuclear ships to this country. The people protesting are fantasising if they expect the world to be as perfect as they would like to see it. The reality is that it has been the strength of the Western Alliance in the past few years that has maintained the peace and, regrettable as it may be to some people, munitions and ammunition and the general readiness of our defence forces are very much part and parcel of maintaining that peace.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that with the redevelopment of St Marys into a modern facility we will be in the business of not only making ammunition for ourselves but also selling it to friends and allies who might require it. There is no reason in the world why Australia should not become a major exporter of defence equipment and munitions, particularly now that the former Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, who was so adamantly opposed to Australia being in this business for so long, has departed the scene for what he expects to be a higher appointment. Perhaps we will see St Marys modernised to become part of the export drive in this country. This raises the question, of course, of what are our reserves of ammunition in this country. I do not profess to know. I hear some disturbing stories about the low level of reserves and I hope they are not true. It also raises the question of how much ammunition is being made available to our defence forces for the very necessary training they have to undertake. I hear they are very short, particularly of small arms ammunition that that the allocation is about 400 rounds per man per year. If that is so, it is a pathetic figure.

Not so long ago, as honourable members might remember-I think it was in about 1983-I raised in this House the question of soldiers having to to out and buy their own ammunition, which was absolutely true. Because not sufficient service ammunition was being given to them for training, they used to acquire rifles, usually .22 rifles or bigger, and buy their own ammunition so that they had something to shoot. It is a pathetic approach to the training of our Defence Force. I have not heard such stories in the last few years. Probably we made such a fuss about it that the problem was fixed. Nevertheless, there are complaints now from our active units, our infantry battalions, that training ammunition is short, and I hope they are not true. If indeed there is a shortage of ammunition, it is just another indictment of the Government that seems to be taking every possible step it can to make life difficult for the service men and women of this country. There is no shortage of money when it comes to big ticket equipment items but when it comes to training facilities and personnel matters, it is a different story. That is why, as the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) knows, record numbers are leaving the service month by month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this reference to the Public Works Committee. I do so claiming to have the facility in my electorate but I am often reminded by at least one member of the Opposition, the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster), that the facility borders his electorate and that of the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free). SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), described the facility as run down. I place on record the cooperation on the shop floor given by the workers to those changes, some of which have been fairly traumatic. I congratulate them and place on record not only my appreciation but also the appreciation of the nation.

Importantly, when the Public Works Committee accepts this reference I hope it will, as the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) indicated, look at waste disposal and, in particular, the storage of nuclear waste at the St Marys munitions factory. One of the features of the storage of nuclear waste is that it is concentrated in Sydney in military establishments, primarily at St Marys munitions factory. It is also stored at the RAAF base at Richmond, at the military establishment at Moorebank and at other non-military sites in the western suburbs of Sydney.

I think I speak on behalf of all my constituents when I say that the St Marys munitions factory is a very significant employer of local people. We want the munitions factory to continue at St Marys. We want it to be modernised and we would like to think that management might be modernised just as the buildings might be modernised. But we do not want it to be used as a repository for nuclear waste. That is absolutely outrageous. The former State Labor Government did no credit to itself by failing to identify a site in New South Wales where nuclear waste could be stored. I appeal to the incoming Government and Minister Moore to take a different approach. He said when he first took office, and perhaps it was understandable, that he did not know that nuclear waste was stored in such quantities in the western suburbs of Sydney. DEBATE.TITLE: DEVELOPMENT OF MILITARY POLICE COMPLEX, GREEN HILLS, LIVERPOOL MILITARY AREA, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Development of a military police complex at Green Hills, Liverpool Military Area, New South Wales.

This proposal will provide new working and living accommodation for military police units currently housed in sub-standard accommodation at Ingleburn. The Army intends to rationalise the use of the Ingleburn military area, with regular Army units currently accommodated there being relocated, and part of the area being redeveloped as an Army reserve centre. The existing military police facilities at Ingleburn are currently dispersed over some 30 hectares and comprise mainly weatherboard buildings dating back to World War II. Most of these facilities are not economically viable to renovate. The standard of accommodation provided has an adverse impact on the training, morale and operational effectiveness of the units.

The new military police complex at Green Hills will accommodate the following Army military police units: A military police school, which conducts training of personnel from both military police and regimental police corps; the 2nd Military Police Company, which provides military police support to units operating within the 2nd military district; the 1st Military Corrective Establishment, whose role is to hold and conduct correctional training for servicemen under sentence or detention; the 2nd Platoon Special Investigation Branch, a unit which seeks to prevent, detect and investigate crime within the Army in the 2nd military district. The proposed complex will provide more efficient and appropriate facilities to accommodate the diverse range of activities carried out by these various military police units.
The proposed complex will comprise four main building groups arranged around a parade ground. Facilities to be provided for the various unit will include:
Headquarters and administration offices;
Operations and training areas;
A separate secure compound for the 1st Military Corrective Establishment, including its own parade ground, cell blocks, rehabilitation and recreation facilities.
There will be sharing between the unit of common-use facilities such as:
A mess served by a fully equipped kitchen;
A canteen;
Living-in accommodation for a total of 20 staff and 40 students;
Sports facilities.
The estimated cost of this proposal is $12.4m at May 1988 prices.

Subject to parliamentary approval, it is intended to call the first tenders for the works in mid-1989. Construction of the proposed complex will take approximately 20 months. I table selected plans of the proposed work and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion of reference to the Public Works Committee. We welcome the improved complex that the Government is proposing and to which this motion relates. We are interested in the fact that it is going to cost some $12.4m in 1988 dollar terms to build this complex, although one wonders what the cost will be after the 20 months of construction, which is due to begin in 1989. As I have said on previous occasions in relation to these sorts of motions, we on this side of the House have a deep-rooted concern that the costs of so many of these projects are higher than they should be and that the people who bear those costs at the end of the day are the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been estimated that restrictive work practices in these sorts of projects amount to about 20 per cent of the total cost of the project. Of course, one does not know at this stage whether that will be the case with this project. We would be interested to know whether the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) has taken account of any prospect of improved work practices or whether he is unconcerned about this very major issue. If this project is going to cost another 20 per cent, the taxpayers will be paying well over $2m more than they should. We on this side of the House are very strongly of the view that as much emphasis as possible in this regard should be placed on subcontractors in projects of this kind. I hope that the Minister will take note of that.

Our real concern is restrictive work practices. With this project, as with many others, we would seek a guarantee from the Minister that he is doing something to address that problem. Let me just give four or so examples to demonstrate the sorts of things that we really do not want to see happen on a project of this kind. We heard recently of what is apparently a very common practice-perhaps it will occur on this project if nothing is done to stop these sorts of practices-where the unions instructed employees to refuse to walk on a wet earth surface in order to get to a dry area to work. Really, I am sure the House will agree that that was a fairly extraordinary and unnecessary restrictive work practice. When the management of that project offered to put down planks for employees to walk across in order to get to the dry area, it was told by the unions that that would be completely unacceptable because people would have to walk across wet earth in order to lay the planks! Really, I think that is a foolish work practice. It simply means that productivity is much lower than it might otherwise be.

The Sydney area has a high rainfall and therefore there is the prospect of this sort of thing occurring numerous times during the construction of the proposed project that is now before the House. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo must keep within the confines of the debate. At the moment we are discussing the referral to the Public Works Committee of the development of a Military Police complex at Green Hills, Liverpool. We are not discussing work practice issues. I would like the honourable member to keep within the confines of the debate.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, let me draw your attention to the fact that $12 1/2m of taxpayers' money is proposed to be spent by the Government on this project. I am doing what I would have thought the House would expect me to do-presenting the view of the Opposition on the way this $12 1/2m is to be spent. We are prepared to support the motion but we want to make the point that we do so with the qualification that the Government must take action to address these sorts of restrictive work practices, which may, in the case of this project, add something over $2m to the cost. I have nearly finished my remarks. What I am doing, Mr Deputy Speaker, is giving a couple of examples of the sorts of problems that we have encountered in the past with projects of this kind. We do not want these practices to be repeated.

SPEECH.PARA: The next time that the Minister comes into the House with a proposal of this kind, we would like to hear not just an analysis of the proposal.
