PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave of the House to make a very short statement, at the outset of the second reading debate, which I believe would assist the House in its deliberation of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I would like to table a replacement explanatory memorandum to the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988. The memorandum that was tabled when I introduced the Bill in May required a series of corrections of a technical nature. I believed that the best way to do that for the convenience of honourable members was to produce a replacement memorandum. Since that was to happen, the opportunity was also taken to clarify some of the clause descriptions. In this instance it was particularly important that the explanatory memorandum provide a clear and accurate description of the detail in the Bill. When I introduced the Bill at the end of the autumn session, I indicated that debate on the Bill would not occur for some months to allow sufficient time for interested parties to examine the Bill in detail and to provide comment to me. I am pleased that a number of organisations took up the invitation and literally dozens of comments on different parts of the Bill have been submitted to me. I wanted to ensure that when those people examined the Bill they would have as clear a description of its contents as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will also be aware that I circulated copies of this revised memorandum in July so that it would be available for general and convenient use during the consultation process. This public consultation process that I adopted in the introduction of this legislation has, I am pleased to say, been extremely effective. Submissions were made by a number of groups, including the Australian Institute of Valuers and Land Administrators, the National Farmers Federation, the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines (Incorporated), the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia (Inc), the Australian Mining Industry Council, and the Land Acquisition Reform Committee. The latter group convened a two-day symposium in Sydney to discuss the Bill, which was attended by representatives of the Opposition, the judiciary and the Government.

At that forum I emphasised my promise contained in my second reading speech that I would consider all comments made and incorporate any suggestions for amendment which I considered would contribute to the general intentions of the Bill. I have considered all the comments and in the committee stage of the debate on this Bill I will be proposing 34 amendments which reflect the suggestions and comments generated by the consultative process. Some of these amendments are of a technical nature but others are proposed because they contribute to the objectives of this major legislative change which clearly has the interests of individuals as its primary focus. Therefore, the fact that I am prepared to propose several significant amendments should be seen, I believe, as a positive response to a successful public consultation process in which the Opposition is involved.
In commenting on the Bill prior to these amendments, Justice Murray Wilcox said:

I will not take the time to refer to the several other features of the draft which will improve the present law. It is enough to say that, even if the Bill were enacted in its present form, it would constitute a significant achievement for the Government and the Parliament. In some respects, notably compensation rights, the legislation would rank with any in the English speaking world, at least.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government has further improved the Bill, I hope, by Parliament accepting these proposed amendments that I will move during the committee stage. In doing so, I believe we are creating a model piece of legislation in this field. I now table the supplementary explanation memorandum covering my proposed amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill before the House is the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988. It is designed to implement much needed reforms of the law governing Commonwealth acquisition of land. Reforms in this difficult area of Commonwealth legislation are long overdue and the Government has been tardy, to say the least, in moving to correct the deficiencies of the current legislation. Nevertheless, the coalition welcomes this legislation as a positive step forward. It is in fact bringing Australia up to the twentieth century and more in line with other nations which have had much better legislation for some years now.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for reform, with a view to providing more adequately for the rights of property owners whose land might be acquired, was recognised by the coalition Government back in 1977. It was not only the inadequacies of the existing legislation that exercised the Fraser Government. With the coalition's firmly held belief in private property, the Government of the day wanted to ensure that fairness in acquisition continued to pertain and that the legislation kept abreast of modern times. Accordingly, the Law Reform Commission had been requested to examine the Commonwealth legislation with terms of reference which concentrated on the rights of people whose land was compulsorily acquired by the Commonwealth. The Commission was also asked to report on the law and practices in relation to compensation payable to users of private land or business in respect of the injurious effect on such land or business arising from the construction of works by the Commonwealth or an instrumentality of the Commonwealth or from the use of such works. In a third reference the Commission was asked to report on any related matter.

Following extensive deliberation, the report of the Law Reform Commission was tabled in Parliament in April 1980. The Commission was critical of a number of aspects of the existing Lands Acquisition Act and recommended new legislation covering both land acquisition and injurious affection incorporating the following:
(1) revised acquisition powers, including the right of an affected owner to an independent review, exception to the right of appeal to be:
when acquisition is urgent, or there is a need to maintain secrecy, and
when the land has already been advertised for sale.
(2) new pre-acquisition procedures, including improved information to owners before acquisition:
entitlement for the former owner to remain in possession of the land for six months after acquisition;
better compensation, including an advance of 90 per cent of the Commonwealth assessment of the compensation payable; and
a general right to compensation for injurious affection.

Since the tabling of the report there has been a lengthy discussion and debate within the community on the report's recommendations. However, it has taken the Government until 1988 finally to introduce this Bill which picks up most of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. Since then there has been a further round of discussions as a result of which, as the Minister has indicated, a number of amendments are to be introduced. These changes will pick up many of the concerns that have been expressed.

But one key issue has not been addressed by the Government's legislation. It relates to injurious affection, that is, compensation for those whose land is deleteriously affected by the acquisition by the Commonwealth of adjacent land. Injurious affection is a very complex area, legally and administratively. Yet this was an important element in the reference to the Law Reform Commission, with the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, pointing out that it was an area that needed looking at, as new legislation in Britain and Canada had to some extent dealt with this problem. In view of this, it would be helpful if the Minister could let us have the reasons why the Government has not proceeded with injurious affection.

Neither the 1955 Act nor the new legislation provides adequately for all the ramifications of injurious affection. Admittedly, the Government proposes to retain section 23 (1) (c) of the existing Act which takes some account of injurious affection. But this by no means goes far enough. It will only take into account, where a property is partially acquired, the effect on the remaining property in determining compensation, either depreciation or enhancement of value. This does not come to grips with the question of injurious affection where no land is acquired at all. As the Law Reform Commission has pointed out, an owner from whom no land is taken may suffer an injury equal to that of his neighbour from whom some land is taken. Yet, he is not entitled to any statutory compensation. This seems anomalous and unjust. Injurious affection is something that should be looked at quite seriously. Recognising the drafting difficulties involved, we suggest that the Government should immediately establish a task force to examine this area and make public its findings.

Another of our concerns relates to the mining of land vested in the Commonwealth. The Bill differs from the 1955 Act which provided for the laws of the State or Territory to apply to mining, subject to prescribed exemptions and modifications. The 1955 Act, in fact, guaranteed compatibility with State practices and procedures. Miners know exactly where they stand and are not subject to potential changes to regulations, which can occur at short notice. By retaining a reference to State laws in the Bill, there would be no need to modify the regulations under the proposed Act as changes are made to State legislation. Accordingly, I foreshadow that, in the Committee stage, we will be moving an amendment seeking to give effect to this.

A central tenet of the Law Reform Commission recommendations was that a person threatened with the compulsory acquisition of his land should be afforded the opportunity to challenge before an independent tribunal the necessity for that acquisition. The principle behind the recommendation is that, generally speaking, a person adversely affected by an administrative decision ought to be able to obtain a review by an independent body as to the fairness, as distinct from the legality, of the decision.

The Bill includes a formal provision for an owner to have the Minister reconsider the decision to acquire and it also provides for appeals to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal based upon the nature of the public purpose; the extent to which the public purpose is in the public interest; suitability of the land for the public purpose; the effect of the acquisition on land owners; the environmental effect of the use and development of the land; and any alternative means of achieving the public purpose. The Bill does not include a provision to enable an owner to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal when the land is `essential for the implementation of policy'. In fact, it specifically excludes any review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Of course, though it is not specified in the Bill, in such circumstances an owner can always appeal to the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review Act). It would be reassuring if the Minister in his reply made clear that this recourse was available to an affected owner. Otherwise the impression remains that no avenue of relief is open where a land acquisition is declared essential for the implementation of policy.

The Commission's recommendations concerning pre-acquisition are already included in the Bill. They encompass improved information to the owners whose land is to be acquired; ability of persons with an interest in the land, in addition to the owner, to appeal against the decision; and a statutory deadline of three months to acquire the property following a declaration by the Minister that acquisition is proposed. This will go some way towards minimising planning blight.

The Bill picks up all the Commission's recommendations on changed acquisition procedures, including the gazettal of acquisitions, and provides for former owners to remain in possession for six months after acquisition. More generous compensation will be available to the former owners, especially home owners. The Bill adopts the Law Reform Commission's recommendation that a home owner should never receive less than the cost of a reasonably equivalent dwelling. It also proposes a solatium of $10,000 instead of the $5,000 originally stipulated, adjusted annually by the consumer price index, to compensate owners for the intangible costs of compulsory acquisition of their homes. The Bill provides a detailed statutory list at clauses 54 to 63, giving guidance to all parties and the Federal courts for the calculation of compensation. While significant improvements will be enacted under this legislation its application must be kept under constant review so that if anomalies arise they will be addressed expeditiously rather than years being allowed to elapse before anything is done.

One of our concerns on this side of the House is that, in applying this legislation, the Government does so in the spirit of ensuring that the owner's rights are protected to the utmost. How often have we seen this Government give assurances, only to back away from them later or seek to water them down? Look at what it has been doing in the pensions-superannuation area; and now its promises for personal tax cuts and wage rises are apparently in doubt.

We do not want to see situations arising, as they have in the case of the Badgerys Creek acquisitions, where the Government has been vacillating for so long. Residents there may have been the victims of distressing political bickering as they wait for news of their future. The present situation at Badgerys Creek, where land is being acquired for a new Sydney airport, is imposing intolerable hardships on landowners. The land acquisitions there must be finalised urgently and adequate funds provided for the Government to meet its obligations to individual owners. People placed in the situation that landowners at Badgerys Creek have been should not have to endure a prolonged fight for compensation justice.

Here is an example of the sort of thing I referred to earlier. The 240 affected landholders at Badgerys Creek were assured that the Government would purchase their properties when the owners desired and that either Government or private valuers could be used. But what has happened? There was a freeze on offers to acquire land and an inadequate budget allocation by the Government to honour fully the offers it had made. Still the Government has no timetable for the construction of the airfield, after having announced its decision in February 1986. How much longer do the people there have to put up with the uncertainty that continues to surround the proposal?

Then, of course, there was the Commonwealth's proposal to acquire rural land in western New South Wales for army training and manoeuvres. After detailed public hearings, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence concluded that the two areas of land in the Bathurst-Orange area and at Cobar were wholly unsuited to meet the specified user requirements. It strongly recommended the immediate abandonment of the proposed acquisitions. In fact, the Committee in its report was highly critical of the acquisition procedures.

In the event, the Government abandoned the two projects. But consider the hardships that the affected landowners had to endure over four or more years. It raises the question of how such areas could have been selected in the first place. It also serves to emphasise the care that has to be taken to ensure that land to be acquired is actually suited to the purpose for which it is to be used. If land is acquired and then abandoned it puts a blight on it, resulting in falling market prices and reduced sales opportunities. It also raises the question of where the Australian Labor Party stands concerning private property. It says it recognises the right to own private property, but it has also acted as one of the greatest undermining factors in property ownership in Australia. Here I refer to the great coal rights grab perpetrated by the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales.

Against that background, to what extent can Labor be trusted to respect the rights of property owners? We do not want to see a repetition of the Wran piracy, when thousands of New South Wales companies and individuals were stripped of their private coal rights under compulsory acquisition and offered compensation which was less than one-third of the coal royalty rate collected by the New South Wales Government. We have had to wait for a Liberal-National Party Government to come to power in New South Wales for this devastating attack on the property system to be put right and for those affected to be afforded a measure of fair treatment.

Another factor to be kept in mind in considering the property scene is the increased scale of acquisitions. The Law Reform Commission noted that each year the Commonwealth acquires an average of 2,000 properties, the majority of which are leasehold. However, approximately 700 are freehold and about 42 per cent of these are acquired by compulsory process. With this sort of legislation and that rate of acquisition, it is as well to remind ourselves that an obligation to justify a decision to deprive an individual of his or her property must rank second only to the obligation to justify a decision to deprive a person of his or her liberty. The landowner is entitled to, and should receive, `just terms' when land is compulsory acquired. It should be incumbent upon governments of the day to adhere to that concept and not impose undue hardship on those from whom they are acquiring land. With just treatment in mind, it is to be hoped the Minister will exercise restraint in using his powers to declare acquisitions `essential for the implementation of policy'.

This is new legislation and, undoubtedly, experience will show up deficiencies that will need to be remedied. It is, therefore, essential that the Government monitor carefully the operation of the Act and be prepared to introduce promptly amendments that are necessary. Possibly one of the most disturbing flaws in the legislation that has not been addressed by the Government is the question of blight following a public announcement of an impending acquisition without a pre-acquisition declaration being made. The gap between impending acquisition announcement and pre-acquisition declaration could be several years, perhaps longer, with the affected owners bereft of the protection provisions of the Act. This should form part of the first review of the legislation.

When the Minister responds to the second reading debate I ask him to give an assurance that there will be no delay in proclaiming the Act. I am aware that regulations have to be drafted. However, the Minister should be able to give an assurance that, at the latest, the Act will be proclaimed very early next year. Whilst the Opposition regrets that the Government has not addressed the question of injurious affection, it recognises that, although belated, this is a positive step forward. We will support the legislation and will keep the administration of it under review. We will be looking for ways to improve the legislation when we return to government after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We shall be waiting for a very long time if we are waiting for the Opposition to return to government before action is taken to bring changes to the legislation. It is rather sad that the very significant and positive steps that have been taken in the Lands Acquisition Bill have met with such faint praise. One would have thought that this very significant restructuring of the provisions which apply to ensure that Australians who have dealings with the Government and whose property is necessarily compulsorily acquired are fairly and effectively compensated would be welcomed with enthusiasm by both sides of this House. Of course, I am delighted that the Bill has the support of the Opposition, but it is a fairly grudging expression of support in the circumstances. The Bill has very significant features, It brings in more open processes in the acquisition system; it allows greater public accountability for decisions to acquire property; and it contains significantly more generous statutory provisions for compensation for persons deprived of their land by the Commonwealth. Each step is significant and important.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the first feature; that is, more open processes in the acquisition system. Prior to these very important developments there has been no onus on the Commonwealth to establish its need to acquire property. It has been left to an assertion of that need. Now the Commonwealth has seen fit to include in a Bill mechanisms to test the assertion of the Commonwealth that a particular proposal needs to proceed and that a particular acquisition is required for those purposes. That is a very significant step. Provisions in the Bill permit the Government, in circumstances where the national interest is involved, to carry out necessary works expeditiously but, in the main, the Government is subjecting itself to restraints which no previous government had and which significantly protect the interests of private individuals whose homes or properties might be subject to acquisition.

The second feature is public accountability. This Bill establishes a mechanism to ensure that not just the decision to acquire but also the question of compensation and the adequacy of compensation can be reviewed. Procedures are set out simply, in a clear form, which has never been done before. I will turn to those measures later in this discussion. Thirdly, the Bill establishes more generous statutory provisions for the compensation of persons, particularly those whose houses have been acquired. It is always wrenching if somebody has to lose his house. There has never been adequate provision in previous legislation to ensure that the additional emotional losses that are inevitable if somebody's home is taken from him are compensated for. This Bill will do that for the very first time by providing $10,000, which will be indexed forward-therefore, the amount will not lose its effective value-on top of whatever else is finally awarded and determined by way of compensation.

The Commonwealth is looking to a regime whereby those individuals who are unfortunate enough to be in a position in which the national interest requires that their home be taken for the provision of facilities, such as roads and airports, will not only get the market value of their property, plus whatever amounts are appropriate for injurious affection to their interests, but also an additional $10,000 to compensate them for the fact that they have lost their home and it involves the burden of emotional beliefs that we all have when we lose our homes. Those are very important steps which I think should be welcomed.

A rather fine irony is involved here because only recently the Opposition opposed a proposal, which was put to the Australian people by way of referendum, which would have entrenched similar rights-rights to fair compensation-not just applying to people who have dealings with the Commonwealth but also with the States. Many States, including Tasmania, have nowhere near adequate provisions of this nature to govern acquisition of lands by the State government concerned. That means that we now have double systems: if one's land is acquired by the Crown in right of the Commonwealth one will be protected, with guaranteed rights of appeal, procedural fairness and fair and adequate compensation, whereas those rights are not entrenched in a similar manner States' legislation or in States' Constitutions. This is because of the opposition to the referendum proposal by the Opposition which failed to address the issue with any degree of candour during the last debates on the referendum.

I welcome the measure as an implementation of an Australian Law Reform Commission document. It is often thought by critics of the law reform process that many documents emanate from the Law Reform Commission and not all are acted on. Some are said to gather dust, to be pigeon-holed and the like. It is pleasing when an important piece of work by the Commission eventually works its way through the system, gains the support of the Government and is brought into legislative form. This is one such example. The proposals in the Bill were based and modelled essentially on the work of the Law Reform Commission, following the reference given to the Commission in 1977 to examine the Commonwealth legislation. That report was tabled in the Parliament in April 1980. The Commission was critical of a number of aspects of the then Lands Acquisition Act which was modelled on 1845 United Kingdom legislation.

The Government has adopted the Law Reform Commission's report with only minor modifications. The form of the Bill reflects the thrust of the Commission's recommendations. It is very pleasing that the work of the Commission has been vindicated. It is important to note that the work of the Commission had been brought into fruition years later. The fact that a Commission report may not result in action immediately should not be seen as a suggestion that the report is worthless. For example, there is the instance of this report which was initiated in 1977 and tabled three years later. Now, in 1988, this Government is bringing in legislation to implement the recommendations of that Commission report.

Just by way of digression, I noticed this morning in my in-tray a discussion paper of the Law Reform Commission on product liability. I have now had the opportunity to read that and look at some of the proposals. The thrust of that recommendation is, firstly, that we need a very stringent form of liability to operate in the product area to make sure that those people who are victims of dangerous or negligent manufacture are adequately compensated, and secondly that we need to overcome some of the technical deficiencies of the law as it presently operates. I hope that that discussion paper stimulates the same kind of interest that the Law Reform Commission report on land acquisition did. I hope that ultimately it will result in appropriate legislative action in this Parliament to ensure that those people who are affected by badly made and dangerous products can get adequate compensation.

I return to the Bill. There are a couple of points on which I should comment. The first of these concerns the detail of what compensation elements will be taken into account. In the past it has always been a bit of a lawyer's nightmare to work out exact procedures for determining compensation. Of course, there are different approaches to the assessment of compensation. However, this Bill now sets out in a tabular form some of the elements to be taken into account. That will help in clarifying the process of the assessment of entitlements and make clear the benefits to which anybody from whom land is taken will be entitled.

Clause 55 of the Bill provides that compensation entitlements will be expanded to provide for disturbance, including loss or damage incurred as a reasonable consequence of the acquisition. Clause 55 of the Bill states also that such costs should at all times be reasonable, having regard to market rates, and that they should be directly related to the acquisition. Clause 59 states that compensation should be assessed on the basis that zoning restrictions for public uses are to be ignored provided that a claimant who bought the property in the knowledge of the restriction would not be entitled to compensation on a `without restriction' basis.

Where a person's principal place of residence is acquired and the compensation payable is insufficient to acquire a replacement house, clause 61 states that compensation is to be increased to enable the acquisition of a reasonable equivalent. That is a very important point, particularly given the way housing markets can operate. Of course, as well as that very important provision, there is the provision I mentioned earlier in relation to the additional compensation of $10,000 to be paid by way of recognition of the importance of an individual's house to that individual. Not only is there an economic interest but also an interest resulting from the various emotional ties that we have to our family homes.

These are important measures. None of us would wish that our property be taken from us by way of the Commonwealth seeking to develop a proposal of any kind. However, we accept and recognise the reality that governments need to acquire land for roads, airports and other public purposes. When that happens the individuals affected obviously have a right to be treated in an appropriate and fair manner. This Bill does that. This Bill follows the proposals that have been set out. It follows the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. It is a much more generous Bill than the provisions that previously applied. It is a streamlined Bill that makes clear what a person's entitlements will be. It gives adequate rights of appeal at two stages. Firstly, there is the stage at which it must be asked whether the acquisition should proceed at all. Secondly, there is the question of what is an appropriate measure of compensation for a person whose land has been acquired.

I welcome these provisions. Again, I say that it is rather sad that the Opposition's response has been so grudging in terms of its welcoming of this legislation. It has been said that the legislation has been accepted with regret. The Opposition is now seeking to move various amendments in the committee stage of the debate. I would have thought that a more appropriate response would have been to welcome the very important elements of this legislation and to recognise them for what they are: landmark changes in an area which affects individuals in the most important areas of their lives-that is, of course, the homes they own. With those remarks, I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to the remarks of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), the Opposition welcomes the Lands Acquisition Bill 1988. The honourable member for Denison might shortly have his seat resumed, because I am told that the previous member for Denison is very determined to do that. I can tell the honourable member that when it comes to profile in this place, by comparison with the former occupant of the seat he is the invisible man. The point is that the Opposition welcomes this legislation but, of course, in its proper role in supporting the people of Australia it has a responsibility to identify existing deficiencies in the area of lands acquisition. To that extent the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), has put forward an amendment relating to the mining industry-a very important industry to Australia-and the amendment is proper and correct. It makes the legislation a little better.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are aspects of the resumption of land by the Commonwealth that I think I should address on this occasion based on experiences that I have had as a member of Parliament. Of course, all such legislation gives effect to the Constitution itself. The honourable member for Denison suggested a short time ago that we should be criticised because of the recent referendum. He and his colleagues threw away $40-odd million of taxpayers' money on an exercise that the taxpayers did not want in the first place and then, in the second place, rejected very substantially. The honourable member was suggesting that as a Commonwealth we should have been imposing the same constitutional requirement on the States in regard to the acquisition of land. I must remind the honourable member, of course, that the people of Australia were never given the opportunity to make that decision. They had to answer either yes or no to a single question that required decisions on trial by jury, certain aspects of religion and the resumption of land in relation to the expression `just terms' in section 51 (xxxi) of the Constitution. That is hardly a simple choice. The honourable member should not blame the Opposition for its proper objection to that particular referendum question. He should blame his own Party for putting those matters to the people in that way.

There are aspects of this legislation which I welcome. I will talk about some of those, as I said, in the light of experience. I want to draw to the attention of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) some of the correspondence relating to this-he will be aware of some of the previous correspondence. We can legislate until we are blue in the face in this place. We can bring down quite excellent legislation. However, unless those in our bureaucracy administer such legislation in a fair and reasonable way-they do not use the power of secrecy or pure brute force, because they know in the end that they can have the land-it does not much matter how we legislate. It does not matter how we legislate if in fact those people in the bureaucracy are not fair to the people whose land they wish to acquire.

I think that the Law Reform Commission, in making its recommendations, took this into account. It has suggested revised acquisition powers, including the right of an affected owner to an independent review. The Commission is talking about an independent review prior to the Government proceeding to acquisition. I gather the Government has picked this up, which is interesting. In other words, people can put an argument to the Minister that he should not even contemplate the resumption of their land. That is excellent. It is much better. Mention is made of entitlement to remain in possession of the land for a period of time, speedier compensation and the advance of money, which is particularly necessary if someone's home is involved and another home has to be bought.

The point I want to make-this has been alluded to by the honourable member for Denison-is that the Bill adopts the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission that a home owner should never receive less than the cost of a reasonably equivalent dwelling. That has been a major sticking point with me for many years because, in the past, the valuation has been inappropriate. I have seen an example of this. Some people owned an old and somewhat decrepit building in an area that had declining residential value probably because the Commonwealth wanted some of the land. The valuer took these factors into account and the amount of money offered to these people was very low in comparison with what they needed to buy similar accommodation elsewhere. The people were clearly happy to remain living in that place. It was home. Under the old arrangements, the money they were offered could not buy anything of equivalent size in a more attractive suburb, which was all that was left. This Bill addresses that problem and, as has also been pointed out, provides for further compensation for the mere fact that a person's life is being disrupted through having to move to a different home.

I have also recently seen people forced out of their homes as a result of the assets test, merely because they lived on a block of land of, say, 100 acres. The family home was in the middle. It is interesting that the Government takes account of the fact that there should be some compensation for people being kicked out of the home that they may have raised their kids in and lived in all their lives. But under the assets test the Government says, `No, you have an asset. It is worthless to you and it brings in no rent. But we will take your pension off you because you own it. If you sell that house and move to the city, and all you have is a house on a suburban block, we will give you back your pension'. That is a pretty remarkable situation which, in another piece of Government legislation, the Government refuses to acknowledge.

Having taken the decision, as the Government has, to recognise the difficulty caused to home owners, one wonders why it is not prepared to extend that recognition to farmers and people with certain business properties, because they too frequently find themselves in the same situation, particularly farmers. The next time this legislation comes before the Parliament, or when we have an opportunity to debate it, I think there should be included within the arrangements a simple requirement for a fair swap. In other words, why is it necessary to get valuers and everybody else in when people could say, `You are taking me out of a three-bedroom home in a medium class suburb, and over there is a three-bedroom home in another middle class suburb. I will have that one. It is for sale, so you buy it for me. You do not have to resume it'. That could happen with farmers. It is very difficult for a farmer to move. A farmer knows his land. He knows which land he can use for certain crops. He has a complete understanding of his land and the soil types. Suddenly the Government wants the land for a particular purpose and it says, `Here is the money, that is about what it is worth'. I think the Government is taking too tough an approach on many of these occasions, sometimes to the detriment of its plans and ambitions. It says, `Take the money and buy another farm'. But it just so happens that no-one in the district wants to sell his farm this year, so that person has the money but has not got a farm to buy. I think people ought to be able to say to the Government, `If you want my land for a special purpose, I cannot argue with that, but you must get me something equivalent and I will shift as soon as you have got it'. If it is going to cost the Government extra money because somebody does not want to sell his land, it then becomes the Government's problem, not the owner's. He is comfortable and does not want to move.

I mentioned earlier how our bureaucracy often deals with people in this situation. I have here a simple case history. I have corresponded with the Minister about it at different times, as well as with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). It is an interesting case. The Government with my support-it did not ask for my approval-wanted to build a base in my electorate to monitor overseas telecommunications and things of that nature. Many chose to call it a spy base, but I did not. During the last election campaign all the candidates in Geraldton, where the base is being constructed, were campaigning on a simple platform. When a questioner asked me, the Liberal Party candidate, my opponent, the Australian Labor Party candidate, and some other candidates whether we supported or opposed the establishment of that base in that town, I spoke strongly in favour of it and the Labor candidate spoke against it. It must never be said that I was taking an opportunity to do anything other than to support this project. I supported it because I thought it was good for my district and I rejected the ridiculous arguments by some that it would become an atomic target. These monitoring stations are the very stations that record rocket launches. Without such stations we would have to find other ways of detecting and destroying them. No self-respecting general, I am sure, would want that to happen.

Land was needed and a particular farm was identified. These people wrote to me pointing out that on about 27 March an officer from a department rang up and said that the department wanted to talk about a satellite site. The people were getting ready to put their crops in. Three days later they received a visit and were told that their farm was one of five sites to be considered, but not to worry about that because it was unlikely that theirs would be chosen. They were told that they had a very large farm and it would be necessary, if their farm was chosen, to resume about half of it, about 500 hectares. Only 50 hectares would actually be required but the rest would be needed for a buffer zone and would be leased back to them. They could continue to farm it. But again they were told it was most unlikely that would occur.

On 11 May another departmental officer-I would love to use his name because it really personifies everything that happened, but I feel I cannot as it would be a bit unfair-came to talk to these people. On 19 May a telegram was phoned through for them to contact someone else. All this time these people were trying to get ready for the harvest, but they kept getting told it did not matter. On 25 May there was further communication. On 26 May this same fellow rang and said that the people would be able to keep farming the land, that they had nothing to worry about. But, as they said, by this time they had still received nothing in writing. The reason given was that the department had not made a decision. It was then suggested, `You had better get ready and ask the Government to give you some professional assistance'. I would concur. But we find that after some more discussion and after these people had written a letter, on about 4 June or 5 June this fellow rang back and said that there was no help available and that they had better get their own.

These people did not want to sell their farm, they wanted to stay there. Time went by. On 17 June they were told that four people were coming to dig up some ground. Still more telephone calls were made but there was nothing in writing-nothing formal; no evidence. Two four-wheel drive vehicles arrived and something that sounds, from their description, like a back hoe turned up and started digging holes in their ground. On 24 June, seven days later, surveyors turned up and started doing contour work. On 25 June an engineer came and told them he had been in touch with everybody else around the countryside, but the people still had nothing to worry about because there was one other site the department was still looking at. Then, on 1 July, Warren somebody or other turned up-they did not know who he was-and on 15 July they were told to get a valuer, again over the telephone. There was no formal proposal. On 23 July they were told that more people were coming to see them.

On 30 July they were told what the Government's valuation was but still they had received nothing in writing. Something referred to as a licence, which was supposed to be a lease for the leaseback of this land, was then produced to them. This is very significant because the value was based on the fact that they were going to keep most of their land. But, in fact, they found it was to be a licence to use the land and that it could be revoked at any time the Commonwealth felt like it. As they said, it was totally contradictory. By this time these people were looking at losing half their farm but it was viable if the leased section could be negotiable. In the early stages they told the people that if they put the mast where it was going to be they would not be able to get to half their land; it just blocked it off. Again, there was nothing in writing. In this letter it states:

30th July . . . The draft he brought with him was unfeasible as a farming lease-and anyway was contradicting what they had lead us to believe-that we'd always have the use of the buffer zone-Still nothing in writing-the lease draft etc he took away with him as he only had one copy . . .

On 7 August they got more phone calls asking them to come to Perth. They were told that on 10 September an independent valuer, people from the Housing Commission and an archaeologist, were coming out to survey the access road. The Government started to worry about the environment but it still had not told these people in any formal way how much money they would get and it had not done anything for them. When the money was eventually offered, it was substantially insufficient. The whole time they were being told, `Don't tell a soul; don't talk to anyone; don't talk to your member of parliament; it's all secret and remember, it might not happen'. Of course this went on and on. On 15 September as this letter states:

Served a notice to treat-left maps etc. Said their valuers had . . . finished doing their new value. We had 4 days to reply (actually 13). John said it would be gazetted on 9th Oct. and that the value would be effective on that date-The licence that John left us is totally unfeasible in a farming situation. So to sum up.
All their talk of us being able to always farm it, was just bluff and we were too trusting, too busy seeding or too naive to realise the implications.

This law will improve those sorts of things but the funny fact about it was that I wrote to the Minister for Defence at one stage and told him that the one thing I had to warn him about, in the Government's own interest, was not to deal unfairly with these people because he was handing a club to the opponents of the base. Of course, as history has proved, they grabbed it. The then Senator Wood, Senator Vallentine and others stood up in the Senate and poured their hearts out on behalf of these people. The people of the district who had accepted that this base was going to be built there and had seen some value in it, were harassed and, of course, all rose up in defence of these farmers. But those who were leading the push were not interested in the farmers. They wanted to stop the base. The Government was not even smart for itself.

I tell that story because it is worth understanding that it will not matter if we do not ensure that the bureaucracy deals fairly with the people. When it comes to the situation of resuming people's land, we should always be generous because it is a major disruption to them. The shadow Minister also raised the matter of Badgerys Creek. I will close on that. What is going on there is outrageous. The simple fact is that once a government identifies an area and says, `We'll build an airport here', nobody can sell his land to anybody but the Government. It is absolutely outrageous to then say, `Look, we're not ready to resume it yet. We really haven't got our plans together. We really don't know when we want your land. Tell you what, if you want to sell it ring us up and we'll negotiate'. The Government would then be the only organisation wanting to buy the land.

I would like to be in that position when I am doing a bit of shopping because I know what price I would get it at. Of course, some of these people need to sell. They have plans to build and construct but all that is finished. They would like to do it somewhere else. It should not be that way. Once the Government makes an announcement of that type it should be obliged to resume the land immediately. If it is not going to do it, it should not make the announcement in the first place.

We know why this announcement was made. It would not proceed with the proper arrangements under the plans of the Minister in the previous Government to give us a second runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. We could be landing on it now. We would not be stacked on 20 minute flights with half an hour waiting times and huge costs to taxpayers and to the community. We would have lost all that. But to overcome that and find an excuse for the disaster that is Sydney Airport, the Government made the announcement of where it was going. It has affected the lives of 200 or 300 families and now it is not acting properly with those people. I hope that this legislation will improve that situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank those who have contributed to this brief debate. Shortly we will be going into the committee stage. As the shadow Minister for administrative services, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), said, this Lands Acquisition Bill has had a long gestation period. That was not only under our Government but also under the former Government. Honourable members opposite were in power when this long process started. As the shadow Minister has said, the Bill must give and does give owners an appeals process to ensure that they get just compensation when their land is compulsorily acquired. I am sure that everyone will agree that that is what this Bill is all about. It sets up-as the shadow Minister and others have said-an appeals process to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). On the issue of a primary decision to acquire, the AAT may make a recommendation to the Minister. But on the matter of determination of compensation, the decision of the AAT is of course determinatory or the owner, if he wishes, can bypass the AAT and go straight to the Federal Court of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of points have been raised by the shadow Minister, particularly the question of blight. Of course that issue raises the secondary issue of the commencement of the acquisition process. That issue has been well canvassed during the debate. I have considered the argument that a government's announcement of an intention to acquire property should trigger the acquisition process. That suggestion has been made and I am satisfied that it is simply not appropriate to do that. The Law Reform Commission spent considerable time looking at this question of blight and when the acquisition process should be deemed to have commenced. It concluded that the only realistic way of starting the acquisition process was by issue of a pre-acquisition declaration to the owners.

I must agree with Opposition speakers and others that there is a problem with blight being inadvertently created by a government, by a ministerial statement or even by pure speculation. Certainly, the land may be required for a public purpose. However, the suggestion that a government or ministerial announcement should be the legal trigger for activating the processes in this Bill really bristles with difficulties as was recognised by the Law Reform Commission. For instance, what would constitute an announcement? How would an announcement clearly identify the land involved? How would the Government ensure that all owners were aware of the announcement? If the Government knew that an announcement would start the acquisition process, it probably would not make an announcement until it was ready to start that process. It would be necessary to define in the legislation precisely what constitutes an announcement or statement of intention.

The point is that when we get to that level of precision we have what is effectively a pre-acquisition declaration. All these difficulties are overcome, in my view, by starting the process with a pre-acquisition declaration to owners, as recommended by the Law Reform Commission. I agree that that is not totally satisfactory, but one cannot deny the problems that are associated with the alternate approach. However, the legislation can specify what information is to be included in the pre-acquisition declaration, the land involved can be clearly and accurately identified, and all owners can be separately notified.

The Law Reform Commission also observed that where many properties were to be acquired for the one project an announcement starting the process would initiate acquisition of all properties at the one time. The Commission did recognise that there could be situations in which it might be impossible to start acquisition of all properties at the one time and complete those acquisitions within some specified time, even if the government made sufficient funds available. In such cases the issuing of pre-acquisition declarations progressively may be the only practical way of dealing with these multiple acquisitions. Consequently the Commission in its report recommended that the acquisition process be started not by a general or specific announcement by government; rather the process should be started by the issuing of a pre-acquisition declaration. My answer to the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Hume, is that all these problems exist and have been considered by both the Commission and the Government. The Bill adopts all the recommendations made by the Law Reform Commission in this regard.

I turn to the question of injurious affection-the shadow Minister and other speakers also raised this matter-where no land is acquired and alternatively where part of a person's property is acquired. We considered the Law Reform Commission's recommendations concerning injurious affection where no land is acquired, and decided that we could not incorporate these recommendations in the Bill. I will give honourable members the reasons for that decision. Firstly, we believe that the issue is of much wider scope than being simply related to land acquisition as a specific issue. It is a land use planning issue. These matters obviously have to be considered at that point; that is, before the primary decision to go on with the project is actually made. Secondly, some related investigations-in particular those of the House of Representatives Select Committee on Aircraft Noise-were under way. The costs to Federal and State governments are simply impossible to predict, but would be extremely high. I do not run away from stating this; as I have said, several deputations came to see me on this matter. The Commission's proposal did not resolve some of the fundamental issues, such as how to measure the change in the value of a property that occurs due to the Commonwealth's actions and no other factor; at what point the effect would be measured-that is, at the planning stage, the completion of development or some years after the activity has commenced; and to whom the compensation shall be paid. If a prospective application is adopted, people who have suffered the injurious affection for years might not be paid compensation, but a neighbour affected by some minor change who had not been affected initially might be paid compensation.

I will deal now with a situation which will be dealt with by amendment in the committee stage-I want to offer something on this vexatious matter-that is, where part of a property is acquired by the compulsory process. The current Act does provide for injurious affection in a particular circumstance; namely, where compensation is to be paid for the compulsory acquisition of a part but not all of a property. It is a provision, strangely enough, which is used fairly infrequently. The current Act gives virtually no direction as to how that compensation should be assessed. It has all the deficiencies of the Law Reform Commission proposal. Furthermore, it is inequitable because it provides for an owner to be paid compensation for the deleterious effect the Commonwealth activities may have on the remainder of his property as long as the smallest portion of the land is acquired; whereas, although the neighbour suffers equally, if none of the neighbour's land is acquired, that neighbour would not be entitled to be paid any compensation at all. So there is even a problem in deciding what to do about the situation which is now covered by the current Act.

I have considered these matters and, on balance, I would affirm the Government's earlier decision that injurious affection where no land is acquired needs to be considered in a wider context, as I set out earlier, than the Commonwealth's land acquisition legislation; that is, basically at the planning stage-whether or not the project ought to go in a particular position at all if, for instance, there are lots of people and small landholders around. For that reason, the Bill should not contain any provision for the payment of compensation on the grounds of injurious affection where no land is acquired. I will be proposing an amendment to the Bill after full consultation with the Opposition spokesman and with organisations such as the Land Acquisition Reform Committee. This amendment will incorporate a provision contained in the current Act whereby the enhancement or depreciation of the remainder of an owner's land caused by the public use of the land acquired from that person shall be taken into account in assessing compensation.

The shadow Minister raised some other matters regarding possible improvements to the Bill. He referred to the new provisions which will apply to applications for mining on Commonwealth land other than Antarctica and national parks. He wants to retain the provision in the current Act, which I understand sets out that mining will occur under the current State legislation. Basically, that is what we intend anyway. I will not be accepting the amendment, but I will explain why in detail-I hope the Opposition will accept that explanation-in the committee stage. I will not take up any more time right now. The question of essentiality in clauses 24 and 22-that is, the Minister's right to declare essentiality and thus exclude appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-has been referred to. I will be proposing an amendment; that is, the deletion of clause 24 (1) (b) but the retention of the provisions of clause 22. I will explain my reasons for that in detail during the committee stage. I hope I have dealt adequately with these matters at this point and will extend those explanations during the committee stage and will deal with the arguments raised by the shadow Minister.

I will now refer very briefly to some of the points raised by other speakers. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) made a very good speech on this issue and he correctly praised the Law Reform Commission. I do not think anyone else did that and I praise the Commission too, as I praised the decision of the former Government many years ago to set up the inquiry. As the honourable member for Denison said, this is how the parliamentary democratic process should work and at the end of the day, as he said, it has worked, despite the lengthy time frame. We have had the referral, the report, the Government consideration and the re-assessment by myself when I took my current office. We have had a Bill introduced, a long period of consultation, and now we are discussing the proposed legislation which, I believe, will lead to a new Act which Justice Murray Wilcox said will be equal to, if not better than any other-even if we do not do anything more and we are planning to do more to the Bill very soon. We will have an Act without peer in the English-speaking world, and that is high praise indeed. It certainly was time that the Act was overhauled. The current Act dates back to 1955 and that legislation was simply based on the 1906 legislation, which was based on the United Kingdom legislation enacted in the 1840s; so, in effect, we are changing something now that has endured for almost 150 years. As the honourable member for Denison has said, that is an achievement.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) raised a very important point. I do not agree in total with what he said, particularly towards the end of his speech, but I certainly agree with him when he points out that it does not matter how good legislation is, at the end of the day if the Minister, the Government and the public servants who administer the Act are not seriously concerned with applying its intent, somewhere along the way the legislation may break down.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is quite right.

—I agree with that. Perhaps he missed the fundamental point. He should have gone on and said that this legislation is good legislation because it understands that salient point and provides a framework-except in certain cases which I think should be there; that is, urgency and cases where national security might be prejudiced-to protect the rights of the individual against the bureaucratic mismanagement which sometimes occurs and which has been referred to. The honourable member, having said that there is a danger that the best of legislation can be subverted, ought to have gone on and said that this legislation at least takes us a long way down the track to creating a situation in which the individual's rights are protected and he or she has an avenue of challenge. I thank the three people who have contributed to the debate. I believe we should now move to the committee stage where I propose to move a number of amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 2, line 7, omit ``and''.
(2) Clause 5, page 2, line 8, omit ``both the law and this Act'', substitute ``that law''.

``and (c) this Act requires that the authority acquire or dispose of the interest in accordance with this Act;''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate, in order to save time, that the Opposition agrees with the amendments proposed by the Minister and on only one or two occasions do I need to make comments. I indicate to the committee at this stage that I shall not take up the time of the committee by speaking each time the Minister moves amendments.
—That would be very helpful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 6, page 2, line 39, insert ``or Norfolk Island'' after ``Northern Territory''.

The amendment alters the definition of a Commonwealth authority. In the Bill as drafted Norfolk Island statutory authorities would have been included as acquiring authorities. As with Northern Territory Government statutory authorities, the Norfolk Island statutory authorities are not intended to be bound by the Bill in recognition of the self-government arrangements there. Hence I propose that the definition of Commonwealth authority be amended to exclude authorities incorporated under a law of the Norfolk Island territory.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Clause 6, page 3, line 13, insert ``and a right of redemption'' after ``option''.
(6) Clause 6, page 3, lines 29 to 31, omit the definition of ``owner''.
(7) Clause 6, page 3, lines 39 to 44, omit the definition of ``public purpose'', substitute the following definition:
`` `public purpose' means a purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws and includes, in relation to land in a Territory, any purpose in relation to the Territory;''.

These are technical amendments to the definitions in clause 6. Amendment (5) clarifies that an interest in land can include an interest associated with a mortgage. Amendment (6) deletes the definition of an owner. Concern had been expressed in comments that the original definition would have excluded a person who held an interest in land which he could not assign to others, an example being a person holding some form of mining tenement which could only be returned to the State. It is not intended that such persons be excluded, so this is a technical amendment to clear that up. Amendment (7) clarifies the definition of a public purpose by removing a part of the original definition which was simply found to be superfluous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 21, page 8, line 2, omit ``An acquiring'', substitute ``Subject to subsection (2), an acquiring''.
(10) Clause 21, page 8, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:
``(2) Nothing in this Act prevents the benefit of a restriction on the use of land becoming vested in an authority by the operation of a law other than this Act.

``(3) In spite of paragraphs 48 (1) (b) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, regulations made for the purpose of paragraph (1) (b) of this section may provide that the regulations shall take effect on a date to be fixed by the Minister by notice published in the Gazette.
``(4) The Minister shall not fix a date for the purpose of subsection (3) that is earlier than:
(a) the last day on which a notice could be given under subsection 48 (4) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 in relation to the regulations; or
(b) if such a notice is given, the latest day on which the regulations could be disallowed by a House of the Parliament in which such a notice has been given.''.

Clause 21 provides that the Commonwealth shall acquire land in accordance with this Bill. This provision is, however, subject to a series of exceptions and concern has been expressed about the provision which allows exemption from the Bill by regulation at clause 21 (b). In this regard it has been suggested that an acquiring authority could be exempted soon after the Senate rises and an acquisition completed outside the terms of the Bill before the Senate and the House of Representatives had the opportunity to consider and perhaps disallow the exemption. I must say that this concern is equally applicable to other legislation which provides for the making of regulations.

More significantly, under the existing legislation exemption is effected simply by gazettal of a ministerial decision. The exemption provisions contained in the Bill provide for parliamentary scrutiny and are consistent with those proposed by the Law Reform Commission. However, it is unlikely that exemption of an authority would be required so quickly that it would not be possible to allow parliamentary scrutiny of the intention to exempt before the exemption took effect. So I am proposing these amendments to prevent the acquisition by an exempted authority until after parliamentary scrutiny of the exemption has taken place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

Clause 22 (Declaration that land is suitable for acquisition).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 22, page 8, lines 22 to 36, omit subclauses (1), (2) and (3), substitute the following subclauses:
``(1) The Minister may declare in writing that the Minister is considering the acquisition by an acquiring authority of an interest in land (other than a mortgage interest) for a public purpose.
``(2) The declaration shall identify the acquiring authority, the land, the interest in the land and the public purpose.
``(3) Except where the interest is a restriction on the use of land, the Minister shall include in the declaration:
(a) a statement that the land appears to the Minister to be suitable for use, or for development for use, for a public purpose; and
(b) a statement setting out:
(i) particulars of the use to which the land will be put or for which it will be developed; and
(ii) the reasons why the land appears to be suitable for that use or for development for that use.
``(4) Where the interest is a restriction on the use of land, the Minister shall include in the declaration:
(a) a statement that it appears to the Minister to be appropriate for the acquiring authority to be given, for a public purpose, the benefit of the restriction on the use of the land; and
(b) a statement:
(i) explaining the nature of the restriction; and
(ii) setting out the reasons why it is appropriate for the acquiring authority to be given the benefit of the restriction.

``(5) The Minister may include in the declaration a statement that the proposed use of the land, or the proposed restriction on the use of the land, as the case may be, is connected with the implementation of a policy particulars of which are set out in the declaration.''.

This is a technical amendment to clause 22, which describes the information that is to be provided in a pre-acquisition declaration. The Bill, as introduced, requires that a pre-acquisition declaration shall contain a description of the use the Commonwealth intends to make of the land to be acquired. Where the interest to be acquired is a restriction on use there may be no actual use of the land. This amendment provides for such a situation.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 23 agreed to.
Clause 24 (Acquisitions where land required urgently etc.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 24, page 10, line 7, insert ``or'' after ``declaration;''.
(13) Clause 24, page 10, lines 8 to 10, omit paragraph (b) and the word ``or'' following it.

These amendments, which are perhaps the most important amendments, have been requested by the Land Acquisition Reform Committee, Justice Murray Wilcox and a whole host of other people. The Law Reform Commission, in its report on the Commonwealth's land acquisition legislation, recommended that there should be two instances where a pre-acquisition declaration need not be given and from which there would be no right of appeal either to the Minister or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) about the decision to acquire. These were in cases of urgency, or, as I said in my reply to the second reading debate, where national security requirements prevented disclosure of details of the proposed land use. This was incorporated in clause 24 of the Bill.

The Administrative Review Council recommended that a third situation should have a constraint on appeal to the AAT-namely, where the Minister is satisfied and certifies that it is in the public interest that a particular parcel of land be acquired for a public purpose; in other words, where it is essential that the specified land be acquired because there was no other option. The Bill includes this recommendation at clause 24 (1) (b).

It has been suggested that since the essentiality provision excludes review, its use could negate the benefits of the Bill. One of the most significant features of the Bill is the appeal provision. The concern is that the essentiality clause might be used frequently for the express purpose of denying an owner access to that appeal provision, although it could be argued that the same criticism applies to the other two provisions which the Law Reform Commission proposed-that is, the urgency and security provisions. I understand the concerns that people have with this provision. It is in the Bill because the Government decided that it would accept the argument put forward by the Administrative Review Council, that in such instances there would be no review by the AAT of the decision to acquire.

Circumstances where this provision might be used would arise, I reckon, infrequently. But from time to time it happens that the Commonwealth has a need to acquire property that is very location specific. For example, the Commonwealth may need to acquire a small parcel of land for a communications repeater station that requires line of sight to other such stations and, because of the terrain, only one place meets the requirement. The Administrative Review Council expressed the view that in such instances appeal to the AAT should be precluded provided that the Minister makes a public declaration that the acquisition is essential. Such a declaration would indicate the Government's commitment to the acquisition, making review by the AAT redundant, given that the Government is not bound to accept the recommendation of the AAT. The Council believed that it was highly desirable that the Minister remain politically accountable for such decisions.

The essentiality provision is cited twice in the Bill-initially at clause 22 (4), where a pre-acquisition declaration would be issued and an appeal to the Minister to reconsider would be available but appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal would not be available; and, secondly, at clause 24 (1) (b) where there would be no pre-acquisition declaration and therefore no appeal to the Minister or the AAT.

So I am proposing an amendment that deletes the more severe of these provisions at clause 24 (1) (b). However, I am of the view that clause 22 (4) should remain unaltered because in its present form the need for public accountability is met. If a Minister chose to use this provision he would not be able to do it without the details of what the Minister was doing becoming public. A pre-acquisition declaration would be issued to anyone affected by the acquisition and copies of the declaration would have to be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and in a newspaper circulated in the area where the land was located. Furthermore, if an owner of land being acquired using this provision believed that the provision was being misused, he would be able to appeal to the Federal Court under the provisions of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

It has been suggested that the availability of such an appeal should be made clear. However, I am advised that it is neither necessary nor desirable to amend clause 22 (4) to refer to an appeal of this nature. it is not necessary because any decision is reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act unless specifically or generally excluded. This decision has not been excluded in any way from the provisions of the Act. Furthermore, it is not desirable to insert a particular reference to the availability of such an appeal in this clause because if that were inserted, for consistency a similar insertion would be required anywhere in the Bill where an administrative decision is involved. I understand the concern that has given rise to the suggestion. In recognition of that concern, I will have the explanatory memorandum to the Bill amended to incorporate reference to the normal availability of appeal under the AD (JR) Act in this situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes this amendment. As I indicated, we support all the amendments that the Minister is proposing but, because I specifically referred to this matter in the second reading debate, I wanted to say that the advice available to me is identical to the advice available to the Minister. There is no need-and indeed, it would not be desirable-to include in this Bill a reference to the fact that land owners in appropriate circumstances could appeal to the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. During the second reading debate I asked whether the Minister would confirm that his advice was in line with ours. He has done so and I thank him for it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

Clause 31 (Consideration to be taken into account on review).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 31, page 13, lines 5 to 12, omit paragraphs (1) (a), (b), (c), (d) and (e), substitute the following paragraphs:
``(a) the nature of the public purpose identified in the declaration;
(b) except where the relevant interest in land is a restriction on the use of land:
(i) the nature of the proposed use of the relevant land;

This is a set of technical amendments to clause 31 which clarify the considerations which the Administrative Appeals Tribunal may take into account when dealing with a review of a decision to acquire where the interest to be acquired is a restriction on the use of land. These amendments are required because clause 31 of the Bill as introduced spoke in terms of the proposed use of land where the interest is in fact a restriction on the use, such as in a restricted area around some Commonwealth establishments where there might not be any actual use.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 32 agreed to.
Clause 33 (Minister to consider Administrative Appeals Tribunal's recommendations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Clause 33, page 14, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:
``(2) The Minister is not entitled to reject a recommendation of the Tribunal more than 90 days after the decision of the Tribunal comes into operation.''.
(19) Clause 33, page 14, line 33, omit ``15'', substitute ``3''.

Clause 33 provides that, where the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has completed its review of an appeal against the decision to acquire, the Tribunal will make a recommendation to the Minister and the Minister will be able to accept or reject that recommendation. The Bill does not specify that the Minister shall make that decision within a particular period. The Bill does specify a period that must follow the AAT's recommendation before the Commonwealth can proceed to acquire. That time period is 28 days. It is specified to enable an owner to seek a review of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's finding on matters of law through the Federal Court as provided in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act.

The Law Reform Commission in its draft Bill did not specify a time in which a Minister must decide whether or not to proceed with an acquisition following the recommendation from the AAT, taking the view that it was not possible to legislate to force a government to take a decision within a specified period. However, in response to the suggestions made to me, I believe that in this instance it is reasonable to place some time limit on the Minister because otherwise the Minister could delay his decision indefinitely. Consequently, I propose to amend the clause so that, if the Minister is to reject the Administrative Appeals Tribunal's recommendation, he must do so within 90 days.

Furthermore, the Bill requires that the Minister must notify Parliament if he rejects the recommendation from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and that he must do so within 15 sitting days. Comments provided to me suggest that this period is unnecessarily long. I also accept that view, and I am proposing an amendment that the Minister must table a notice of rejection of an AAT recommendation within three sitting days.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
