SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20) Clause 41, page 17, line 35, omit ``declaration interest'', substitute ``interest identified in the declaration''.
This is purely a technical amendment to clause 41 to clarify that reference in the Bill to a declaration interest means reference to an interest identified in the pre-acquisition declaration.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 42 to 45-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 46 (Disallowance of acquisition of interest in land in public park).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Clause 46, page 20, line 12, omit ``28 days'', substitute ``7 sitting days of that House''.

Clause 42 of the Bill provides that land in a public park can be acquired by the Commonwealth provided that a particular set of requirements is met. These conditions are as follows: There must be a full environmental inquiry unless both Houses of Parliament veto the need for a full inquiry. Even if both Houses do veto the need for a full inquiry, any other requirement of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act must still be met. In particular, where the property is a World Heritage property or on the Register of the National Estate, an environmental impact statement must be prepared. The relevant State must also agree to acquisition of the land. After the acquisition has been gazetted, either House of Parliament can disallow it.

In my view that process provides a means whereby inconsequential acquisition in public parks can occur. At the same time, this process provides appropriate checks and balances to ensure that acquisitions of some consequence in public parks cannot occur without appropriate scrutiny. In stipulating this process, the Bill provides in clause 46 that the Parliament be notified of the acquisition of land in public parks and that, within 28 days after the notification, either House can pass a resolution disallowing the acquisition. Concern has been expressed at the 28 day limit. It is suggested that it would be possible for the information to be tabled at the end of a parliamentary session and that either House might not have time to consider the matter adequately.

It should be noted that the current Act provides a power to either House to veto any compulsory acquisition that is undertaken, stipulating that this must be done within 30 days of notification of the acquisition. That time limit as stipulated in the current Act has not led to the situation that the comments suggest might arise, but even so I am sympathetic to the concerns that have been expressed. On the other hand, there needs to be a balance between the desirability of allowing either House sufficient time to consider the matter against the need for the Commonwealth to act following the acquisition. In practice, although the Commonwealth may have acquired the land once it is gazetted, the Commonwealth is not really in a position to make use of the land as intended until after the potential parliamentary disallowance period has expired. Under these circumstances, I believe that the best approach is to specify the disallowance period in terms of a number of sitting days, and I propose to amend the period from 28 calendar days to seven sitting days.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 47 to 54-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 55 (Amount of compensation-general principles).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 55, page 23, line 32, omit ``and''.
(23) Clause 55, page 23, after subparagraph (2) (a) (iii) insert the following word and subparagraph:

``and (iv) where the acquisition has the effect of severing the acquired interest from another interest, any increase or decrease in the market value of the interest still held by the person resulting from the nature of, or the carrying out of, the purpose for which the acquired interest was acquired;''.

These are the amendments I referred to earlier. I have received several comments about the lack of provision in the Bill for the payment of compensation for injurious affection where the Commonwealth's use of land causes a diminution of value of a person's property. There are two situations that arise here: firstly, where no land is acquired by the Commonwealth; and secondly, where part of a person's land is acquired. Regarding the first situation, the Government considered the Australian Law Reform Commission's recommendations on injurious affection and decided that this Bill would not incorporate them. As I mentioned earlier, the reasons for that decision include the fact that the issue is of much wider scope than, being related simply to land acquisition, it is in the primary instance a land use planning issue.

Some related investigations were under way, particularly the investigation by the House of Representatives committee inquiry into aircraft noise, at the time we took this decision. The costs to government were difficult to predict but would no doubt be very high, not only to the Commonwealth but to the various States. The Law Reform Commission proposal did not resolve some of the fundamental issues-such issues, for instance, as how to measure the change in value of a property that occurs due to the Commonwealth's actions and no other factor; at what point in time the effect should be measured-at the planning stage, at the completion of the development, or some years after the activity has commenced; and to whom compensation should be paid. Consequently, the Bill does not incorporate compensation for injurious affection where no land is acquired.

In the second instance-where part of a person's property is acquired by compulsory process-the current Act does provide for the assessment of compensation to take into account any decrease or increase in the value of the remaining part of the person's property as a result of the Commonwealth's activities on the part acquired. It has been suggested that the same provision at least should be carried into this Bill, and I agree. This Bill has as one of its main objectives the intention that compensation provisions will be improved compared with those under the current Act. In my view, if this aspect of injurious affection were not included in this Bill, then the Bill could be seen as detracting from the present provision. In these amendments I am proposing that the provisions of compensation for injurious affection, where part of a property is acquired by compulsory process, should be incorporated in this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the amendment that has been moved by the Minister. As I indicated earlier, we support this and the other amendments he has moved. They have certainly improved the original Bill in so far as injurious affection is concerned. As I pointed out in my speech on the second reading, this is a very important element and certainly a very important reference that was made to the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Committee might recall that I advised the House that the then Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, pointed out that it was an area that needed looking at as legislation in Britain and Canada had, to some extent, dealt with the problem. I do not underestimate the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I want the Committee and the Minister to understand that I and the Opposition appreciate the drafting and administrative difficulties associated with this matter. However, it is a very important matter, and a moment ago the Minister said that his advice indicates that the cost to government could be very high. If the cost to government could be very high, that indicates that the loss to people is also very high. We cannot have one without the other. If that is the case, then the Government and the Parliament are neglecting a very important area. I have not proposed an amendment; I do not intend to. I think a great deal of thought and consideration needs to go into it before an amendment is proposed. To propose an amendment just to make a point would, I think, be irresponsible of the Opposition. What I did ask the Minister to consider during my speech on the second reading was the establishment of some kind of task force. He has pointed out that it is not only this Bill, when it becomes an Act, that injurious affection will apply to. Maybe the Government would consider establishing a task force or making another reference to the Law Reform Commission or some other body that could provide technical advice to see how this issue could be properly addressed and then make public the findings of that investigation.

It is a very important issue. As I said, I appreciate the difficulties. If I thought there was an easy solution then the Opposition would be moving an amendment. I ask the Minister again through you, Mr Deputy Chairman, to at least consider, and perhaps advise me at a later date, whether the Government is prepared to look at this matter again.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 56 and 57-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 58 (No general market for interest acquired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Clause 58, page 25, omit the last 2 lines of subclause 58 (3), substitute:
``FI is the present value of any real and substantial saving in recurring costs (relating to land or an interest in land) gained by the person as a result of the relocation.''.

This is a technical amendment. Clause 58 of the Bill describes how compensation is to be assessed where the Commonwealth acquires property which has no general market value, such as a church or a school. The basis of that approach is that sufficient compensation will be paid to enable the former owner to relocate the facility, although that amount would be reduced by the amount the owner had improved his financial position. This amendment simply clarifies that for the purpose of this clause the replacement by a new facility of an old facility does not in itself improve an owner's financial position, although some clearly identifiable reduction in future maintenance and operating costs would be an improvement of an owner's financial position.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 59 and 60-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 61 (Acquisition of a dwelling).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Clause 61, page 26, line 33, omit ``$5,000'', substitute ``$10,000 (or that amount as indexed by section 126)''.

We propose to make a solace payment to people whose homes or primary places of residence are acquired by compulsory process, in recognition of the often intangible value attached to a home or the owner outside of any commercial value. This once only payment will be additional to any amount of compensation determined for the acquisition as a whole. I think it is only reasonable that individuals should receive some recompense for those personal aspects of home ownership that cannot be valued in a commercial sense. It is, of course, these personal attachments and memories which for whatever reason, often cause the greatest distress to persons when they are required to vacate their homes. The legislation as originally drafted provided for a payment of $5,000 in each case.

Several groups in the community have expressed concern about three specific aspects of solatium payments: firstly, the amount of the payment being incorporated in the body of the Bill rather than in regulations makes it difficult to alter, particularly if the amount of the solatium payment is to keep pace with inflation; secondly, the specification of a single figure does not recognise the difference in the value of different homes and, thirdly, the amount is too low. I think the first point is valid to the extent that it is more difficult to amend an Act than it is to amend regulations. However, incorporation of the amount in the Act at least makes clear the Government's intention about the quantum of the amount that should be paid.

If the amount was left to be specified in regulations to the Act there could be criticism on the grounds that the Act itself should indicate the order of magnitude of the payment that the Government considers appropriate. Comments have been received from several sources suggesting that any difficulties associated with amending the value of the payment could be overcome by writing in a provision for an automatic upgrading. This could be achieved by amending the clause to provide for an increase in the value of the payment in line with some index. I agree with that view and I propose an amendment which would increase the amount annually in line with the consumer price index (CPI).

I now turn to the second area of concern-solace payments and the different value of homes. When the Government considered the proposition for a solace payment it considered a number of options. Some States provide a householder solatium with the amount to be paid linked to the value of the property. The Government believes that that is not a valid basis for payment since the intangible losses suffered by less affluent socioeconomic groups are not necessarily less and, in fact, may be greater than those suffered by more affluent groups whose properties are valued much higher. The Australian Law Reform Commission proposed some broad criteria that could be applied-for example, interest in the property; length of occupancy; and inconvenience caused by having to move-to determine the amount of solace compensation. However, the Government considers that the application of such criteria would depend largely on value judgments. That is something to be avoided because of possible disagreement and disputation. Therefore, we decided on a fixed statutory payment for each residence so acquired.

Regarding the third matter of concern-that is, the amount of the payment-I agree that the figure of $5,000 is now too low. Therefore, I propose that the amount be specified as $10,000 which, as I mentioned earlier, will be increased each year in line with the CPI.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 62 to 95-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 96 (Entitlement to compensation-pre-acquisition declaration made but acquisition not proceeded with).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (26) Clause 96, pages 41 and 42, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Entitlement to compensation-pre-acquisition declaration or section 24 certificate made but acquisition not proceeded with
(a) a pre-acquisition declaration is revoked or ceases to have effect because of subsection 44 (2) or 46 (3);

(b) a person who, when the declaration was in force, was an owner of an interest affected by the declaration, suffers loss as a direct, natural and reasonable consequence of the making of the declaration; and
(c) within 3 years after the declaration is revoked or ceases to have effect, the person claims compensation in accordance with section 97;
the Commonwealth is liable to pay to the person as compensation such amount as will justly compensate him or her for the loss.
``(2) Where:
(a) a certificate under section 24 is revoked or ceases to have effect because of subsection 46 (3);
(b) a person who, when the certificate was in force, was a person affected by the certificate, suffers loss as a direct, natural and reasonable consequence of the giving of the certificate; and
(c) within 3 years after the certificate is revoked or ceases to have effect, the person claims compensation in accordance with section 97;
the Commonwealth is liable to pay to the person as compensation such amount as will justly compensate him or her for the loss.''.

Clause 96 of the Bill makes provision for compensation for any loss suffered by an owner to be payable when a pre-acquisition declaration has been made but acquisition does not proceed. However, several comments have been made to me identifying two situations where it appears compensation will not be paid when an acquisition does not proceed. In both situations no pre-acquisition declaration would have been issued. The first of these is when land is acquired in a public park. Due to the special procedures to be adopted when acquiring land in a public park, no pre-acquisition declaration is issued. The second case identified is when land is acquired using the provisions in section 24 where land is required due to urgency or, in some cases, when to provide details of the intended land use might be prejudicial to the security of the country. In both instances the Minister certifies that a pre-acquisition declaration will not be issued.

Regarding the first case, where land is to be acquired in a public park, by definition a public park would be owned by a State or local government. For that reason it is not considered necessary to have a compensation provision if the acquisition did not proceed; hence clause 96 does not need to refer to that particular situation. However, where the Minister has certified under clause 24 that an acquisition should proceed without issue of a pre-acquisition declaration and then that acquisition does not proceed, it is reasonable that the owners of the land involved should be able to claim compensation for a failure to proceed with the acquisition in the same way as if a pre-acquisition declaration had been issued. For that reason I propose an amendment to clause 96, so that where an acquisition has been instigated by certification under clause 24 and that acquisition does not proceed, the owners of the land involved should be able to claim compensation if they suffer loss as a result.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 97 to 116-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 117 (Disposals to be in accordance with Part).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Clause 117, page 51, at the end of the clause, add the following subclauses:

``(2) In spite of paragraph 48 (1) (b) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901, regulations made for the purpose of paragraph (1) (b) of this section may provide that the regulations shall take effect on a date to be fixed by the Minister by notice in the Gazette.
``(3) The Minister shall not fix a date for the purpose of subsection (2) that is earlier than:
(a) the last day on which a notice could be given under subsection 48 (4) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 in relation to the regulations; or
(b) if such a notice is given, the latest day on which the regulations could be disallowed by a House of the Parliament in which such a notice has been given.''.

Clause 117 provides that the Commonwealth shall dispose of land in accordance with the Bill. However, this provision is subject to a series of exceptions. Concern has been expressed about the provision which allows exemption from the Bill by regulation at clause 117 (b). In this regard it has been suggested that an acquiring authority could be exempted soon after the Senate rises and a disposal completed outside the terms of the Bill before the Senate and the House of Representatives had the opportunity to consider and perhaps disallow the exemption. I must say that that is equally applicable to other legislation but, more significantly, under the existing legislation exemption is affected simply by gazettal of a ministerial decision. The exemption provisions contained in the Bill provide for parliamentary scrutiny and are consistent with those provided by the Australian Law Reform Commission. However, it is unlikely that exemption of an authority would be required so quickly that it would not be possible to allow parliamentary scrutiny of the intention. Therefore, I propose this amendment to prevent a disposal by an exempted authority until after parliamentary scrutiny of the exemption has taken place.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

Clause 121 (Interest in land to be offered first to former owner).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Clause 121, pages 51 and 52, omit subclauses (2) and (3), substitute the following subclauses:

``(2) An offer shall be made by the Minister by written notice given to the former owner and shall specify the amount that, in the opinion of the Minister, represents the market value of the interest at the time of the offer.
``(3) The acquiring authority shall not dispose of the interest to a person other than the former owner within 28 days after the day on which the offer is made.

``(4) If, within that period of 28 days, the former owner gives to the Minister notice that he or she wishes to purchase the interest from the acquiring authority, the authority shall not dispose of the interest to a person other than the former owner within 2 months after the notice is given.
``(5) The former owner may apply to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of the Minister's decision as to the amount specified in the offer as the market value of the interest.
``(6) The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 applies to the former owner's application.
``(7) If the former owner makes an application to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the acquiring authority shall not dispose of the interest to a person other than the former owner:
(a) until the end of 14 days after the decision of the Tribunal on the application comes into operation; or

(b) if, within that period of 14 days, the owner gives the Minister written notice of his or her wish to purchase the interest from the Commonwealth at the market value determined by the Tribunal, until the end of 2 months after the decision of the Tribunal comes into operation.
``(8) The Minister may, by notice in writing given to the former owner, extend the period of 2 months referred to in paragraph (7) (b).
``(9) The validity of the disposal of an interest in land is not affected by a failure to comply with this section.
``(10) In this section:
`former owner', in relation to an interest in land, means:
(a) if the interest was acquired by the acquiring authority from only one person and that person is still alive or, in the case of a corporation, is still in existence-that person; and

(b) in any other case-such persons (if any) as the Minister, having regard to the interests that existed in the land immediately before the acquisition, considers to be fairly entitled to the benefit of subsection (1);
`market value' has the same meaning as in section 56.''.

The Bill provides for the disposal of Commonwealth land as well as the acquisition of it. Clause 121 of the Bill requires that when the Commonwealth is reselling land that it acquired by compulsory process within the last seven years, regard shall be had for the general principle that the land should be first offered back to the former owner. It has been suggested that the Bill should identify a specified time during which former owners may consider the Commonwealth's offer. They might need to investigate all manner of things, not the least of which would be their financial position. By the same token, I need to be conscious of the desirability of avoiding delay to the Commonwealth's disposal program, particularly if the former owner is not very interested at the suggestion of the saleback offer. Therefore, I propose an amendment which would provide that the former owner would have 28 days in which to indicate his general intention to acquire the land. That does not mean that the former owner must acquire it within that time, nor is he bound to acquire it having indicated an intention to do so.

Another point made to me concerns the price at which the land is offered back to the former owner. The Bill requires that the land be offered at market value. A technical amendment to the Bill is required to make it clear that the definition of market value contained in clause 56 shall also apply to clause 121.
Amendment agreed to.

Clause 124 (Mining etc. on certain land).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 124, pages 53 and 54, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Mining etc. on certain land
``124. (1) The Governor-General may authorise the grant of a lease or licence to a person to explore, recover or mine for minerals on land situated in a State, which is vested in the Commonwealth.

``(2) Subject to such exemptions and modification as are prescribed, the laws of the State in which the land is situated relating to mining shall, so far as applicable, apply to a lease or licence under this section, and to exploration, recovering or mining carried on under the lease or licence.
``(3) In this section:
`mineral' means a naturally occurring substance or mixture of substances;

`mining law' means a law relating to the exploration for, or mining or recovery of, minerals and includes a law relating to the protection of the environment from the effect of such exploration, mining or recovery;
`relevant land' means:
(a) land in a State vested in an acquiring authority, being land that is a Commonwealth place for the purposes of the Commonwealth Places (Application of Laws) Act 1970; or
(b) land in a Territory, being land:
(i) vested in an acquiring authority; or
(ii) that:
(a) is in a conservation zone within the Northern Territory pastoral lease area; and

(b) by a grant under section 12 of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 is vested in an Aboriginal Land Trust, whether the vesting occurred or occurs before or after the commencement of this section.''.

This clause provides for the making of regulations prescribing the conditions for exploration and mining on Commonwealth land. The regulations can also make provision for the making of arrangements between the Commonwealth and a State or Territory for the officers of the State or Territory to perform functions or exercise powers under the regulations. The Government has said that it is envisaged that the regulations made under the Bill will contain provisions similar to those of relevant State or Territory mining laws.

The Bill before the House differs from the 1955 Act, which provided for the laws of the State to apply to mining subject to prescribed exemptions and modifications. I want to emphasise that there is a capacity for the Commonwealth to insert in those mining leases conditions to suit its requirements. The Opposition and the mining industry consider that the 1955 Act provisions are preferable to those proposed in the Bill for the following reasons. First, the 1955 Act guarantees compatibility with State practices and procedures. Miners will know exactly where they stand, and will not be subject to potential changes to regulations, which can occur at short notice. Secondly, State laws are, from time to time, modified, and if the Bill is passed in its current form new regulations to the proposed Act may be required each time State legislation is changed. By retaining a reference to State laws in the Bill there would be no need to modify the regulations under the proposed Act as changes are made to State legislation. The amendment would ensure compatibilities. Thirdly, the 1955 Act provides a much clearer statement of respective responsibility. Accordingly, I have moved on behalf of the Opposition the amendment which has been circulated, providing for clause 124 of the Bill to be deleted except for section 7, to be replaced with words akin to section 51 (2) of the 1955 Act.

Honourable members will notice that additional words have been added to the section of the 1955 Act to cover exploration and recovery as well as mining. I have already made it clear that the Opposition and the mining industry believe the amendment I am moving is preferable to what is proposed in the Bill. As well as providing greater certainty for the mining industry, what the Opposition is proposing will be more administratively efficient for the Commonwealth Government and still provide the Government with all the powers it needs in relation to mining on or beneath Commonwealth land. Indeed, I predict the making of these regulations will prove complex and I seek from the Minister an indication as to when they will be available for scrutiny by the Opposition, State governments and the mining industry. I also invite the Minister to indicate in his response whether the holders of any mining tenements situated upon land to be acquired by the Commonwealth are persons affected by the Bill and are thus entitled to be notified of any intended acquisition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not accept the Opposition's amendment, for the following reasons. The provisions contained in the Bill have not been sprung on anyone overnight. As far back as May this year I issued a press release foreshadowing the introduction of this legislation and outlining the key reforms that it contains, including the issue of mineral exploration and development on Commonwealth land. Although I applaud the constructive way in which the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), has approached the majority of the provisions in the Bill, he has not really followed the progress of the mining aspect of the legislation. I have not been approached in the last six months by anyone seeking clarification or explanation of the rationale in making these mining reforms. I really think the issue has been raised at the eleventh hour. I think there is a misunderstanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, I shall again outline the Government's intentions and the reasons why I think these changes are necessary. For many years there has been a perception within the mining industry and some State mines departments that exploration and mining on Commonwealth land either is not allowed or is just too difficult and time-consuming to attempt. Back in September 1986 this Government established an interdepartmental committee to examine the problems in this area and to formulate possible solutions that would streamline the administration of exploration and mining on Commonwealth land.

One of the major problems identified by this interdepartmental committee was the present Lands Acquisition Act. Sections in the present Act which deal with exploration and mining on Commonwealth land are imprecise and inconsistent. The current Act provides that State laws, subject to such exemptions and modifications as prescribed, shall apply to mining on Commonwealth land in a State or the Northern Territory. However, the same provision is not made in regard to exploration on Commonwealth land. A further shortcoming in the current Act is that exploration and mining provisions apply only to land vested in the name of the Commonwealth. For land vested in the name of Commonwealth bodies sharing the Commonwealth immunity from State law, there is no mining regime providing for the issuing of exploration licences or mining leases. This has resulted in poorly defined administrative procedures which mean that the present system is not working well.

Our objective is to facilitate access to Commonwealth land, other than national parks and Antarctica, for mineral exploration and development while at the same time to both protect the use of the land and meet statutory responsibilities for environmental protection and heritage conservation. To this end we have recently decided on a multiple land use policy that will apply to all Commonwealth land; as I said, the exceptions being national parks and Antarctica. This policy should ensure that a proper resource assessment is undertaken prior to acquisition; that the wider interests of the Commonwealth are considered in determining land use, not just the specific use to which the land is put; the mining industry is aware of general guidelines that are likely to govern operations on Commonwealth land; and Commonwealth land is used as efficiently as possible in returning a benefit to the Government and the country. The policy will ensure that environmental and heritage interests are adequately protected when considering development proposals to mine or explore on Commonwealth land.

The other major recommendation was that revised provisions on exploration and mining on Commonwealth land should be included in the Lands Acquisition Bill and that regulations should be developed based on that multiple land use policy. These regulations will prescribe all the conditions under which exploration and mining will be allowed on Commonwealth land. The mining industry will know exactly what it must do to obtain access to Commonwealth land. The regulations will be drafted after consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. They will contain provisions similar to those of relevant State mining laws and, at the same time, ensure that the Commonwealth meets all its statutory responsibilities in managing the land it owns. The regulations will provide for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements with the States and the Northern Territory for them to administer exploration and mining on Commonwealth land. The Commonwealth will be looking to the States and the Northern Territory, with their expertise in mining administration, to become more closely involved in the administration of both exploration and mining on Commonwealth land.

I wish to digress slightly. The interdepartmental committee and I considered whether we should set up a separate Federal mining regime for this purpose, and we decided against it. We decided to do it by regulation agreements which, after initial Federal approval, would allow for exploration and mining to proceed according to Commonwealth law but administered by the States. All of this goes much further towards involving the States and the Northern Territory in the exploration of mining activities on Commonwealth land than is the case under the present system. Together with the new multiple land use policy, this will streamline the process the industry has to follow in order to gain access. We consider that it is not desirable or necessary for actual State law to be applied to Commonwealth land. This would mean-I think this is very important-that, as a State or Territory parliament changed its laws, it would be changing what can or cannot be done on Commonwealth land.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just said that you will have regulations which will mirror the States'.
—That is right, but it does not necessarily mean that, if they make a change, that change has to be mirrored in what we do.
—Well, then it will not be mirrored. That is the point. You have made my case.

—Under the provisions proposed in this Bill, the Commonwealth therefore retains ultimate control at the end of the day over what happens on our land. Doing this by regulation means that this Parliament remains fully informed about just what conditions apply to mineral exploration and development on Commonwealth land. Of course, the Parliament has the normal 15 sitting days in which to disallow any regulations put forward under this legislation-the ultimate safeguard.

SPEECH.PARA: With this legislation I am improving a situation that is not working well and has not done so for the last 30 or so years. Once the regulations are drafted, companies will know exactly what they must do to obtain access to Commonwealth land for exploration and mining. If the States and the Northern Territory choose to enter into agreements with us on administering these activities, this will further improve matters. Mining companies will be able to deal with State mines departments which they already know, and the States and the Northern Territory will then be fully aware of all exploration and mining activity within their borders. At the same time, these proposals will not diminish the Commonwealth's responsibilities in the areas of environmental protection and heritage conservation. I repeat, they will not apply in the national parks or Antarctica. These proposals ensure that at all times the Commonwealth will have full knowledge of, and control over, the conditions that apply to mineral exploration and development on Commonwealth land.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had it not been for the fact that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) represents a mining constituency, I would have said, with the greatest of respect, that he had been badly advised. But because he represents a mining area, I would not have thought he would need advice on this matter. Before I go into detail and respond to what he said, let me take up one point. He mistakenly said that this matter was raised at the eleventh hour. Today is 20 October, and I have in front of me a copy of a letter dated 29 August 1988, addressed to the Minister, from the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia, (Inc.) which in part states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Chamber respectfully submits that this Bill fails to properly protect the interests of the mining and petroleum industries.
In desperation, it goes on to say that, if the Bill is to be passed as drafted:

We thus seek your urgent confirmation that the proposed regulations will closely reflect relevant State laws and that the holders of mining to petroleum tenements are considered to fall within the definition of the term `owner'.

That was not raised at the eleventh hour; it was raised with the Minister on 29 August. The only point I want to make at this stage, because the Minister has indicated clearly that the Government will not accept the Opposition's amendment, is that at present the 1955 Lands Acquisition Act gives the Commonwealth all the power it needs in relation to mining leases, mining purposes leases, exploration licences and any other mining operation on Commonwealth land. The Commonwealth can demand and have conditions inserted in the State licences as they are issued. The Commonwealth does this now, and it can continue to do it. If it is the intention of the Commonwealth to regulate, to mirror State legislation, it means that we will have a set of regulations for every State in the Commonwealth.

The Minister said a moment ago that these regulations will not be promulgated until there have been negotiations with the States. In other words, officers of his Department will soon be negotiating with every mines department in Australia. Following that, these regulations will be drawn up and, if the Minister is telling the truth-and I have no reason to disbelieve him-those regulations will conform with State mining legislation, plus the conditions that the Commonwealth will require for a particular mining operation.

I do not believe that it is possible to prescribe regulations for the Commonwealth that will cover every situation. If the Government succeeds in doing that, its draftsmen will be the first in Australia who have succeeded in prescribing regulations in a central way to suit every mining operation. Conditions have to be attached to mining leases and exploration licences to conform with the requirements of specific areas. The Minister ought to know that. It is just not possible to cover every situation. So what is proposed in this legislation can be described as nothing less than an administrative nightmare. It must mean that the Commonwealth has draftsmen to spare, that they are unemployed, and that it is looking for something for them to do. I say that with the greatest of respect, because what is proposed here is just a load of nonsense. There is no need for it. The Act has been in place since 1955. I do not know of any problem that has occurred between the Commonwealth and any State in relation to mining on or beneath Commonwealth land. I administered the New South Wales Act for seven years.

TALK.START.PARA: —And very well.

—I thank the Minister very much. I do not recall, in the seven years in which I administered the New South Wales Act, a problem with the Commonwealth in relation to mining on or beneath Commonwealth land. I assume that the Minister has his riding instructions. Cabinet has told him that this is the piece of legislation and, not withstanding the fact that the Opposition has drawn to his attention this deficiency, it will go through. It is a case of yes, Minister, it has to go through. If it has to go through tonight-and by weight of numbers the Government will push it through-I ask the Minister, in the interests of common sense, that after the Bill has been passed by this House and the Senate, that he look at it again.

SPEECH.PARA: Indeed, I ask that it be looked at between here and the Senate. I ask this sincerely because I believe that the Minister will find that he has many problems with it. Perhaps, by way of interjection or when I sit down, he can indicate to me when these regulations will be available for scrutiny. If he cannot give me some indication as to when the regulations will be available for scrutiny, then he cannot tell me when this Act will be proclaimed. Will there be further delay? I am sorry to introduce at this stage of the debate what could be referred to as a sour note. The Minister, his Department, his departmental officers, and his personal staff, have been very cooperative with me and my staff in this matter. Indeed, the Minister has set an example for some of his colleagues by bringing this Bill into the House in May and leaving it on the table until October for it to be debated. I commend him for that. I hope that other Ministers will follow his example. In the interests of good administration and common sense, I plead with him to look at this again. If he cannot accept the amendment tonight, I ask that he look at it again before the matter is dealt with in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our intentions on this matter are to streamline the process and strike a balance between expediting applications for exploration and mining on Commonwealth land, other than national parks and Antarctica, and the need for proper environmental controls and so on. Our intentions are pure. We wish to streamline the process. This goes back a long way. An interdepartmental committee has looked at this in great length and provided me with a very lengthy report. As I said earlier tonight, it discussed whether we ought to set up a separate federal mining regime under federal legislation.
—I can't believe that it would consider that.

—It did consider that and it rejected it. We then rejected it. The shadow Minister says, and basically implies in his amendment, that we should simply rely on the provisions of the current Act. But as I explained to him, that situation applies only to mining; it does not apply to exploration. We are trying to provide an expeditious regime under which we would, firstly, write the regulations, and secondly, strike the agreements with the States or the Northern Territory. This would then allow exploration or mining to proceed after the Federal Minister has approved the initial application. If the Commonwealth does not approve it, it is chopped off-that is proper and fair. If it is approved under the regulations and the agreements that would be reached under those regulations, the agreements would stipulate the regime which would virtually mirror-and be reached in agreement with the State if there were any deviation-the current State law. That is what the Opposition wants to achieve. Basically, at the end of the day we have to decide or be the arbiter of whether we want to accept the State law absolutely to the letter or whether we want to accept to the letter any changes that it may make in future-changes over which we have no control whatsoever. I repeat: Our intentions are pure. We think this system will expedite it. If it does not, we will certainly have a look at it. That is it. I hope that this does not hold up the Bill, particularly when it reaches the other place. I want to get the whole process going as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to the second part of the shadow Minister's contribution; that is, how long it will take to get the show moving. If we have not already written to the Premiers, we will be doing so very quickly telling them what we have in mind. Providing this legislation goes through the Senate, it is my intention to promulgate this matter as quickly as possible. Probably, as of now, we would be preparing the regulations under which we would reach the agreements. If the letters to the Premiers have not already gone, I assure the House that they will go very soon. I know that I have authorised them. We will then write the regulations. The Senate can disallow them if it wishes. I do not expect that it will. As I have said, we will reach agreements with the States and they will be informed very quickly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Within three months?

—I expect so. We will write the regulations quickly and we will attempt to reach quick agreements with the States. I expect that the Bill will be promulgated very quickly after it passes the Senate. It is in the Opposition's hands. If we get the Bill through the Senate, the regulations will be written, the agreements will be struck, and the situation will be streamlined. This will be a great improvement on the present situation. I think the Opposition's amendment is unnecessary.

SPEECH.PARA: If it proves, in practice, that I am wrong, we will most certainly have another look at the situation. As I said at the outset, our whole intent has been to strike a balance between the need to get rid of the red tape, to expedite the process, to avoid having to set up our own federal administration, to work with the States and the Northern Territory, and to allow the ultimate Commonwealth sanction with the need to be able to keep control of the environmental process at the same time. I will maintain my position on this. If I am proven wrong and if it does not work I am willing to look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —By the time the Minister is proven wrong, the damage will have been done because all the regulations will have been drawn up.
—The honourable member for Hume can speak on only two occasions in the committee stage.

—With your indulgence Mr Deputy Chairman, I will make two comments for the assistance of the Minister. The Opposition will not be holding up this Bill in the Senate. `` `conservation zone' means a conservation zone declared under section 8a of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975;

`Gimbat' or `Goodparla' means, in each case, the area described by that name (being an area of land that is or was subject to a pastoral lease) on the map referred to in the definition of `Alligator Rivers Region' in section 3 of the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act 1978;

Injunctions

``132. (1) Where a person has used, or is proposing to use, land in a manner inconsistent with a restriction on the use of the land acquired by an acquiring authority under this Act, the Federal Court may, on the application of that authority, grant an injunction restraining the person from using the land in that manner.

``(2) Where an application is made to the Court for an injunction under this section, the Court may, if in the Court's opinion it is desirable to do so, grant an interim injunction restraining a person from engaging in conduct of the kind to which the application relates pending the determination of the application.
``(3) The Court may discharge or vary an injunction granted under this section.
``(4) The power of the Court to grant an injunction restraining a person from using land in a particular manner may be exercised:

The Bill provides the means by which the Commonwealth can acquire all types of interests in land. This amendment is simply a technical amendment which provides a means by which a restriction on the use of land that has been acquired by the Commonwealth can be enforced. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (34) Clause 137, page 59, line 7, omit ``person'', substitute ``member of the Australian Public Service''.

This amendment provides that the Minister may delegate powers under the Act and regulations. The clause goes on to qualify those by listing a number of areas where the Minister's powers cannot be delegated. Comments have been made during the consultative process expressing concern that when the Minister delegates powers he or she is delegating responsibility for the use of those powers and the Minister's powers may be delegated to elements of the bureaucracy which might have little regard for the intentions behind the legislation, and hence ministerial powers should not be delegated. I disagree with that view. Delegation of ministerial powers rightly or wrongly does not remove responsibility for the use of those powers from the Minister. Furthermore, it is necessary to delegate general powers simply to enable the day to day operation of government and the House would be aware of that. However, I believe it is not appropriate for some of the Minister's powers to be delegated, and for that reason the Bill identifies those powers which I think should not be delegated.

Another concern has been raised, that is that the Minister may delegate his powers to a person. That is the way it is written in the current Bill. The view has been expressed that persons to whom powers are delegated should be qualified so that it cannot be assumed that the Minister is able to delegate these powers to just any person he chooses. I consider that that point is very valid and I am proposing that this clause be amended to make it clear that ministerial powers would be delegated only to persons who are Commonwealth public servants.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.
