DEBATE.TITLE: JUDICIAL AND STATUTORY OFFICERS (REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Judicial and Statutory Officers (Remuneration and Allowances) Amendment Bill 1988 makes provision for an increase in the salaries and allowances of certain persons and, in particular, judicial officers and the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. Under Section 72 of the Constitution, provision is made to the effect that:

SPEECH.PARA: The Justices of the High Court and of the other courts created by the Parliament-
(iii) Shall receive such remuneration as the Parliament may fix: but the remuneration shall not be diminished during their continuance in office.

Of course, the reason for that device is to provide security for judicial appointments to ensure their independence from the Executive. The Bill before us specifically changes the law to effect salary and allowance increases. The increases of 3 per cent include such matters as travel allowances. The cost to the Budget is in the order of $1.2m.

The Bill implements the 1987 recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal. Of course, the Remuneration Tribunal was established by the Parliament to advise the Parliament on appropriate levels of remuneration for such persons as judges. I think as a matter of common sense and a matter of general principle there is a very heavy obligation on the Parliament always to give favourable consideration to the advice and recommendations of the Remuneration Tribunal. So it is that the Government has acted to initiate a change in the law to implement these increases.

I was very interested in a statement made in the second reading speech of the then Minister for Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), in support of the increases. In the third paragraph of his second reading speech the Minister said:

In relation to the second tier salary adjustment, I am satisfied that the changes to practices and procedures in the various courts and tribunals in the federal jurisdiction, together with changes in the value of work of the office holders, justify an increase of 3 per cent in conformity with the national wage case principles.

So what the Minister has said is that because of an increase in productivity, judges have earned this extra 3 per cent. He felt that this was such a precondition the increase of 3 per cent that he placed real emphasis on the justification on the first page of his second reading speech. I think that is very interesting. In fact, the Remuneration Tribunal, in coming to its recommendation, said this on page 4 of its report:

All of the provisions of the Commission's decisions are not in their literal terms applicable to the groups within the Tribunal's jurisdiction. For example, the restriction upon the grant of second tier increases by reference to restructuring and to enquiry and approval by the Commission are not applicable. However, as it has done on previous occasions, the Tribunal will continue to apply the intent and spirit of the Commission's decision.

I just put this matter into perspective. In the recent national wage case to which this decision is relevant there was an agreement that people would get more pay in exchange for entering into changes in work practices. That is a pretty simple and sensible idea. This is a marked change from some of the attitudes that we have had in the past. One of the problems that we have had in this country in regard to pay increases is the dog chasing its tail effect. People are saying, `Look, inflation has gone up so we want the equivalent amount of dollars in our pocket'. The problem with that is that the economy of this country is operating in an environment where we compete with people from other countries who are producing goods and services for the same markets that we want to be in. So we are engaged in serious competition with other countries in an international environment. But one gets nowhere fast when one has a wages system which is based on indexation. In fact, one starts to go backwards because the economy has a wage structure in which wages are going up faster than those of our competitors. So it is no wonder that we do not do well. This is one of the problems that we have faced as a nation.

We have moved from a system of indexation to one where we encourage people to say, `Well, look, if you want a wage increase why not sit down and work out some basis upon which you can become more productive and more efficient?'. In that way we will create the wealth so that we can in fact have some real money to pay people real wage increases. I am sure that honourable members will agree that such an approach is only sensible.

Superimposed on that fact of life we have in this country a centralised wage fixing system. It is interesting to look at the way in which we are worrying in this Bill about justifying pay increases of judges and fitting them into a centralised system and to compare that with the actual reality. The reality is that judges are not getting the 3 per cent increase because people have used stopwatches to see whether they have been more productive. That is nonsense, as everybody in this chamber knows. It is not a question of productivity. In fact, it is just nonsense to apply the centralised system to individual circumstances. This is a good example of the centralised solution not being relevant and sensible in each and every case. It just cannot be done.

One of the great points of difference between the Opposition and the Government is that we say, `Look, it is about time we woke up to ourselves. This country is going backwards. Our international competitors-the people with whom we are in competition-have a better system than we have. It is about time we thought of something rather than trying to impose from the centre rigid and inflexible arrangements. It is about time we had a system which reflected the actual circumstances of the hundreds of thousands of workplaces around this country'.

I just say to the Government, `To the extent that we have moved from the system of indexation, to the extent that we have encouraged people when they are looking for pay increases to be more efficient, that is great; that is fine; that is sensible. But we have to move faster and there has to be an understanding that this sort of imposition from the centre in a rigid and inflexible manner is inappropriate in so many circumstances'.

Award restructuring is the next stage, as it were, in this process. We have moved on from productivity to award restructuring. To the extent that that is going to encourage people again to sit down and say, `Let us have a look at our enterprise and see what other sensible things we can do to make it more profitable', to the extent that we can encourage an employee and an employer to say, `We actually have something in common-a future, a stake in this enterprise', and to the extent that award restructuring facilitates that, that is fine. But, quite frankly, we are going at a snail's pace-and, in this world, unless one goes forward, one goes backwards.

One of the interesting debates in the Parliament in the last week or so has been about the tax cuts. I am sure thousands of people who have heard of this business are saying, `Look, the bad times are over, the wartime conditions are behind us. Bob and the Grim Reaper have been telling us that the good times are coming. There will be tax cuts, the biggest tax cuts in the history of the federation'. It is all good news, all building up the next election. Of course, the Government had a thrashing in Oxley and a thrashing back in Adelaide. After Adelaide the Government said, `We have to start telling people that things are going to be better whether they are or not'. It was telling people in Oxley before the result, `Vote for Labor because we have turned the corner'. That is the line, and we have seen as a result the great build-up of expectations about wages and about the extent of the tax cuts.

It is no wonder people are expecting something because, if we were to put the average family in the position they were in then back in 1983, we would have to put $56 a week in their pocket. No wonder everybody is talking about living standards. People out there under this Minister have had a cut in their wages and in their living standards. The Minister talks about all the extra jobs. Why have there been some extra jobs in this country? It is because the Government has been cutting wages and cutting people's living standards. Now the Minister has got himself into one unholy mess. His rhetoric is about sitting down and talking to people on the basis of productivity. He asks them to make some changes to their organisational arrangements at the workplace and thereby create the wealth to pay for the wage increases. But the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not interested in all that. He is just worried about the next election. He has only one political strategy, and that is try to get some dollars into people's pockets so that they will feel better as they go down to the ballot box. Nobody will believe it, because everyone knows that the Government has robbed them blind. It gives them back half what it took and then asks them to be grateful and vote for it.

The reality is that the build-up of expectations has led to this situation: People are going to say that if the tax cuts are not big enough they want a few extra dollars in the wage packet. It has not dawned on the Minister's side that the Government is preparing the ground to shoot itself in the foot, because the spillover into wages is in fact a spill back to the concepts of wage indexation. To the extent that we agree about where we want to go in industrial relations, to the extent that we agree that we want people to sit down at the workplace and come to sensible arrangements for the benefit of the enterprise in which they all have a future stake, the situation which the Minister has built up, primarily because of the Prime Minister's simplistic political strategies, is working against the interests of this country.

Judges' salaries, of course, are essentially in the public sector. I have talked about this Bill. Let me tell the Government the view of the Opposition when it comes to the manner in which we should set salaries. We have issued what is, I think, the most comprehensive industrial relations policy that has ever been presented and I read just two of its clauses. Clause 6.1 reads:
A Liberal and National Party Government will adopt a more flexible, market-oriented approach to industrial relations in the area of Commonwealth employment.
Clause 6.2 reads:

Public sector pay and conditions will be such as to enable employers to recruit, retain and motivate the staff they require in order to achieve their objectives. In determining pay and conditions the following factors will be taken into account: economic conditions, cost, the need to be fair to employees, and the need to reflect differences in market conditions, individual performance, skills and experience. Public servants will, as far as possible, be provided with terms and conditions of employment that are broadly comparable to, but not more generous than, the private sector.
In respect of judges, the Remuneration Tribunal had this to say by way of preliminary remarks:

For the purpose of this review it should be stated that preliminary findings to date have confirmed the Tribunal's earlier reported view of the serious inadequacies of judicial salaries and conditions.

The Law Council, in a press release, spoke about the manner in which the Government had gone about looking to improve judges' salaries. The heading, which pretty well expresses the Council's view, was `Judges shouldn't have to punch time clocks'. That was its view, and when one thinks about it, it is a pretty sensible reaction and one that the Government should not be surprised about. Specifically, the Law Council said this:

The task of judges is not just to `increase production' and to raise the productivity of their courts, but to produce just decisions. It would be quite wrong to have a situation in which litigants felt that their cases might not be properly dealt with because judges were under pressure to comply with wage determination principles set by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

That reinforces the point I have made, which is that these centrally dictated principles, when applied to a specific situation such as judicial salaries, show what a nonsense they can be and how inflexible those rules are. But it was not just the Law Council that had something to say in respect of these salaries. I refer the Minister to some comments of Sir Anthony Mason, the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia. He said in respect of this approach that judicial salaries should be conditioned on achieving equivalent cost savings resulting from the introduction of innovative procedures:

This approach, which may be an acceptable yardstick in measuring salary increases in productive enterprises, is quite inappropriate for the judiciary. It is an approach which may create an impression that judges stand to gain from concentrating on speedy justice.

That is another nail in the coffin, as it were, of the policy position that the Government has adopted and its inflexibility. Also of very considerable significance was the allied remark of Sir Anthony Mason to the effect that, given the involvement of other court officers in terms of the capacity of the courts to deal with cases and to get through their work load, what one achieves by this sort of criterion is to impose a foreign element, as it were, on the court structure which in fact goes to the independence of the judiciary. This is what Sir Anthony Mason said:
Judges do not participate in the provision of these court services.
That is stating the obvious, of course. He said, and this was his cautionary note:
These moves may impair judicial independence.

Not only is it a question of being an inappropriate criteria to adopt and apply to the provision of judges' salaries but, furthermore, as was stated by Sir Anthony Mason, it imposes on the judicial system an element which has the potential for impairing judicial independence.

If we look back in recent times at judges' salaries, I do not think there is any question whatsoever that they have seen a relative decline in real terms in the salaries they receive. I do not think there is any doubt that, as a consequence of that, we have expected from our judges an ever increasing level of a sense of public duty as their salaries have declined and they have been prepared to continue to undertake the work of judges. That is not an appropriate situation. That is not a situation that can go on forever and a day as the differentials widen. There is only so much that we as a community can expect of people when it comes to the giving of their time and their services and their dedication to the maintenance of our system of justice. On behalf of the Opposition, I simply say that we welcome this measure, but-and I point to the inappropriate standards by which the Government has come to this conclusion-I note that the Remuneration Tribunal has been reviewing judicial salaries. That is good. We look forward to its report. If that report states a necessity for an increase in judicial salaries, I hope that the Government will give it favourable consideration. One hardly needs to state the importance of ensuring that we properly attend to the need of the judiciary for a reasonable salary level.

I conclude my remarks by reiterating our support for the Bill. I look forward to the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendation in respect of judges' salaries. I think it is certainly overdue. It is a poor reflection on the Government that it has not addressed these issues earlier. It is a poor reflection on the Government that it is in a position where the system it is so keen on supporting-the centralised system-in this case is an inappropriate vehicle for measuring the proper standards by which we should assess the remuneration of judges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The slow, ponderous and padded speech that we have just been listening to was full of contradictions. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) seemed at one point to be arguing for reduced pay and then later criticising the Government for allowing real labour costs to fall. He seemed to be arguing at one point for a more flexible system and then criticising a more flexible system when it occurred. He described the country as going backwards when, of course, the rate of economic growth has been very substantial. The country is going forward rapidly and a process of major restructuring is well under way.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most striking things about the last five years is how well the centralised wage fixing system has worked. It is true that real unit labour costs have fallen, as they had to during the last three years because of the decline in the terms of trade. That has happened at exactly the same time as there has been a sharp reduction in industrial conflict. It has been a remarkable achievement of this Government to have succeeded in a costly and difficult restructuring program at the same time as the level of time lost through strikes has fallen to about half of what it was in the last years of the Fraser Government.

The accord has been a resounding success. It has been a success because the Government has consulted closely with both unions and employers and has been successful in getting agreement about major economic policies and about the process of restructuring. That agreement has been achieved in a voluntary way, which has ensured its durability and success. It is remarkable that the Government has been able to achieve all of that at the same time as there has been a rapid growth in employment. I think perhaps the Government's greatest achievement during the past 5 1/2 years has been the growth in employment. The number of people in employment has gone up by 1.1 million in the last 5 1/2 years, and nothing could possibly be more important than that. Employment is what gives people the opportunity to earn an income, to have satisfying jobs; and, of course, it has been associated with a substantial reduction in unemployment. That has been partly the result of the success of the accord in allowing real unit labour costs to fall, then to stabilise and now to rise.

The Opposition's industrial relations policy, on the other hand, would be a recipe for chaos, anarchy and disorder. There would be massive increases in pay for some people and reductions in pay for other people. The policy is opposed by most people who are practitioners in industrial relations. It is certainly opposed by the unions, but also opposed by many employers. If it were introduced, the cost would be a major increase in industrial conflict again. The time lost through strikes, which has fallen by half under this Government, would rise again and we would be back to the levels of the Fraser years.

The arbitration system has served Australia very well over the last 80 years. It would be vandalism to destroy it in the way the Opposition is proposing, as well as being a recipe for the exploitation of the weak by the less scrupulous employers. There has been some decline in the real salaries of judges, but they have been sharing in the adjustment that has had to happen throughout the community as a result of the decline in the terms of trade that Australia has experienced during the last four years.

This Bill is about increasing pay again-an increase in pay that is now being experienced by all the Australian work force as they receive their second tier adjustment. So one can be very glad about this Bill. One can support it wholeheartedly, and I am glad the Opposition is doing so, because one welcomes it as a symbol of the increase in pay that it is now possible for the whole work force to receive as a result of the adjustments that have taken place.

One could argue that this is a trivial Bill. It certainly covers only a few people. No doubt it is not trivial to them because it is about their pay. One major point that I want to make about this Bill is that this sort of Bill should not have to come to Parliament. It would be much more logical for increases in the pay of judges to be set simply by the Remuneration Tribunal. I know the Government has that under consideration. There is no constitutional bar to that. It would save the time of Parliament. It would remove delays in the implementation of decisions of the Remuneration Tribunal. It would be simply logical to allow the Remuneration Tribunal to set pay for judges, as it does for politicians, departmental heads and other statutory officeholders. I conclude by saying I hope we never have to debate a Bill of this kind again, because it is really not appropriate for Parliament to be debating issues so local and small in character as this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a few observations about the contributions that have been made to this debate by both honourable members who have spoken. I think all honourable members are aware of the fact that the Remuneration Tribunal has jurisdiction to make recommendations only in relation to the remuneration of the Federal judiciary and related officers. This Bill now implements the recommendations made by the Remuneration Tribunal, as was indicated by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) when he was leading for the Opposition, in its 1987 review concerning the remuneration and allowances of the Federal judiciary, including people who, by virtue of an Act, have the same status as a judge, and the President and members of the Inter-State Commission. It provides for a 3 per cent second tier salary increase and adjustments to various allowance. The honourable member for Flinders used a few throwaway lines of the kind that the economy is going backwards when, in fact, the whole of the Australia community knows that the contrary is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to spend a great deal of time dealing with those issues because, in my judgment, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) dealt with them more than adequately. He indicated that one of the fundamental reasons behind such legislation is the fact that, to a very large extent, the Hawke Government has been remarkably successful in bringing about the type of restructuring that it has been pursuing. That has been important as a follow-up to those wider macro-economic responses that were introduced when we came to government in March 1983. As a result of those macro-responses, it was possible to put a fairly substantial and significant solid base under the Australian economy to make it possible now for us to switch our emphasis to micro-policies and to bring about this restructuring. I realise, as does the honourable member for Flinders, that the judiciary would not be and should not be expected to punch the bundy. Members of the judiciary do not have responsibilities which lend themselves to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just my point.

—The honourable member said, quite correctly, that it was not appropriate for them to punch time clocks. Of course they should not be doing that. That is not the nature of their work. If their work was such that it was determined by starting at 9 o'clock in the morning and finishing at 5 o'clock in the evening, I would not believe that it was necessarily inappropriate for them or any employee or person carrying out any type of social or economic responsibility to participate in that sort of thing. I do not want to make a lot of this, but I think that there is an element of arrogance about the implications of that comment, that perhaps it is all right and appropriate for certain types of employees to punch bundies but there are others whose position is so elevated that they should not do so. It is not as a result of the elevation of their particular responsibilities, but the nature of those responsibilities, which makes punching the bundy inappropriate. Of course, that was not the implication in the contribution of the honourable member for Flinders.

SPEECH.PARA: On all occasions remuneration should reflect effort, whatever the task happens to be. That can be manual effort, creative effort, intellectual effort and effort of the kind that is involved in the judiciary. It is quite appropriate and sensible that we attempt to marry into the centralised wage fixing system a recognition that, as a result of the application and operation of that system, it is possible for increases in remuneration to be applied right across the economy. The honourable member for Flinders suggested that the centralised wage fixing system and the application of these principles are not appropriate in this case. That is a quite legitimate point to make. However, we have emphasised that there has been a general application. The honourable member quoted my colleague the then Minister for Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), as having said, in his second reading speech to the Bill:

. . . the changes to practices and procedures in the various courts and tribunals in the Federal jurisdiction, together with changes in the value of work of the office holders, justify an increase of 3 per cent in conformity with the national wage case principles.

There is nothing exceptional about that and I do not think that we should seek to find anything exceptional about it. What we are doing is applying those general principles to make it possible for that 3 per cent increase to be applied to the judiciary. If we do not do it that way, on what basis do we provide the increase? Do we provide it simply because it is applied elsewhere or do we, as we attempted to do for members of parliament, professional people and all people on wages and salaries right through the economy, identify the improvements that have taken place in order to say that it is appropriate for the 3 per cent to be applied?

TALK.START.PARA: —I read out our policy so that you would know how to do it.

—We are familiar with the fact that some statements have been made by the Opposition but, in terms of those types of distinctions, I do not think that the Opposition's policy at this stage is in any way adequate to deal with the matter. The contribution of the honourable member for Flinders implies what I suggested before-an essentially arrogant type of response to occupational differentials in the economy and the implications of those differentials. The honourable member also referred to the fact that Sir Anthony Mason suggested that this introduced an element which had the potential for infringing judicial independence. I think that that is drawing a fairly long bow.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fraser also drew attention to one of the particular points that are covered in this legislation when he raised questions concerning the extent to which it may be necessary to implement increases to remuneration of the judiciary by legislation. That has been necessary up to the present time and I think honourable members are aware of the fact that under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 the Tribunal only has jurisdiction to make recommendations in regard to the remuneration of the Federal judiciary and not legally binding determinations. However, I understand that the view of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is that the Act could be amended to give the Tribunal determination-making powers. The Government considers that this would be a desirable step and would eliminate to a large extent delays that have occurred in the past in implementing increases to salaries and allowances within the Federal judiciary.

I understand that it is the Government's current intention to legislate in 1989 to enable those determinations to be made and thus to eliminate the necessity for legislation. That would be in terms of the general type of application of wage fixing tribunals and the way in which they operate in relation to all other types of wages and salaries in the community. That would be appropriate. It is not necessary for parliaments and governments to legislate in order to give effect to determinations that are made by other wage and salary fixing tribunals and it probably is not and should not be necessary in connection with this as well. Those are the only matters to which I wished to draw attention. The Minister has asked me to thank the honourable member for Flinders and the honourable member for Fraser for their contributions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Robert Brown) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 September, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up too much of the time of the House tonight, but I say on behalf of the Opposition that it certainly does not oppose the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. The legislation provides for amendments to five bounty Acts and one subsidy Act and the principal part of it relates to amendments to three bounty Acts for textile yarns and certain fabrics in accordance with the textile, clothing and footwear assistance measures announced in November 1986 and modified in the May economic statement this year.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is very much what we expected and, more significantly, it was what the industry itself expected. The challenge for the Government now is that it must maintain a predictable, stable policy environment for the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I know only too well that those industries want from the Government a guarantee that they will not see some sudden changes to that plan at some time in its duration. If there is one thing that an industry wants it is consistency so that it can invest and have some prospect of anticipating returns on investment and thus have some predictability in the way it can evolve.

It has been an historic problem for many Australian industries that they have been struck by unpredictable decisions from governments. Therefore, in the reply of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) both I and, I am certain, people within the industry will be only too pleased to hear a clear statement from him that the Government's policy in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear plan will remain predictable. They want to know that when this Government goes the plan will still be in place. I am certain that predictability will be the hallmark of the new Government's policies as well.

Of course, this industry will succeed and do well only if it has, in addition to that predictability, a chance to become truly competitive. If it is to become competitive, if it is to stay competitive in the areas in which it is already competitive, it will have to continue to invest. It will have to invest in higher technology equipment and produce quality products. It cannot expect Australians or the world markets to accept products of a low quality. There is no point in our industries going out and trying to grab the mass share at the bottom of the market. We have to look at the higher ends of the market. We have to look at the quality end of the market where we can use, as the Minister would put it, our brain power to achieve products which are different and which are respected not only in our own country in the face of import competition but around the world.

Let honourable members make no mistake: it is my view that the textile, clothing and footwear industries can do that. There is no reason why we cannot. Countries such as Italy which have a high cost structure-perhaps not as high as Australia's-succeed. They have an extraordinarily successful record in the textile, clothing and footwear field. We can do it ourselves if we concentrate on quality and if we give the industries predictability.

Of course, when we are making these sorts of judgments we have to take into account factors such as the cost of capital to our industries and, indeed, the relative cost of capital to investors in Australia as against investors in the same industries in other parts of the world. It is matter of concern to me, as I often say, that the cost of capital in Australia is relatively higher than it is in most of our competitor countries; more than that, it is higher than most countries in our region which are increasingly also becoming competitor countries.

If we look at the estimates of the Business Council of Australia of the cost of capital, we can see that the cost of capital in Australia, according to its list of 16 selected nations in both our region and around the world, is the second highest, exceeded only by New Zealand. That is a matter of real concern. It is something that the Government, in spite of the changes it made in the May economic statement, in the Budget and in the subsequent legislation that has been before the House, needs to take into consideration. The Business Council estimates that the cost of capital actually has increased since the changes made in the May economic statement-particularly in regard to depreciation and company tax rates. That is something that the Government needs to note, and to note very carefully. We have to go further in trying to reduce the cost of our capital. The cost of capital is lower in Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines. The cost of capital is lower in London, New York, Montreal, and Toronto as well. We have the second highest cost of capital, I repeat, of the 16 nations in the Business Council of Australia survey. Our capital cost is exceeded only by that of Labour New Zealand. That is one factor our industries have to live with.

We need also to take into account the real interest rate problems that we still have in Australia. Of course, the balance of payments crisis has exacerbated that. In spite of this, the Government is determined to pursue economic management on the basis of interest rates being its almost sole tool of economic policy, instead of making the appropriate structural adjustments, in particular to our industrial relations and wage fixing system, which it should be making.

I have noticed with some amusement the way the Treasurer (Mr Keating) stands at the despatch box on the other side of the table and repeatedly talks about the enormous achievements of this Government in the field of structural adjustment. We are waiting to see when those so-called achievements are going to bear some fruit. Living standards are falling. Many of our industries and particularly our smaller businesses are in a great deal of difficulty. Bankruptcies are at the highest rate they have been for many years, almost at a historical high. The cost of capital, the industrial relations and wage fixing system we are lumbered with in this country and our extraordinarily high interest rates are a major contribution to that.

I want to make one specific point in relation to this legislation, and that concerns the bed sheeting bounty scheme. The bed sheeting industry was of the view that the bounty scheme would be reviewed after February 1993. That was the understanding it had all along. But the Minister implied in his second reading speech that the scheme would be terminated in February 1993. I am not making a political point, but I ask the Minister in his reply to this debate to clarify that point, in particular so that the industry has no uncertainty. The point is not so much what the Minister means but that the industry is uncertain. The situation needs to be clarified.

The final point I wish to make relates to the Bounty (Ships) Act amendments which are incorporated in this legislation. This bounty scheme has caused some confusion in the industry. There have been quite a few difficulties. One of the difficulties relates to the ships built for the tourism industry. There was no understanding amongst shipbuilders, including shipbuilders in my own electorate, that the bounty would not be available for ships built for the tourist industry. Some of them went ahead and planned on the basis that they would be eligible for the bounty. No second reading speech indicated that that would be inappropriate. Yet we noted in a statement that Senator Ray made on 1 September 1988 that if bounties were provided for shipbuilding in the tourism industry, those sorts of ships would not `stimulate improvements in the design, operation and crewing of Australian ships'. It is hard to understand why ships for the tourism industry are somehow so totally different, so totally valueless in terms of design, operation and crewing that they are not eligible in any way for the bounty. It is a quite arbitrary decision by the Government to exclude this section of the shipbuilding industry. It will be interesting to hear from the Minister an explanation as to why that may be the case.

There has been quite a bit of confusion in the shipbuilding industry about registrations for bounty purposes. Again there is a great need for the policy to be made clearer than it is. It is a policy that has been administered with a great deal of departmental discretion and ministerial discretion. Sometimes the exercise of that discretion has been very unclear to people in the industry. But let me say it before the Minister says it: the shipbuilding industry has improved over the last couple of years. The Opposition is happy to see that occurring. We obviously want things to be going well in Australia. We do not just want to point to things that go badly. I note, in particular, that the Shipbuilding Consultative Group's annual report came out today. It pointed to a significant growth in shipbuilding orders in our shipbuilding industry, reaching orders worth $500m. The report made the surprising point that there were no recorded industrial disputes during the last year in the industry. Naturally we on this side of the House welcome that. If only it were true of most of our other industries.

I point to one other thing that appeared in the annual report of the Shipbuilding Consultative Group. It expressed the view that the Royal Australian Navy's submarine and Anzac frigate projects would provide very little benefit to the Australian shipbuilding industry. That came to me as something of a surprise, because the Premier of South Australia is always telling us how the salvation of South Australia lies first with the grand prix and secondly with the submarine project, although occasionally he needs to be reminded that 75 per cent of the submarine project will take place in other States and not South Australia. I am sorry about that; I wish it was all going to be in South Australia. He would be interested to know-he probably does know but he will not tell us-as, I think, would most people in Australia, that, according to the Shipbuilding Consultative Group's annual report, there will not be a lot of direct benefit for Australia's shipbuilding industry from the project. I am not sure I agree with that. As time goes on projects such as this may very well provide spin-off benefits. I hope that they give our shipbuilding industry greater technological capacity and know-how. I hope that the know-how is genuinely transferred, in the case of the submarine project, from Sweden to Australia and that we do not end up with Swedes coming here, doing all the technological jobs and then jumping on a jumbo jet and flying back to Sweden for training, but one wonders how many, and one wonders how enduring that training is going to be in terms of their being able to make some contribution to future design and technology in the Australian shipbuilding industry.

I am sure I have taken enough of the time of the House on this issue tonight. These are important measures for the textile, clothing and footwear industries in particular. Also, let me not denigrate the bounty that is provided for the shipbuilding industry. The industry regards that as valuable assistance, and this legislation will pass through the House with the support of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see the bipartisan support for the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The only thing on which I would disagree with the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) is the fact that this Government will not be changing. He will have to get used to another decade, and a decade after that, of Labor Government. It is ironic that he criticises structural adjustment. We have certainly done more in five years than the conservative forces did in 40 years. All they did was put a tariff monkey on the back of farmers and industry. We have thrown that tariff monkey off.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill aims to extend the life of the first two bounty schemes until 30 June 1995 as part of the Government's post-1988 textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan and to implement the phasing down of assistance under the schemes to a final rate of 30 per cent. This was announced in that plan and in the May economic statement introduced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 25 May. The textile, clothing and footwear industries have been the subject of a thorough examination by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC). The Commission brought down its report on 19 May 1986. The Commission's report found the industry to comprise what it termed a bewildering menu of measures ranging through quotas, tariffs, bounties, by-laws, country preferences, regional measures and payroll exemptions. Its reform package recommended a tops-down gradualism in reducing existing protection. It did so in the belief that there would be widespread community benefits. It also believed that this was the only way of cutting through the tangle of interventions which exist. The industry feared that rapid change in protection would severely restrict job opportunities.

The industry is characterised by a constant movement of firms and people into and out of the industry. It was estimated in the IAC report that about 30,000 people leave jobs in the industry each year. In recent years about the same number have entered. According to the National Institute of Labour Studies, unemployment is common among textile, clothing and footwear workers, with 24 per cent of those surveyed having been unemployed at some stage in the past three years. The IAC found that, with a 50 per cent rate of protection, employment would fall by 20,000. Spreading this over seven years gives an order of magnitude of less than 3,000 jobs a year. Compared with an annual turnover of 30,000, the IAC believed that this number was small. The industry itself faces continuing competitive changes. There are constant changes in fashion and buying habits. In addition, there are changes in technology. Naturally, workers in textiles, clothing and footwear industries fear technological changes, particularly if their jobs are under threat. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) in a keynote address at the twenty-fifth Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Congress in 1983 quoted United States union leaders who said:
If you robotise you lose 75 per cent of the workforce. If you fail to robotise you lose 100 per cent, because the firm goes out of business.

This description is just as fitting for textile, clothing and footwear industries as it was in the American experience. The Government in the May statement set about the task of continuing to provide industry restructuring which will greatly enhance job prospects in the manufacturing sector. Tariff rates greater than 15 per cent were phased in in five stages to 15 per cent over four years beginning on 1 July, 1988. Tariffs between 15 per cent and 10 per cent inclusive were phased to 10 per cent over four years. The main change to the post-1988 TCF plan was a reduction in tariffs of five percentage points for apparel and footwear. Tariff fabric and footwear parts items were also reduced by five percentage points. The TCF plan will end on 30 June 1995, eight months earlier than announced.

The Government also announced the establishment of a Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority which began operations on 1 June this year. The Authority was established to revitalise the TCF industries. It will implement a number of comprehensive progams aimed at encouraging raw materials processing, lifting industry efficiency, enhancing the skill base of TCF workers and increasing penetration into export markets. The Authority will be able to recommend to the Government a review of policy provisions should the Government's plan cause an excessive decline in domestic production.

New export development initiatives are being developed by the Authority in cooperation with Austrade. The Authority will be encouraging improved business practices in small firms through the facilities of the National Industry Extension Service and State government delivery agencies. There are special labour adjustment provisions designed to help workers adversely affected in the course of industry restructuring. There has been a great deal of emphasis in encouraging primary industry to develop value added industries. This Authority will set a priority for a wide-ranging raw materials processing program designed to facilitate greater domestic processing of Australian wool, cotton, hides and skins. Other programs which the Authority will direct include a scheme to encourage textile industry modernisation and another aimed at encouraging the emergence of world class manufacturing operations.

The TCF industry like all other industries, will benefit from a range of measures put in place by the Government over a number of years. The deregulated exchange rate has helped give Australian industry its most competitive edge ever. This year alone industry benefited from the abolition of the 2 per cent revenue duty. This represented a tax of about $240m a year on industry. More than 80 per cent of the duty was paid on intermediate or capital goods and amounted to a direct tax on production in Australia. The Government decided to remove the tax because it was seen as handicapping our manufacturers facing international competition. The net effect of abolishing the duty and reducing tariffs was to reduce input costs for many industries and make them more competitive on international markets.

The TCF and other industries will gain from the restructuring of the corporate taxation scales which makes the top company rate 39 per cent. Moreover, the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development will continue until 1991 and there will be a 100 per cent deductibility after that for companies, partnerships, individuals and trusts. Businesses are responding positively to the need to invest in research and development. Expenditure on research and development in 1986-87 rose by 12 per cent in real terms-the largest increase in any national sector. There had been a commensurate increase in the number of people working on research and development in the business sector. There was an increase of 10 per cent to more than 15,400 person years in 1986-87. Expenditure from, 1985-86 to 1986-87 was almost $3,120m-an increase of 7 per cent in real terms in just one year. However, Australia is trailing its main competitors in research and development spending. The gains we have made need to be built upon.

The Australian manufacturing sector is showing signs of recovery and there is evidence of growth in the range of products being produced. In my own State of Queensland, there was further growth in the manufacturing sector in the September quarter over the same period last year. There was a growth of 7.7 per cent from quite a low base. Queensland's manufacturing has shrunk in relative terms to other industries. Five years ago, it represented 12.5 per cent of national manufacturing. Latest figures indicate Queensland's share at just over 11 per cent.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that years of high tariff protection and an overvalued dollar impacted most severely in Queensland. Whereas in other States manufacturing industry was scaled down, in Queensland firms simply closed their doors. It is to be hoped that the range of measures outlined in this Bill, as well as the positive measures the Government has introduced, will revitalise industry throughout Australia. Queensland, being a primary industry State, needs to diversify to give itself economic strength. It should be ideally placed to take up the challenge offered by the new opportunities in TCF industries. The tariff monkey has been lifted off the back of industries. These bounty Bills serve to underline this trend and are worthy of support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation chiefly enacts amendments to the textile, clothing and footwear (TCF) plan announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in the context of the May statement. The first major component of the amendments is to the Bounty (Printed Fabrics) Act 1981. Whereas originally the TCF industries plan envisaged a phased reduction of bounty payable in this area from 56 per cent to 30 per cent by 1 March 1996, this amendment will see that phased reduction achieved by 30 June 1995. Similarly with the Bounty (Textile Yarns) Act 1977, this amendment changes the timetable for the phased reduction of bounties under this legislation. The bounty payable will now be reduced to 42.5 per cent on 1 March 1989, then to 35 per cent on 1 March 1993, and finally to 30 per cent on 1 March 1994. The other major change is in the form of an amendment to the Bounty (Bed Sheeting) Act 1977 which increases the total amount of bounty payable under this scheme from $600,000 per annum to $3,200,000 per annum. This system will operate until the scheme ends on 28 February 1993 and is an important form of assistance to this sector of the TCF industries.

SPEECH.PARA: It is most important for these legislative arrangements to be seen in their proper context-that being this Government's commitment to tripartite planning for industry restructuring and development. In November 1986 the Government rejected the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), report recommendations for the TCF industries. These recommendations focused solely on the area of tariffs, with a phased reduction of protection being recommended over a seven-year period. The IAC envisaged that this reduction would have led to a loss of 20,000 jobs in this period, although union estimates put the figure as high as 60,000. The IAC plan had no scope to look at retraining provisions for those workers who became victims of the restructuring. It had no investment incentive provisions for industry and there was no provision for a monitoring authority to review the effects of the changes on this industry. Such a plan would have had a disastrous impact on the TCF industries.

The TCF industries are an historically vital part of our manufacturing economy. In 1987 these industries were still employing nearly 10 per cent of our manufacturing work force and accounted for 7 per cent of manufacturing value added. The Government was therefore determined not to endanger such a vital component of our manufacturing industry through a haphazard policy approach such as that demonstrated to us over so many years by those on the opposite side of this House. Instead, in consultation with industry unions and employers, the Government developed its textile, clothing and footwear industries plan. The details of this plan were announced by the Minister in a statement to the House in June last year. This plan is designed to provide the industry with the opportunity to restructure on a gradual basis over a period of years. The emphasis is on making the industry more internationally competitive by developing local production advantages and by increasing productivity. A key element of the plan is a production guarantee and accompanying trigger mechanism, being administered by the TCF Industries Development Authority. This system is designed to ensure that, if production figures for the TCF industries fall below 85 per cent of the 1986 levels, the operation of the plan can be temporarily suspended until a report on the operation of the plan is presented to the Minister. This works to guarantee that rapid disruption to the industries, and accompanying job losses, will not occur. It represents a flexible and level-headed approach to restructuring.

Another key element contained in the plan is an industries restructuring strategy. This strategy contains four parts: first, a raw materials processing program; secondly, an industries efficiency program; thirdly, an industries infrastructure program; and, fourthly, an export development program. The raw materials processing program is aimed at rectifying the situation that has existed in Australia whereby, although we produce some of the highest quality wool, cotton and hides in the world, important parts of the processing of these raw materials have been carried out overseas. The plan aims to correct this situation. Through the assistance of government funding, Australian industry will carry out all stages of the processing of raw materials. The benefits in terms both of employment and our balance of trade should be obvious to all members of the House.

The industries efficiency program is aimed at helping to diagnose problems that may have existed with management techniques, at developing new designs and technology for the industries, and at improving the quality of finished products. An important part of this process for those companies participating in the adoption of a close consultative process with unions over all changes in the workplace. No improvements in efficiency will be won without the input of unions.

It should be noted that the development of consultative processes between management and unions has always been a key plank of the Government's industry restructuring plans. Those who work in an industry have a point of view on restructuring equally valid as that of employers. Those who work in an industry have a right to share in the decisions on the future development of their industries. I believe the TCF industries are a fine example of the value of this approach. The textile clothing and footwear unions have played a major role-a positive role-in the future development of their industry. I believe this House should commend them for their valuable work in this area.

The third program in the restructuring strategy is the industries infrastructure program. The focus here is on information services, research and development, and upgrading the skills of the work force through extensive retraining programs. The final component of the restructuring strategy is the export development program. Previously a large part of the exports from TCF industries have comprised products in early stages of processing. This program aims at giving government assistance for industry to build on the growth that has occurred in recent years in the export of finished products.

Development of export markets is crucial to the success of the restructuring plan. Australia has great advantages in the area of raw materials in this industry. We need to translate that advantage into success in the international market-place if the restructuring of the TCF industries is to be viable in the long term. The TCF industries plan represents a great step forward for industry planning in this country. It gives both employers and employees in these industries the guarantee of a stable environment in which to carry out necessary restructuring. The plan is therefore of great economic value to the industries.

The plan guarantees workers who are retrenched a package of retraining and relocation assistance measures which will assist them to return rapidly to the work force. The plan is therefore of great human value to the work force. It demonstrates that restructuring can occur in a well planned fashion that shows concern for those whose lives are disrupted by the process. This is the antithesis of the callous economic anarchy preached by the Opposition. I commend the amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for their contributions to the debate and, because I know honourable members are bursting to say something in the adjournment debate, I shall not detain the House for very long. I wish to answer a matter that was raised by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) in his debut as shadow Minister for Customs. He was anxious to find out about the proposed review of the bed sheeting bounty. As I said in my second reading speech, the provisions of the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill No. 2 will increase the maxiumum annual amount of bounty payable to bed sheeting manufacturers each year, commencing 1 March 1989, from $600,000 to $3.2m, until 28 February 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: I also indicated in the second reading speech that this bounty scheme would be reviewed. On 5 June 1987 Senator Button announced in the Senate the changes to the Government's industry policy as they relate to the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, which became known as the TCF plan. This plan is designed to encourage and facilitate the revitalisation and restructuring of Australia's TCF sector, of which the bed sheeting manufacturing industry is a part. At that time Senator Button also announced that further continuation of the bed sheeting bounty beyond 28 February 1993 would be subject to a review by the newly established TCF Development Authority. It is anticipated that the TCF Authority will conduct the inquiry into the continued assistance of the bed sheeting manufacturing industry in the middle of 1992 when the Authority conducts its scheduled mid-term review of the TCF plan. I think that was obviously the difficulty expressed by the honourable member for Mayo.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Defence Force Stores Depots: Sackings-Limericks-Daw Park Repatriation Hospital-Drugs-In Vitro Fertilisation Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Barry Jones) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Press reports this week in Toowoomba and Brisbane have suggested that the Department of Defence last week issued a notice of dismissal to a substantial number of civilian employees in Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) stores depots in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. The reasons for this action are unclear at present and yesterday, 19 October, I placed on notice a question with the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) seeking clarification and amplification. However, a local spokesman for the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union and the Australian Public Service Association, Mr Terry Olsen, of No. 7 Stores Depot in Toowoomba is quoted in the Toowoomba Chronicle on 15 October as saying `It is just all to do with dollars and cents', when commenting on the possible sackings of about 11 per cent of the civilian work force in his depot, which I understand might be the order of sackings in other States. Furthermore, yesterday's 19 October page 1 headline in that newspaper suggested-once again I quote-`Union action could ground F111's' pointing to possible industrial action with the Federated Storemen and Packers Union State Secretary, Mr Wal Rutherford, and assistant State Secretary, Mr Jeff Brahim, saying that action by No. 7 Stores Depot members could ground those aircraft within three days-a matter, no doubt, of interest to the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott).

SPEECH.PARA: A report in today's Brisbane Courier-Mail indicates that storemen in that depot in Toowoomba have imposed bans preventing some spare parts and high priority equipment being issued or being issued to aircraft, particularly to the F111 force of Amberley, the Army aviation centre at Oakey and Air Force elements in Townsville. The No. 7 Stores Depot commanding officer, Wing Commander Rod Brittain, has conceded that this industrial action will have `a fairly substantial impact'. I understand that a hearing was set down earlier today in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in Brisbane, but I am not aware at this time of the results.

This dispute has a serious potential to impair the operational effectiveness of the RAAF. Clearly this is not in the national interest. Over the last two days in this place we have heard a large degree of self-congratulation from the Government on defence matters. What I cannot understand is how civilian logistics staff can be sacked when large scale civilianisation was approved by the Minister for Defence last year to allow uniformed members of the Defence Force to assume a higher operational function. I ask: Who will assume the additional tasks of those personnel at a time of personnel stretch and poor morale?

I have discussed the press reports informally with the Minister for Defence. With the indulgence of the House, I ask that he give my question his early attention so that the matter, or the wider ramifications of the decision, can be explored, remedial action can be taken quickly and the understandable concerns of many civilian employees in Defence Force stores depots can be put to rest before the issue escalates to a point that everyone will regret. It is about time that the Minister for Defence matched his undoubted intellect and equipment acquisition skills with the equally important administrative needs so vital to his portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The year 1988 is one of great significance for Australia. I take the opportunity this evening to remind the House that it is also the centenary of the death of Edward Lear. Lear was a remarkable and talented man. He was born in London in 1812. He had to earn his living from the age of 15. He began by making tinted drawings of birds and assisted the famous John Gould. In 1837 he left England for health reasons, and lived as a landscape artist. But Lear is best known as the father of the limerick, the verse form he came across while entertaining the grandchildren of the Earl of Derby.

SPEECH.PARA: The limerick form did not originate with Lear. Scholars differ as to its origin. There are claims that it began in a play by Aristrophanes in 4 BC. Others claim an old English origin and certainly many nursery rhymes, such as Hickory, Dickory, Dock, which are of great antiquity are in limerick form. There is also argument about the origin of the name `limerick'. Incidentally, in Lear's time they were known as `learics'. One theory has it that the name came from an association with the Irish city of Limerick whose inhabitants apparently have a reputation for verse. A second theory associates the limerick with the old English dialect word `limmer', meaning scoundrel or rascal, in line with the association of the limerick with the bawdy and the obscene.

Lear's contribution was to transform the limerick from its bawdy form to a form later taken up by academics, philosophers, churchmen and others. Of course the earlier form lives on. It has made many famous, including the old man of Khartoum, the young man of Belgrade, the young lass from Madras, the young lady from Ryde, and assorted residents of Tashkent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us make sure that we are not unparliamentary here.
—It made them famous, Mr Acting Speaker, in a way in which I dare not have recorded in Hansard.
—It would be very difficult for you if you did.
—In the refined form we have seen observations on inflation. For example:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a young man from Montrose.
Who had pockets in none of his clothes,
When asked by his lass,
Where he carried his brass,
He said `Darling, I pay through the nose!'
There were also observations on the theory of relativity:
There was a young lady named Bright,
Whose speed was faster than light,
She set out one day
In a relative way,
And returned home the previous night.
Of course this change from the obscene to the refined version left some people unhappy. One said:
The limerick packs laughs anatomical
Into space that is quite economical
But the good ones I've seen
So seldom are clean
And the clean ones so seldom are comical

Whatever it changes, the limerick has been an enduring and popular verse form. The first limerick competition was staged in 1863 by the magazine Punch. It had to be discontinued because of the low tone of the entries. At the turn of the century, limerick competitions offered fabulous prizes, including houses and #3 a week for life. They were as popular as Sale of the Century.

More recently the Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio's clean limerick competition attracted over 1,000 entries. The Wilderness Society also staged a competition following the recent New South Wales election. Among the entries was this one:
There was a young man called Nick,
Who used to write with a Bic,
But being a frog,
Who became top dog,
He writes budgets today with a Schick.

We owe a lot to Edward Lear. In his memory tonight I am launching the parliamentary bicentennial limerick competition. It is open to all who work in this place. I undertake to enrol a panel of eminent judges and to arrange a suitable presentation to the winner. I propose to pass on entries received to a suitable charity for publication and sale. I exhort all members and senators and all who work in this place to get to work on their entries which should be received in my office by the end of November.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that, I suppose we should just say that bogongs should be bogongs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a hard act to follow, Mr Acting Speaker.
—It certainly is.

—On Sunday, 30 October, I am convening an important meeting of the Gilles Plains-Hampstead branch of the Returned Services League. The meeting is titled `Save the Repat', the Daw Park Repatriation General Hospital. A friend and colleague of mine, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), a Vietnam veteran and shadow Minister for the Arts, will be the keynote speaker. I bring it to the attention of the House again tonight because earlier today the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) claimed that our policy would shabbily treat veterans and that this much-vaunted forum that I am convening did not have a lot of substance. I reiterate a couple of points for her attention and for the attention of the veterans. It is clear that there will be no change in 10 years. We have a firm commitment until 1998, as set out in our Veterans Affairs fair go for veterans policy put out by the shadow Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: I have researched it a bit further. Since Budget week, we have had five Thursdays of petitions sent to the Bills and Papers Office, on which there have been more than 7,740 signatures concerning the decision to place certain pharmaceutical drugs on the authority list. Seventy members in this House, on both sides-50 from the Liberal and National parties-are included in that 7,740. My electorate alone contained 244. Some 40 of those 53 drugs have now gone back for review. But the honourable member for Hawker has not seen fit to have anything to do with the petitions on drugs or the pension issue. Honourable members should remember that she made the classic statement, `Why should pensioners get any concessions?', and I am sure that pensioners and veterans are very aware of the pharmaceuticals and their market-linked investments.

The other matter is that my electorate of Adelaide has been rocked by the recent prosecution and conviction of former Drug Squad chief Barry Moyse on 17 drug offences. The sworn evidence of a super-grass, a Mr X, has put Barry Moyse away for a very long time and cut off all avenues of appeal. His testimony is a compelling account of the sleazy world of marijuana, smack, grass, dope, crack, needles, bongs, pushers and pedlars. This is not a script for Miami Vice or Hill Street Blues. This is Adelaide.

For months I have been on the drug trail myself in the grass-roots area of drugs in schools, with anxious parents, my constituents, giving evidence to the Drug Squad. I personally handed over to the police the evidence given to me by a worried relative-marijuana pipes and implements that kids in my electorate have, unfortunately, been using to free-base.

My concern over this sort of problem moved me to convene a public meeting, a drug forum, in order that my constituents could show their concern by standing up to be counted and, at the same time, find out what they could do about drugs; not with holier-than-thou experts, but with former drug addicts and dealers, street kids-Poppa John T. was one-and those at the coal-face who had been introduced to drugs by their school mates. The meeting in the Enfield Civic Centre was packed. People sat or stood in rapt attention as they listened to speakers put lie to the Deputy Premier's claim that there was no problem with drugs in schools. I have here a copy of a story that appeared in the Adelaide News on Thursday, 16 June last, in which Dr Don Hopgood accused me of a cheap political stunt and deceit over claims about young children using marijuana in Adelaide's schools. I also have a copy of a story that appeared in the News of the following day, referring to a single mother who said her two teenage children both used drugs while at school. I was there when this worried woman told reporter Sean Whittington that children as young as 13 were using drugs in school playgrounds.

Did Hoppy Hopgood recant or retract the statement made by his press secretary? No. Did he apologise on behalf of his press secretary, who obviously wrote this rubbish? No. And since then, two students have been expelled from a private school for using and peddling drugs. The press ran an article `Drug dealers beware' because they were operating at Tea Tree Plaza, and two principals had to come out in support of that; and yet the Bannon Government denies that there is a drug problem. As Mr X spills the beans on South Australia's drug industry, and as the truth finally comes to light, I suggest that the Deputy Premier at least has some explaining to do, or at most I call on him to resign.

The drug forum I convened at Enfield Civic Centre passed two resolutions which I am currently acting upon. Time does not permit me to complete this. As the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) and Fairfax (Mr Adermann) reiterated yesterday-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —All of us would have read today in the newspaper of the multiple birth of three children in Perth to a mother who had been assisted by in vitro fertilisation. The question involved a surrogate mother and, as such, raises many moral and ethical questions. Indeed, the doctor in charge of the pregnancy, Dr John Yovich, said that he believed a case could be made for compassionate family surrogacy as was the case in this episode. But, of course, I think the scope of dealing with that issue goes beyond a five-minute adjournment address. Suffice it to say, as is quoted in the Age today, that Mr Daniel Callahan, Director of the internationally renowned Hastings Centre in New York, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are caught in the middle of a major social experiment without the faintest idea how it should be conducted.

I suppose that that is the status of the surrogacy debate in this country at the moment. I wish to focus on the in vitro fertilisation (IVF) program and the future of this program. I want to make some comparisons on the basis of cost-benefit analysis. There is a great deal of pressure on government to fund new technology and new procedures in medicine. Let us look at some of the programs that are involved. The average cost of heart transplants is about $60,000 to $70,000. On top of that, those who have a heart transplant need considerable treatment after the procedure and there is anti-rejection therapy which costs in the region of $8,000 to $10,000 a year. So it is a considerably expensive procedure.

A liver transplant, which again is something that is gaining popularity in this country, costs about twice to three times as much and requires the same anti-rejection therapy. We find that governments increasingly have to make decisions about the cost-benefit analysis of such procedures. For instance, in Great Britain it is necessary for governments to make decisions that kidney dialysis is not available to people over 55 years of age or hip replacements are not available to people over 65 years of age. Increasingly, in other countries and in Australia we have to look at these factors.

There has been a great deal of controversy about the cost-benefit analysis of the in vitro fertilisation program. If we look at the program in Australia we find that 1,850 live children have been born as a result of the program during the last 10 years. It seems that the average percentage success is about 8.8 per cent of in vitro treatment cycles resulting in an ongoing pregnancy and the birth of a child. This is an estimation, but there are a number of programs and protocols throughout the country and it seems that this is a reasonable one.

At this rate, the cost of each IVF baby is at least $40,000 and therein I suppose lies the controversy when we talk about the IVF program because there are many who believe that this is excessive. Let us put aside the ethical and moral questions. There are those who believe that we should look at the cost-benefit analysis. Perhaps that is excessive but when we compare it with heart or liver transplants I think it is easy to see that this procedure provides, in the vast majority of cases, a fit and healthy citizen for 60 to 70 years of life and thus it is a program that we should be supporting.

In 1987 the number of couples in the IVF program was 5,000. So we can see that it is growing in popularity. The Government commissioned a report into the IVF program. A number of funding options were considered by the Government because it was concerned about the cost of the procedure and the open-ended way in which it was presently funded. There was great concern amongst my constituents before the Budget. Indeed, there was great relief when no changes were made and at least the status quo was preserved in the Budget. But it is certainly true that much more consideration is needed about this issue in a country where the birth rate is falling and 10 per cent of the population is infertile. This offers a chance for many couples who feel the hopelessness and frustration of infertility. Indeed, there are many questions to be answered. More research is needed. The Government needs to consider the access which is available to couples who want this procedure. Certainly there are moral and ethical questions to be dealt with.

If we look in totality at this procedure I believe that it deserves our support. I am sure that the protocols will become streamlined and the effectiveness of the procedures will improve. Those moral and ethical questions that have been resolved in respect of heart and liver transplants similarly will be resolved in this case. It is a program that deserves our support.
