QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 15 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What properties is the Commonwealth planning to dispose of by 1990 in (a) NSW, (b) VIC, (c), QLD, (d) SA, (e) WA, (f) TAS, (g) the ACT and (h) the NT.
(2) Which of these properties have been listed by the Australian Heritage Commission on the Register of the National Estate.
(3) What covenants, agreements and other undertakings would it require purchasers to comply with to ensure that the National Estate value of these properties is preserved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth is planning to dispose of a number of properties by 1990.
The list of properties identified at this stage is variable and subject to alteration, additions and deletions over time.
Due to the changing nature of the disposals program, I do not consider it appropriate or meaningful to provide a detailed answer to this part of the question.
(2) Of the properties currently identified for disposal, the following have been entered by the Australian Heritage Commission on the Register of the National Estate.

(a) New South Wales: Vacant Land, Castle Hill; House (Lot 1) ``Cliffbrook'' 45 Beach Street, Coogee; Commonwealth Stores &Office, 5-7 Hickson Road, Millers Point; Anzac Rifle Range (Part), Franklin Street, Malabar; Residences, Barrenjoey Headland, Barrenjoey; Lightstation, Montague Island; Surplus Property, Macquarie Lightstation, Watson's Bay; Cockatoo Island, Sydney.
(b) Victoria: Old Customs House, 126 Nelson Place, Williamstown; Lighthouse, Cape Otway; Lighthouse, Point Hicks: ``Majella'' 473 St Kilda Road, City.
(c) Queensland: Customs House, Petrie Bight, Brisbane; Brisbane Airport Old Terminal, Areas 6 &7, Eagle Farm, Brisbane; Part of Lighthouse Reserve, Moreton Island.
(d) South Australia: Navaid, Cape Du Couedic Lighthouse, Kangaroo Island; Customs House, Commercial Road, North Parade, Port Adelaide.
(e) Western Australia: Lightkeepers Quarters &Land, Jarman Island, Lighthouse, Yardie Creek Road, Exmouth.
(f) Tasmania: Eddystone, No. 3 Quarters, Eddystone Point Lightstation; Laboratory Site, 121 Hampden Road, Battery Point; Part of Light Station Low Head.

(3) When disposing of heritage property, officers of the Australian Property Group consult with the Australian Heritage Commission and the office of the Australian Government Solicitor on the most appropriate form of protection for such properties once they leave Commonwealth ownership.

In those States and Territories where there are suitable legal mechanisms available, protection of heritage properties is provided in conjunction with the National Trust. The requirements differ between most State/Territorial Governments, but the various covenants, agreements and other undertakings are all designed to adequately protect the National Estate.
In South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria, which have effective heritage legislation, conservation orders or similar protective planning mechanisms are put in place.
In addition, properties may be disposed of through long-term lease arrangements where none of the options outlined above are likely to achieve an adequate level of protection.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What procedures are adopted to ensure the swift retrieval of drugs which, for any reason, need to be recalled.
(2) How are members of the pharmaceutical industry advised of these recalls.
(3) Were normal recall procedures adopted in the case of antibiotic Achromycin, batch number 8G048A.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The procedure for the recall of drugs (and therapeutic devices) is described in a document called ``Uniforn Recall Procedure for Therapeutic Goods''. This represents a voluntary agreement between the Commonwealth and State health authorities and the therapeutic goods industry in Australia.

The procedure is based on a network of people comprising of an Australian co-ordinator in the Recalls Section of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, recall officers in each State and Territory health authority and two personnel in each company which markets therapeutic goods in Australia.

Recalls are carried out to different levels within the distribution chain depending on the nature of the problem, extent of the product's distribution and the degree of hazard involved. The health authorities monitor the effectiveness of the recall and follow-up the reason and also the remedial action taken by the company to prevent a recurrence of the problem.

(2) In many cases, recall action is initiated when the company advises the Australian co-ordinator of the problem. In other instances, the company may be advised of a problem which has been referred to the Australian co-ordinator.
In all cases, negotiation occurs between the company and the Australian co-ordinator prior to the company implementing the recall action.

(3) Yes. The company notified the Department of the problem. On the basis of expert medical opinion concerning the hazard represented by the presence of wire fragments in orally ingested capsules, the company and the Australian co-ordinator agreed to an urgent consumer level recall.

A media release and press advertisements, with an agreed text, were released. The media release occurred on the same afternoon that the Australian co-ordinator was notified of the problem by the company.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer upon notice, on 25 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say, at the most recent date for which figures are available, which countries were in arrears in their interest payments or repayments of foreign debt; if so, (a) what was the amount of the arrears and (b) what proportion are the arrears of each country's total foreign debts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The IMF's 1988 Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions lists 56 member countries which, at the end of 1987, were maintaining external payments arrears to all sources on both current and capital transactions, of which interest and principal arrears on foreign debt may be a component. These are:

Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Benin, Bolivia, Brazil, Burkina Faso, Burma, Central African Republic, Chad, Comoros, Congo, Costa Rica, Cote d'Ivoire, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, El Salvador, Equatorial Guinea, The Gambia, Ghana, Grenada, Guatemala, Guinea, Guinea-Bissau, Guyana, Haiti, Honduras, Iraq, Liberia, Libya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Morocco, Mozambique, Nicaragua, Nigeria, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Poland, St Lucia, Sao Tome and Principe, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Sudan, Suriname, Syrian Arab Republic, Tanzania, Togo, Uganda, Venezuela, Vietnam, Zaire, Zambia.
IMF data on arrears to all sources is unsubstantiated and is not published for individual countries.

The IMF report also notes that, from a peak of SDR 44 billion recorded at the end of 1984, total external payments arrears of IMF members are estimated to have declined by over SDR7 billion in 1985 and increased again by about SDR8 billion in 1986. (At 30 June 1988, one SDR, or Special Drawing Right, was equivalent to $A1.6504). Provisional data indicates that the amount of arrears decreased significantly in 1987, possibly by SDR 7 billion. The number of countries experiencing arrears fell to 56 at end-1987 from 58 a year earlier; this number had been rising continuously from 1976 to 1986 (reflecting the difficulty of eliminating arrears once they have been incurred). Of the countries for which data is available, 25 experienced increases in existing arrears and 21 were able to reduce arrears. The large reduction in the amount of arrears outstanding was mainly due to debt reschedulings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the International Monetary Fund planning to change the conditions under which compensatory financing will be available to developing countries; if so, (a) what are the new conditions and (b) will the changes increase the number and stringency of conditions which developing countries must meet before compensatory loans will be approved.
(2) What is the Government's position on the proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has recently reviewed the operations of its Compensatory Financing Facility for Export Fluctions (CFF) which was established in 1963 to assist members (especially primary product exporting countries) confronted with balance of payments difficulties arising from a temporary shortfall in export earnings associated with factors largely beyond the member's control.

On 26 August 1988 the IMF announced that it had established a Compensatory and Contingency Financing Facility (CCFF). The new facility replaces the existing CFF and also introduces an external contingency financing facility to help maintain the momentum of Fund-supported growth-oriented adjustment programs in the face of unexpected adverse external shocks. The CCFF will provide assistance to member countries encountering balance of payments difficulties that arise out of temporary export shortfalls, adverse external contingencies or excessive costs of cereal imports.

(a) The amount of compensatory financing available under the CCFF depends on the circumstances of the member. Where a member has a satisfactory balance of payments position but is confronted with a temporary export shortfall or excessive cereal import costs, the existing CFF access limit of 83 per cent of the member's quota under either component has been maintained. In all other circumstances, the amount of financing available under the CCFF is 40 per cent of quota on account of each of the export shortfall and the external contingency components and 17 per cent of quota for the cereal import costs component. In addition, there is one optional tranche of 25 per cent of quota which can be used to supplement any one of these three elements, at the choice of the member. Total access under the new facility is therefore 122 per cent of quota, compared with total access of 105 per cent under the previous CCFF.
Access to the compensatory component in respect of export shortfall is available in three tranches:

20 per cent of the member's quota, where the member's record of cooperation in recent periods has been unsatisfactory, or its existing policies are seriously deficient in relation to the size of its existing or prospective payments imbalances, but where the Fund is satisfied that the member has taken action that gives an assurance that policies corrective of the member's balance of payments problem will be adopted;

an additional 20 per cent of the member's quota (or total accesss of 40 per cent of quota) when the member has a Fund arrangement under which performance is broadly satisfactory, or if the Fund approves such an arrangement for the member at the time of the request;

the optional tranche of 25 per cent of the member's quota (or total access of 65 per cent of quota) if the member has a Fund arrangement under which a review is completed by the Fund at the time of the request.

(b) The essential objective of the new facility is to revitalise access to the lower tranche and thereby improve the timeliness of CFF assistance. This can be compared with recent practice where purchases in both tranches had become increasingly linked to approval of stand-by arrangements. It is designed also to provide for possible use of the compensatory element during the course of programs that are supported by stand-by arrangements to help cushion the program from the effects of unexpected export shortfalls.

(2) The Australian Government supported the restructuring of the CFF (including the addition of a contingency element to help ensure that Fund programs were adequately financed). The Government supported the position that the operation of the CCFF should ensure that purchases under the new facility provide timely compensation for export shortfalls, while at the same time providing reasonable assurance of protection of the Fund's resources.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that patents have been granted for Kangaroo Paw; if so, why was it necessary on 28 November 1987 to call for public comment on the inclusion of Kangaroo Paw under the Plant Variety Rights Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, I understand that patents have been granted for some varieties of Anigozanthos, the Kangaroo Paw. Patents, however, are not administered by my portfolio.

It is necessary to call for public comment on the inclusion of Kangaroo Paw under the PVR Act to canvass public interest in seeking Plant Variety Rights on Anigozanthos varieties. The fact that there are some varieties protected by patents does not disqualify other new varieties from Plant Variety Rights.

An Australian plant breeder who holds patents for some of his varieties of Kangaroo Paw, informed the Plant Variety Rights office that his breeding work was completed in the mid 1970's and he has been waiting since then for the Plant Variety Rights Act to be passed. He said that he would have preferred Plant Variety Rights protection because it is more appropriate but was unable to delay any longer the marketing of his varieties and resorted instead to the protection of patents.
